description: Noël Coward’s riff on the Horse’s Neck is a classic Prohibition-era cocktail that appears in his 1951 play, Relative Values. More to the point though he touts it as the ultimate hangover cure – the Angostura Bitters and Ginger Ale will settle the stomach, the aspirin will clear your head and the Brandy is there to soothe your soul.

If you are after a little colour and froth, then the Purple Haze Sour is the fruity Whiskey Sour riff you’ve been looking for. This cocktail mixes Bain’s Single Grain Whiskey, Sweet Vermouth, Blueberry Puree, Apple Juice, a blend of Lemon & Lime citrus, Sweet Vermouth, Vanilla Syrup, Bitters, and Aquafaba for that bit of foam.

When it comes it comfort cocktails, there is nothing better than an Old Fashioned, but if you want to take that comfort factor up a notch, then 1800 Tequila’s Cinnamon Smoked Old Fashioned can’t be beat. The smokey complexity of Añejo Tequila mixed with the smoked from the grated cinnamon, and the citrus notes of the Orange Bitters will make this drink a favourite.

While you could just think of the Going Out West cocktail as a Rye Whiskey and Mezcal riff on an Old Fashioned, the drink is made just that little bit more special with the addition of Averna.
“Smashing the modern day expectation of too much work and not enough play, the nightcap ensures that early nights and bourgeois banality are pushed aside for one evening at least. Yet Vanessa often found that the conversations she had when drinking a nightcap were, like the drink itself, tinged with equal amounts of pleasure and regret.”

Wonderfully aromatic with a medium-dry finish, the Coronation Cocktail No. 1, is one of those classic drinks that you’ve probably never heard of but certainly won’t regret making. The delicate notes of almond from the sherry and fruitiness from the maraschino work beautifully when added to the Dry Vermouth and Orange Bitters.

Making its first appearance mid last century, the Rusty Nail is the very definition of a classic.  But classic or not, the proportions used of Scotch to Drambuie vary widely. We tend to prefer a 3:1 ratio but it really is just a matter of taste.

Ginger Liqueur can bring a semi-sweet, semi-spicy flavour to cocktails that are truly refreshing and perfect for summer. The Ginger Snap created by Gary Regan in 2007 is a well balanced Gin Collins-style drink with Gin, Ginger Liqueur, Triple Sec, Lemon Juice, Angostura & Soda Water.
Created by Erin Ward at Carmine’s, the Amaretto Sidecar is a nutty version of the classic cocktail The Sidecar. Replacing Cognac with Amaretto, this drink is the perfect end-of-week relaxer.

If you are a fan of the classic Sidecar cocktail, then you will love the Asian inspired, Tokyo Sidecar. While keeping the Cointreau from the original recipe, this riff swaps out the Cognac for Japanese Whisky and the Lemon Juice for Yuzu Juice, for a bright cocktail that will certainly take you on a journey.

If you are after a Sazerac-style drink but with both Bourbon and Cognac, then the Black Rose is perfect for this evening. Slightly fruitier than its new Orleans cousin, this drink is sweetened with a little Grenadine rather than a sugar cube and seasoned with both Peychaud’s and Angostura Bitters.

Back in the 1950s when A-bombs were being tested in Nevada, an unknown bartender in Las Vagas came up with a little drink called the Atomic Cocktail. With Vodka, Cognac, Amontillado Sherry & topped with Brut Champagne, all we can say is this is a drink to handle with care.

If you like your Negroni on the drier side, then make yourself The Tunnel Negroni as created by Franck Audoux owner of the Cravan in Paris. With the usual amount of Gin, this drink hen uses an equal amount of Dry Vermouth but then less Campari, which is filled out with a bit of Sweet Vermouth.

Adding a little smoke and pineapple tartness to the classic Old Fashioned, the Smoked Pineapple Old Fashioned is the perfect summer riff. Mixing Bourbon, Pineapple Syrup and Tiki Bitters, this drink is perfect for summer barbeques and beachside imbibing.

If you think your Greyhound cocktail needs a little bit of European flair, then add a bit of Campari to the mix to create an Italian Greyhound. The Campari ups the bitterness of the grapefruit … not a lot, but basically by the required amount …

This tall, refreshing, Aperitif-style drink was created by the Spanish Martini brand ambassador, Ignacio Vázquez in 2015. The Summer Americano mixes Sweet Vermouth, Campari, Suze & Cardamom Bitters before being topped by Tonic Water

Created at Perla Negra, the Ume Sangria embraces all the fruit flavours that you love from a Sangria but without all the fuss. Mixing Ume Plum Liqueur, Pinot Grigio, White Rum (we’re using Ten To One), Simple Syrup and Lavender Bitters, this drink is perfect for a mid afternoon indulgence.

If you want to take your Negroni in a slightly more exotic direction, then do as the bartenders at Whisler’s in Austin did and make a My Fair Lady. Using the ever versatile Pisco as the primary spirit (instead of Gin), this drink uses Cocchi Americano and Grapefruit Bitters, as well as the usual Campari

When this drink was created by Erick Castro at Polite Provisions in 2019, he used a ‘grasshopper salt rim’ (with sea salt and dehydrated grasshoppers). As grasshoppers (dehydrated or otherwise) are not always easy to find, we suggest just using sea salt. Either way, the mix of Mezcal, Sweet Vermouth, Strega and Grapefruit Bitters creates a drink that’s beautifully loaded.
“While a nightcape is usually drunk at the end of the night as a way to unwind, Vanessa often used the drink as a jumping off point to discuss everything from philosophy to popular culture. Well-read and surprisingly eloquent (especially with a few Mezcals under her belt), there are few who would not say ‘that girl is a pistol’ when describing her 2am soliloquies.”

One of our favourite classics, the Old Fashioned is basically a glass of booze sweetened with sugar and seasoned with Bitters.  So grab a glass, an once or two of Bourbon, a sugar cube and a dash or so of Angostura and Orange Bitters and experience this classic for yourself.

Believed to be one of the first Vodka cocktails in the US, with references going back to the mid-1930s, the Gypsy Queen is a complex drink with flavours of spiced honey and herbal notes. With a simple stir of Bénédictine and Bitters, this drink could easily become a favourite.

If you love a dessert-like cocktail then the Trifle Cocktail is a drink that is not to be trifled with. The combination of Raspberry flavoured Vodka, Black Raspberry Liqueur & Drambuie make this a drink worth indulging in at the end of the night.

My love of Margaritas and delicate aperitifs inspired my creation for this year’s Patrón Perfectionist. The balance of Jasmine and Mandarin allows for the quality and naturally occurring notes of Patron Silver to shine through – Corina Retter – Capitano – Melbourne

If you are after a simple, yet wonderfully spicy Whisky cocktail then you can’t go past a Whisky Mac. With only two ingredients – a good blended Scotch and Green Ginger Wine, this drink is the ideal sipper for the end of a long day.

The Sunset Sour uses the classic template of a Whiskey Sour, but with the addition of some Raspberries and Orange Juice, to create a a beautiful gradient cocktail, with the dehydrated orange garnish representing the sun over a cloud of foam.
“The fact that their friends had turned up was an overwhelming relief for Vanessa. It wasn’t that Juan (her faithful PA) wasn’t fun to hang with, but his time with the local ranger had lead to an ongoing commentary on the birds of upstate New York, which was seriously beginning to drive Vanessa to drink (a rather tasty Sunset Sour, if you please).”

Winning 20 out of 21 races during the season in 1919-1920, Man O’ War was considered one of the greatest racing horses to ever live. Therefore it’s only fitting that the drink that bears his name is also outstanding with Bourbon, Cointreau, Sweet Vermouth, Lemon Juice and Simple Syrup.

With a nice swing between sweet and sour, the Fig Sidecar makes a tasty riff on the classic. So, yes, as well as the Fig Liqueur, there is the usual Brandy, Cointreau and Lemon Juice that all maks this drink divinely tempting.

The drink I’ve created for the Patrón Perfectionists competition represents the concept of a journey. It tells the story of how, over time, our personal journey influences everything, and everyone, around us. My drink is also an homage to my staff, and the way we grow together and learn from each other – Pauric Kennedy – Baragaroo House – Sydney

Believed to be created by Harry MacElhone at Harry’s Bar in Paris, Between The Sheets is a rum riff on a Sidecar. With Gold Rum, Cognac, Cointreau and Lemon Juice, the name refers to the drink’s potency and the potential for a risqué end to an evening.
If you are after a Margarita riff that has a slightly more healthy spin, then the electro lights in coconut water and the antioxidants in ginger make the Coconut Ginger Margarita the perfect choice.

Created by Andres Juarez at Raines Law Room, the Plum Role is a long, refreshing drink that mixes Gin, UME Plum Liqueur, Jasmine Tea Syrup and both Grapefruit and Lime Juice, before being topped with Soda Water.

When the weather is warm there is nothing like the flavour hints of Basil, Ginger and Tequila mingling with watermelon to create a long, fruity and refreshing drink that we like to call a Watermelon & Basil Smash

Wonderfully floral and balanced, the Tango cocktail is as dynamic as it’s namesake. The botanical nature of the gin works as a wonderful base allowing the Passionfruit Liqueur and the Ruby Grapefruit Juice to dance with each other in harmony.

The Gin Gin Cocktail is as simple as it sounds, a wonderful little mix of Gin and Ginger Wine. As simple as it may be, don’t let the  unassuming nature of this cocktail fool you, it has a nice spice while being surprisingly good.

With a nice bite of Cynar, the Mezchine Head is a drink that has a smoky, ginger, yet definitely tropical flavour that would make it equally at home on a beach in the south pacific, as it will be on your drinks trolley.
“What Vanessa loved most about an opening night was the guaranteed casting couch calibre of the crowd. While Juan, her faithful PA, contemplated the use of Mezcal in a variety of tropical libations, Vanessa kept on eagle eye on the door, ever on the look out for husband no 3.”

With the best possible name that a cocktail could ever have, we present a Bee’s Knees riff, the Oldest Living Confederate Widow. When you mix Gin, Honey Syrup, Lemon Juice, a couple of dashes of Orange Bitters & a dash of Absinthe, it makes for a truly refreshing cocktail.

While the name of this drink is something you should never say aloud except into a CB radio, the Papa Bear provides a delicate spiced and honeyed Cognac flavour. Created in 2008 by Tim Homewood at the Dirty Martini Bar in London, it mixes Cognac, Honey Liqueur, Lemon Juice and Honey Syrup.

Obviously a riff on the classic Rusty Nail, the Mexican Nail incorporates the flavours of Drambuie and the peatiness of a single malt Scotch but adds another layer with the addition of Reposado Tequila for a nice complexity.
Long and tropical in feel, the Dingo is a sweet, fruity cocktail that’s, luckily, not too clawing, but comes with a nice little kick, and courtesy of the Rum and Whiskey in the mix.

The Dandy Lion can only be described as a grown-up riff on a classic G&T. With muddled Cucumber, Absinthe and a little Lemon Juice, all added to the expected Gin & chilled Tonic Water, this is a riff with a little more sophistication.

The White Manhattan not only pays homage to the early days of Moonshine but also to its namesake. It blends and balances White Whisky with Dry Vermouth, then brings out the citrus notes of the Lillet Blanc with the addition of Orange Bitters.

No matter what time you intend to wake up, there is no better way to start a weekend morning than with a coffee cocktail. Mixing Bourbon, Caramel Syrup, a little Cold Brew Oat Milk Latte, a whole egg and a dash of Mole Bitters, the drink will certainly help start the weekend right.

The Elixirita is basically a Tommy’s Margarita with a splash of Cognac. It was created by H.Joseph Ehrmann and is the signature Margarita at his bar Elixir in San Francisco and mixes Reposado Tequila, Lime Juice, Agave Syrup and Cognac.

The Modern Pink Gin is a nice little riff on the original that of course includes Gin and the Angostura Bitters but for modern tastes, add just enough Simple Syrup to highlight the sweeter elements in the gin and the bitters.

A classic Key West cocktail, it’s easy to think of the Rum Runner as a fruitier rum version of a Singapore Sling, but this drink is certainly more than the sum of its parts and is a fusion of sweet fresh fruit and spicy rum.

A riff on the quintessential summer cup cocktail, the Strawberry Pimm’s Cup is similar to the original, except that the Strawberries are soaked in Pimm’s overnight, so as to up the Strawberry flavour of the overall drink.

If you substitute the gin from a Last Word for Irish Whiskey, then you get an Dublin Mistrel. Named after Frank Fogarty, a vaudeville perormer nown as the Dublin Minstrel, te drink mixes Irish Whiskey with Green Chartreuse, Lime Juice and Maraschino Liqueur.

When it comes to creating a riff on a Cosmpolitan, the Honey Cosmopolitan is the perfect example of what balance can achieve. Using the Cranberry Juice and Lime Juice from the original, this drink adds Grapefruit Juice and Grapefruit Vodka for the citrus elements and honey syrup for its delicious flavour and richness.

There’s nothing more delicious or satisfying than a sour and with the inclusion of Figs, the Fig Sour definitely raises the bar. With Fig Liqueur, Galayya Liqueur, Lemon Juice and egg white, this is a drink that you’ll end up craving.

Grab a towel, your sunglasses and find a place by the pool, cause it’s time for an iconic classic cocktail. First made in Puerto Rico back in 1952, the Piña Colada is a sweet drink made with White Rum, Coconut Cream and Pineapple Juice.

The most famous of the Aperol cocktails, the Aperol Spritz is the refreshing taste of summer; perfect for sipping as the afternoon heat dies down. Made with the lovely, yet slightly bitter taste of Aperol, and fizzed up with Soda Water & Prosecco, the vibrant orange colour and flavour of this aperitif is unmistakable.

A little smoky, a tad bitter but with a nice floral element, La Parka is the cocktail for which you’ve been searching.  Just add some Mezcal and Lemon Juice to Punt E Mes and little St Germain and you’ll see what we mean.
“While Vanessa didn’t want to say goodbye to Singapore, she knew it was time to go. It was a great city with spectacular bars and even better bartenders, but her own city was waiting. Yet as she sat at the airport, with her new favourite Mezcal cocktail in her hand, she realised that this little sojourn had renewed her faith that living a life in liquid was always worthwhile.”

No matter what other questionable choices Debbie has made, this is one drink that Debbie should definitely do. Created by Zachary Gelnaw-Rubin at New York’s Dutch Kills, this tasty little sour has Reposado Tequila, Averna, Lemon Juice & Maple Syrup

While traditionally, an “Angel’s Share” is the term for the percentage of a whisky’s volume that is lost to evaporation, it is also the name of an amazing Cognac cocktail. With Orange Marmalade, Cognac VSOP, Licor43, Lemon Juice & Sugar Syrup, this cocktail has a wonderful citrus flavour with a  hint of Vanilla.

Described by some as having bits of a Brooklyn Cocktail and other bits of a Godfather Cocktail, the Brooklyn Godfather with Bourbon, Amaretto, Dry Vermouth & Sweet Vermouth is really the best of both worlds.

The Gin & Jam Cocktail is one that can easily be adapted to your tastes. We rather like it with Raspberry Jam but the joy of this drink is that any Jam will work equally well. A good floral Gin, some lemon Juice, Sugar Syrup and a little Jam and you are set.

Nothing could be simpler or tastier than the Debonair Cocktail. Created in the 1990s by Gary Regan this rich, sophisticated Single Malt Scotch-based drink has a wonderful zing of spice from the Ginger Liqueur.

As far as Kumquat cocktails goes, nothing is more refreshing than a Kumquat Quest. This drink is a crisp and citrusy combination of Vodka, fresh Lime Juice, Sugar and Kumquats, topped with Grand Marnier.

Inspired by the Swedish concept of Fika (a ritual that emphasises the importance of connection, time out and enjoying a sweet treat or two), the nordic brand Flävar is here to tell you that Schnapps is back! So we start our pre-Christmas Schnapps journey with a Strawberry Kiss, which mixes Raspberry & Liquorice Flävar with Orgeat and Lime Juice.

Phil Ward from New York’s Death & Co puts a nice floral twist on the Old Fashioned with his Elder Fashioned. With Gin, St Germain and the zesty citrus of Orange Bitters, this is a nice cleansing and boozy riff on the classic.

Created by Shannon Mustipher, at Glady’s, Brooklyn, this elegant riff on the Parasol cocktail leans into Baijiu’s natural fruity flavour by combining it with Passionfruit Liqueur, Lime & Pineapple Juice to create the perfect summer drink.

The Bushwick is a tasty Italian-American mix that was created by Phil Ward in 2009 when he was at Mayahuel in New York. It is, as you might assume from the name a riff on the Brooklyn with Rye, Sweet Vermouth, Maraschino Liqueur and Amer Picon.

Inspiration to make my cocktail comes from the culture, passion and feeling that is reflected in a bottle of Patrón. Culture of perfecting the tequila with passionate hand involved in the process and the feeling that emerges while drinking Patrón. This inspires me to make a drink, which not only tastes good but gives that aesthetic pleasure a feeling of warmth that urges people to order another one and a drink that is made by 100% blue agave Tequila – Pravin Phuyal – Hot Tamale – Darwin.

A first sight, this seemingly impossibly spirit-forward cocktail appears to need more than A Moment Of Silence to be consumed, but the Apricot Brandy balances everything out and makes it much more approachable then you might suspect.

Inspired by the Indian tradition of having tea and cookies after a long workday, the Tea & Biscuit Flip was created at Saffron in New Orleans. The Cognac and Chai work beautifully together and are enhanced by the lemon Juice, Orgeat, Cardamom Syrup and whole Egg.
“When a bartender friend, Ivan, had said he had an idea to help her improve her cocktail game, Vanessa had not imagined meeting in a tea emporium. But the longer she stayed and the more flavours she experienced, the more she realised that her pride in making a simple syrup from Chai was, by comparison, relatively small fry.”

If you are after a Moscow Mule riff that definitely has some kick, then you need to be making a Spicy Mule. It has the Vodka, Lime Juice and Ginger Beer of the original, but adds Cointreau and some slices of Jalapeño Pepper.

Refreshing and pink, the Honey Deuce is a Vodka-based cocktail that has been the official cocktail of the US Open since 2006. Named for the tie score of 40-40, known in tennis as ‘deuce’, this drink blends the flavours of lemonade, raspberry liqueur and honeydew.

You’ve got to love a cocktail that mixes east and west and then throws in a little James Bond for good measure. The Reverse Vesper & Tonic is a riff on James Bond’s classic Vesper but reverses it with less Gin & Vodka, the addition of Lillet Blanc and a little Becherovka to help it along.

Derived from Jim Meehan’s 2011 The PDT Cocktail Book, the South Slope was created by Michael Madrusan and is named after the South Slope area of Brooklyn. With Gin, Aperol, Lillet Blanc, Orange Curaçao & Lemon Juice this is a very tasty aperitif.

With a nod to the old luxury and style of the 1930s flights from Florida to Havana, the Pan Am Cocktail is a 2015 Bacardi Legacy winner. With White Rum, Aperol, Orgeat, Lemon Juice & Egg White, this is one drink that will transport you on an elegant escape.

Created by legendary bartender Dale DeGroff in New York City, the Velvet Fog Cocktail is hard to pass up. The Vodka, Falernum, Bitters and the juice of Limes and Oranges, create a tangy, fresh and bittersweet drink.

When Craig ‘Colonel Tiki’ Herman created this drink in 2010, it was served straight up in a coupe; David Selle later adapted it into this format. But either way, the Bourbon-laced, zesty Lemon Poison Dart has herbal complexity and cinnamon spice balanced with rich Orgeat.

With Japanese Whiskey, Blanc Vermouth and bitters, the Drifter may feel similar to a few other stirred cocktails out there, but what will keep you coming back is the bittersweet complexity with delicate notes of apricot and saffron from the Amaro Nonino.

The perfect after-dinner drink, the Brainstorm utilises the herbal pungency of Bénédictine to highlight the smoky smoothness of the whiskey, while the dryness of the vermouth balances the sweetness of the Bénédictine, and the orange peel adds a hint of brightness.
Chocolate-y and boozy, the Bourbon Ball is a drink that will dance delightfully around your taste buds with a tantalizing combination of Bourbon, Creme de Cocoa, Hazelnut Liqueur and Cream.

“Lustre is a diligent stand in for gin in this White Negroni riff, which substitutes gentian—based Suze for Campari and orange-accented Lillet Blanc for Sweet Vermouth.” – Jim Meehan
Image – AJ Meeker

A popular drink in New Orleans on a Sunday as it is reputed to have miraculous hang-over cure properties, the Brandy Milk Punch is an easy three-ingredient drink … just make sure you do not dry shake, as that will lead to eggnog.
“With the sun rising and the band on a well deserved break, Vanessa nipped behind the bar to shake up a New Orleans classic. Feeling a little like a Saint Bernard, as she ministered Brandy for the needy, she understood the importance of a little ‘hair of the dog’ for those poor souls stranded after closing.

Back when Jim Meehan still had his Chicago bar Prairie School, they created a cocktail called the Canadian Sour, which (as you might assume from the name) takes a Canadian approach to a Whiskey Sour with Rye Whiskey and Maple Syrup.
“As their camping trip had taken them only a few hours from the Canadian boarder, Juan decided to ‘Canadian things up, eh’ with a Whiskey Sour that not only incorporated Maple Syrup but was built on the backbone of Canadian Rye Whiskey. Somehow Vanessa knew this was only going to lead to an afternoon of ‘Oh Canada’ jokes.”

Created by J.P. Fetherston and Alex Levy at the Columbia Room in Washington, D.C, the Cosmogroni is a Cosmo / Negroni mashup that retains the orange and Cranberry aspects on the Cosmopolitan but adds Aperol
“Years before Vanessa had dated a law student who had a strong belief that if you want to see how depraved people could be, you needed to study criminal law, but as she looked around at all the silly season micro-dramas that were unfolding before her, she realised that actually all you need to do was work in a bar.”

Not since The Clash has there been a better reason to keep an ear out for London Calling. And with Gin, Sloe Gin, Sweet vermouth and Orange Bitters this is a traditionally styled sweet Martini with a dry, fruity finish.

No matter what the season, there are some nights when you need the bittersweet of Averna combined with the bracing spice of Rye and the warmth of Allspice (Pimento) Dram. On those occasions, the Winter Waltz offers a whiskey-based spice bomb, of modern classic proportions.

If you are after a bit of a boozy, but still delightfully fruity drink, then a Cassini might just be the ticket. With Vodka, Gin, Dry Cassis & Cranberry Juice, this drink is not overly sweet but still delightfully berry-licious.

If you are after a Whiskey Sour riff that is perfectly sweet but also nicely smokey, then a Rye-Blackberry Cocktail might be the cure. With Rye Whiskey,  Blackberry Preserve and Bruto Americano, this is the ideal late summer sipper.
“Since Juan, Vanessa’s faithful PA, had abandoned her to go out on a bird-watching hike with the quiet, although slightly sinister looking local ranger, Vanessa found herself having to make her evening cocktail herself. While normally she would have waited for Juan’s return before consuming her creation, the mere effort of crushing all that ice, had lead her to conclusion that sometimes cocktail-ing is hard work.”

Created by the late Sasha Petraske at Milk & Honey, The Business is a riff on the classic Bees Knees cocktail. Staying within the realm of the original, this drink is made a little snappier by the inclusion of Lime Juice instead of Lemon Juice.

The perfect Whiskey-based dessert drink, the Liquid Bourbon Ball is drier, smoother and more indulgent than you’d think. With Bourbon, Crème de Cacao and a little Frangelico for good measure, this drink is not your typical chocolate cocktail.

Nothing adds a more Christmas feel than adding some Christmas spices, and this is the trick that the Christmas Cosmo uses to give a bit of seasonal flavour to this Cosmo riff.
“As the temperature dropped, a little snow fell and everyone huddled into the bar. Mix that with the lights, the decorations and a little festive crooning and even Vanessa was ready to admit that it really was beginning to feel a lot like Christmas”

Sweet Vermouth and Port dominate this deep cherry red Negroni-like aperitivo, with Campri providing balancing bitterness. Four Poster Red was created by Simon Difford in 2018 at the Cabinet Room in London
Dry Curacao becomes the star of this martini-style highball with Gin, Dry vermouth, Orange Bitters and Soda Water created by Greg Best at the Ticonderoga Club in Atlanta, GA

Champagne replaces Dry White Wine in this ‘royal’ rendition of Mayor Canon Kir’s classic Aperitif. With Brut Champagne and Cassis this is one special drink that is not only easy to make but also oh so easy to drink.

Believed to have originated at the Noriega Hotel in Bakersfield, California, the Picon Punch has become somewhat of a signature drink of the Basque communities in the US. With Amer Picon, Grenadine, Soda & Cognac VSOP for a distinctly French aperitif.

The Casper combines Reposado Tequila and Lime Juice with Orgeat. A riff on a Margarita, this drink is finished with rose water to complement the floral tequila, and nutmeg, to give an added layer of complexity and spice.

Created in 2008 by Paul Mathew at The Hide in London, the Beginning Of The End is a riff on the classic Fin de Siècle except the gin is replaced with rum to create a balanced but complex bittersweet drink.

Light, dry and crisp, the Flame Of Love is an iconic drink with a dash of theatre that is part elegance, part grace. Originally created by Dean Martin at Chasen’s in Beverley Hills, this legendary drink has a Hollywood feel and showcases how well sherry pairs with wheat vodka.

Created by Shawn Chen from RedFarm in NYC, the I Think She Got It utilises Ginger Liqueur, Fresh Ginger & Blackberries to show what Baijiu can really do. Added to these is Lime Juice, Sugar Syrup & Basil Leaves for a long drink that’s packed with flavour.

Complex and herbal, the Monte & Mezcal is a riff on the Negroni that is as vibrant in flavour as it is in colour. With Montenegro Amaro, Select Aperitivo and Mezcal, this drink is the perfect stir-down pre-dinner or even at the end of the night.

The Tia Mia is not only a riff but also an anagram of that famous tropical drink, the Mai Tai. With smokey Mezcal instead of White Rum, this twist on the original is like a Mexican spritz with a taste of the Caribbean.

If you are looking for a variation from Gin in your Negroni then you can’t go past the smooth, delicate flavour with subtle fruit undertones of Rakia. Made with the same proportions as the original, a Rakia Negroni has an absolutely amazing taste.
Sweet and flavoursome, the Lanique Rose Petal Martini was first created by the legendary bartender Dick Bradsell, who mixed Lanique Liqueur with Old Tom Gin, Lychee Juice and Peychard’s Bitters.
Limoncello is definitely an underused liqueur in cocktails but make a Limoncello Collins, with Limoncello, gin and a nice topping of Soda Water and you’ll always have an easy crowd pleaser.

Created in 2008 by Lewis Jaffrey, the Drambuie Global Ambassador, the Ancient Daiquiri is a lovely Daiquiri twist is heavily influenced by its herbal liqueurs. According to Lewis, the combination of Rum, Drambuie, Green Chartreuse, Lime Juice and Vanilla Syrup has a combined age over 650 years.

Created by bartender Joaquín Simó at former East Village bar Pouring Ribbons, the refreshing High King Highball is a bright fruity highball that is not only visually appealing but also a delicious drink that easily converts anyone who believes that Irish Whiskey shouldn’t be in a cocktail

Created by Eric Tecosky from the Olive Juice company Dirty Sue, the Dirty Laundry shows that brine can be used for more than just a Dirty Martini. A fun mix of Vodka, Grapefruit, Agave and lemon, cucumber and bell peppers, this cocktail is vegetal with a bit of bite.

“A lightly-roasted coffee with fruity florals —reminiscent of the berry the bean descends from—is the perfect pairing for Earthen in this alcohol free “copy” of the classic Irish Coffee.” – Jim Meehan

Named after the press slogan which allegedly provoked the 1898 Spanish-American War, the cocktail Remember The Maine is a twist on a Sazerac. This Rye cocktail is given a subtle sweetness with Cherry Liqueur and a hint of savagery from a dash of good Absinthe.
Definitely a crowd-pleaser, the Old Town Vodka Punch embraces all the best elements of a summer cocktail, from the sweetness of elderflower liqueur to the hints of bittersweet orange from Aperol.

While it might initially look friendly and harmless, the Dalmatian packs an unexpected punch – a little bitter but still sweet, earthy and deep, with a little heat from the vodka and pepper combination … perfect to end the week. Created by Helen Rosner at saveur.com

The Party Cat Mezcal Cocktail is all about presenting fresh flavour with tangy grapefruit juice and sparkling wine. If you don’t have Cardamon Bitters on hand, then make your own by steeping 1 Tbsp. of crushed cardamom in 8 oz. of high-proof neutral spirit for 10 days, strain and bottle.

Greg Kong, beverage director for Kimika New York describes the bar’s Watermelon Cooler as a watermelon daiquiri at heart. With Ten To One White Rum, Trois Rivieres Cuvee L’Ocean, salted Watermelon Syrup, Aperol and a hint of chilli, the drink is rounded off with a little Lambrusco Rosso sparkle.

Lychees make the perfect ingredient for a cocktail that is equally enjoyable with no-alcohol as it is with a little booze. The combination of Grapefruit Juice, Lime Juice, Honey Syrup, Lychees & Soda Water (Gin optional) has enough depth to be a truly tasty combo.

Who among us doesn’t love a good pun but with For Sake’s Sake you not only get a good pun but also a good cocktail. With Sake (as the name suggests), White Rum, Italicus and Cointreau, this is a subtly orange sake and rum cocktail.

A nice riff on David Wondrich’s Airmail cocktail, You’ve Got Mail mixes Cachaça with Citrus (Lime Juice & Orange Juice), which is balanced with Honey Syrup and then nicely and effervescently topped with Champagne.

As you might assume from the name, this is yet another Negroni riff. If like us, you believe there can never be enough Negroni riffs, but would perhaps like yours a little lighter and sweeter, then this cross-continental drink with Tequila, Sweet Vermouth & Aperol won’t disappoint.

If you are after a slightly drier riff on an Aviation then throw out the Creme de Violette and make a Casino #1. With the usual Gin, Maraschino Liqueur and Lemon Juice, it is made drier and more complex with a dash of Orange Bitters.

If you haven’t indulged in a little White Whiskey (Moonshine, Hooch, Firewater, White Lightning etc), then a Strawberry Moonshine is the perfect place to start. With White Whiskey, Strawberry Jam, Lemon Juice & Soda Water, this drink is a good slow sipper on the porch.

Whether you drink this as a citrusy Whisky aperitif or as a refreshing Scotch and Port wine nightcap, the Rosemary Tuck is definitely a winner. With Scotch, Tawny Port, Orange Juice, Sugar Syrup and Orange Bitters, this is a wonderfully warming balanced drink.

If you are after a tropical cocktail with just about everything, then you can go past Jamaican Me Crazy. White Rum and Coconut Rum are the basis for this fruity concoction that includes the juice of Passionfruits, Cranberries, Oranges and Lime, as well as a little Grenadine for extra colour.

This classic, bitter drink makes quite a few appearances in a number of the work of Bret Easton Ellis. In his memoir, White, he mentions the combo of Vodka & Grapefruit juice saying “I found her stillness intimidating, so as a hungover, shaggy twenty-one-year-old I ordered a midday vodka and grapefruit juice to settle my nerves”.

If you’re after a spicy, smoky and sweet drink, then you can’t go past a Cave Creek Cocktail. With Rye, Scotch, Lemon Juice, Grenadine & Campari, this is the ideal whisk(e)y sipper for the end of a long humid day.

At the end of the night, nothing beats a tasty, bittersweet Aperitivo like Little Italy. A Manhattan-like mix of Rye, Cynar and Sweet Vermouth, this drink was created by Audrey Saunders at Pegu Club in New York.

Named after the third installment of the Fast & Furious movie franchise, the Tokyo Drift is a delicate but boozy Japanese Whisky riff on the classic Manhattan, but unlike the film this drink is balenced and complex.

Created in 2019 by Simon Difford at Clocktower in Sussex, the Grapefruit Crusta is a refreshing, zesty cocktail.  With Grapefruit Vodka, Pamplemousse Rosé Liqueur, Ruby Grapefruit Juice, Simple Syrup & Grapefruit Bitters this is easy-drinking at its best.
Not to be confused with a Tommy’s Margarita, the Tommi’s Cocktail is a delicate yet bittersweet aperitif. With Mezcal as the star, the drink backs this up with Aperol and Maraschino Liqueur.

If you are after a cocktail the embodies a chocolaty, nutty, coffee flavour, then the Montgomery Slugger. should be your go-to. Created in 2013 at Maison Premiere in Williamsburg New York, this drink combines Bourbon, Vermouth, Coffee Liqueur, Falernum, Walnut Liqueur and Angostura Bitters in an Absinthe-rinsed glass.

If you believe, as we do, that nothing beats a slightly spicy fizz cocktail, then In My Peel needs to be on your list of drinks to make. Created by Kelsey Ramage of Trash Collective, this drink features carrot peel-infused Vodka, spiced syrup, Amaro Lucano, Greek yogurt and Soda Water

We’re all for Negroni riffs and the Paper Tiger is a particular favourite. If you’ve been thinking that the only thing lacking from a Negroni is more spice, then this cocktail amps it up with the use of dark spiced Rum and Carpano.

You know you are doing adulting right when you find yourself sitting outside on a barmy summer evening with a drink like a Gin Spritz in your hand. Floral and citrusy, sparkly and crisp, this drink is the perfect after-work libation.

A riff on the Whiskey Sour, the Old Elk Apple Sour provides a nice fruity twist without the foam. The Apple Brandy ensures the drink is not overly tart but has enough apple flavour to mix well with the Bourbon and Lemon Juice

Slightly sweet, lemony fresh and perfectly boozy, Give A Fig is a great drink for an impromptu get together. With Bourbon, Fig Liqueur, Honey Simple Syrup & Lemon Juice, this is one drink you’re going to care about.
Created by Ryan ‘Mr Lyan’ Chetiyawardana at Dandelyan London, the Three Storms Flip is a complex but silky smooth riff on a rum flip that has subtle hints of Peaty Scotch

Although the Tuxedo No.3 only uses a small amount of Sherry, it does change the overall impact of the drink. The original was first recorded in Harry Johnson’s 1900 Bartenders Manual and this is a later riff that changes the amount of Gin and Vermouth used, while also adding Sherry.
A riff on a Gin & Tonic, the Peach & Tonic understandably has Peach as the star of the show. As well as Peach Liqueur, the drink has shaved ice from a frozen peach zested over the top

Who doesn’t love the flavour of Cranberry Juice, Rose Syrup and Strawberry Syrup? Mix them all together and add enough Vodka to show you’re serious and a little lemon Juice to cut through the sweetness and you’ll be a sweetheart in the making.

Created by Rose’s Luxury in Washington, D.C., the Rose & Rye is a wonderful cocktail with which to start the night. Combining Rye, Rose Syrup, Lemon Juice & Bitters, this is a sprightly, pretty little cocktail, that is sure to delight.

The Yellow Jacket is an aromatic Tequila cocktail named for the wasps that swarm around agave farms and tequila distilleries. Herbal, musky, and bittersweet, this drink combines Reposado Tequila with St Germain and Yellow Chartreuse.

Like all entertainers, Sandy the Showgirl has an interesting combination of ingredients but strangely pulls it off to create a drink that has a delicious floral smokiness. With Tequilas, Mezcal, Maraschino Liqueur, Agave Syrup and Lavender Bitters.

If you are looking for a new go-to variation on a Negroni, 1800 Tequila’s Jalisco Negroni is the perfect Agave update on the classic. Using the Campari and Sweet Vermouth that you expect, the drink just swaps out the Gin for Silver Tequila … easy!

Perfectly balanced and easily sippable, the Mildred Pierce is a wonderful three ingredient cocktail. The smokiness of Mezcal, adds the necessary roughness to Aperol, Creme de Pamplemousse & Lemon Juice.

I was really impressed with Patrón’s emphasis on the community, which inspired me to create a cocktail that reflects this, through the use of local and easily accessible produce – Sion Roberts – Dead Ringer – Sydney

For a completely different take on a Mint Julep you can’t go past the chocolatey goodness of a Thin Mint Julep. Reminiscent of Mint Thin Cookies, this cocktail adds a little Peppermint Schnapps and Creme de Cacao to the traditional Bourbon & Mint.

The Hemingway Daiquiri was created at the La Floridita bar in Cuba for Ernest Hemingway. Legend has it that he loved it so much that he always ordered a double, lending the cocktail its nickname of Papa Doble.

While a Hot Toddy is a perfect winter drink, that doesn’t mean you can’t drink it in summer. Drinking hot drinks when it is hot can cool the body down, and adding Tequila will make your heart grateful.

Don’t get too worried by the name of the cocktail, as it is the perfect combination of dark spicy flavours. With Kraken Spiced Rum and Ginger Beer, there can be no better combination at the end of a long, hot summer day.

This simple, three-ingredient cocktail is the perfect summer sipper to have by the pool. The Pearl Harbour mixes Vodka, Midori and Pineapple Juice, this stunning green drink will have your friends Midori with envy.

ingredients: 4 dash Dr.Adam Elmegirab's The Dead Rabbit Orinoco Bitters
description: Created by celebrated bartender Pamela Wiznitzer, Head Of Steam is an Irish Whiskey stirred cocktail creates a wonderfully rich mix of Whiskey, Vermouth Sherry and Bitters
With a well-balanced floral flavour, the Rose Martini makes the ideal summer sipper. Delicate but definately refreshing, this Martini riff combines Vodka, Rose Water, Sugar Syrup and a little Lemon.

Although fruit cups are traditionally made with Pimms (which is really a Gin based, herbal aperitif), they can also be made simply with just Gin and Vermouth. The Melbourne Fruit Cup as a combinations of Gin, Vermouth, Ginger Ale & Lemonade for the perfect summer sipper.

When you get a drink with a split base of Rum & Scotch you might assume it’ll be a winter sipper. Yet when you add Dry Curacao & Coconut Water to the mix, as happens with the Scotch & Coconut Cocktail, it easily takes a turn towards the tropical.

Sometimes you just need the healing power of a simple three-ingredient cocktail like the Louisville Cocktail. With Bourbon, Lillet Rouge and Lillet Blanc, this drink is a spirit-forward, elegant, modern classic.

Philadelphia’s contributions to cocktail history, The Clover Club pre-dates Prohibition and is named for the Philadelphia men’s club of the same name. With Gin, Raspberry Syrup, Lemon Juice and Egg White, this is a rich, silky-textured drink with enough sweet and sour to keep everyone happy.

The Agave Margarita is, as it says on the box, a cocktail that contains Agave Syrup, instead of the traditional Cointreau. Super simple, it also uses Reposado Tequila instead of Blanco but otherwise, the Lime Juice remains the same.

Created by Brooklyn bartender Ivy Mix, the Palo Negro is a mix of black strap rum, reposado tequila and Grand Marnier, which all work in harmony with the Palo Cortado sherry for a nightcap cocktail that works in perfect harmony.
“They say that you can’t really know a city until you’ve spent a night drinking with its inhabitants. If this is true then Vanessa felt she knew New York very well. After all, there’s not much that can remain hidden when you have both Tequila and Rum in the mix.”

Pan de Muerto, one of the most popular Día de Muertos offerings, is characterized by the inclusion of orange zest and orange juice. Like its namesake, the Pan de Muertos cocktail also features a tangy citrus flavour with the inclusion of orange liqueur.

It might have a funny name but the GVC Cocktail definitely packs a punch. Named after it’s three ingredients – Ginger, Vodka & Cointreau, this drink is warming, tasty and the perfect drink to have with friends beside the fire.

Drunk Uncle may not be your favourite person but it should be your favourite cocktail. This spirituous cocktail has a savory, smoky flavour that mixes the peaty taste of Scotch and the vegetal yet bittersweet taste of Cynar, then balances them out with a little Bianco Vermouth.

Inspired by the mists of Victoria Falls, the Royal Mukombe is a nutty drink with warm winter spices and stewed fruits. Created by Antony Mudzengerere for Gigi’s Rooftop, the Mukombe describes the gourd in which the cocktail of Cognac and Butternut brown spices is served.

Another refreshment typically served at a Día de Muertos celebration is fresh fruit water. With the Paloma Roja that idea is kicked up a notch by featuring Silver Tequila among grapefruit and lemon juices, and then St Germain,with a little Hibiscus Syrup

Believed to have been created at New York City’s Manhattan Club, sometime around 1880, the Manhattan is a cocktail that is both timeless and tasty. Mixing American Rye Whiskey, Italian Sweet Vermouth and perked up with the inclusion of Angostura Bitters, it is the very definition of what a cocktail should be.

While you might think the Gimlet is a pretty perfect cocktail that doesn’t mean that it can’t be improved upon. And that’s exactly what Andrea Gualdi has done for Alibi, Sydney. By featuring Citadelle Gin, Chartreuse, Vermouth and a Basil Oil garnish, this drink has an unbeatable aroma and a silky mouth feel.

If you are after a fruity classic, then you can’t go past the dry tartiness of a Sloe Gin Fizz. With Sloe Gin, Lemon Juice and Sugar Syrup, then top with Champagne, if you want to be fancy or Soda Water if you don’t.

Made truly popular by the 1998 Coen Brothers film, The Big Lebowski, The White Russian is a simple, smooth mix of vodka, coffee liqueur and cream. So yes, it’s basically a Black Russian with Cream but nonetheless, a great sipping drink.

Inspired by the classic New Orleans Brandy Crusta, which is in itself a Cognac-based twist on the Old Fashioned, the Sidecar is a drink that will certainly take you for a ride. But understand, with Cognac, Cointreau and Lemon Juice, this really is just a gussied up Cognac sour.

Considered by many to be the best version of a Corpse Reviver, the Corpse Reviver 2 is a well balance libation, with zesty lemon and Absinthe shinning above all. Added to that, the Gin, Cointreau and Lillet Blanc, make this a concoction that definitely would revive a corpse

The result of a collaboration between Cause & Effect Cocktail Kitchen in Cape Town and Red Bull, the Rock To Fakie is as extreme a sport of cocktails gets.  It’s easy to skate into this cocktail with it’s mix of Bacardi Spiced, Rum, Ginger Syrup, Lichee & Mint Sorbet, Spiced Apple Sorbet and a float of Watermelon Redbull.

A cocktail that you can’t help but love, the Black-Eyed Rye is a take on a Black-Eyed Susan, the official drink of Maryland’s biggest sporting event—the Preakness Stakes. With Rye, Ginger Beer, Lime Juice & Blackberry Simple Syrup, this has been inspired by fast horses but should be drunk slow.

The Amora Amaro could easily be described as a love song in a glass. The combination of Amaro di Angostura, Angostura Bitters, Lime Juice & Sugar Syrup, is a perfect balance of bitter, sweet and sour notes and an ode to one’s “Love of Bitter”.

Created by Sam Ross at Attaboy, the Midnight Stringer is the perfect digestivo cocktail. With Bourbon, Fernet Branca, Lemon Juice and Sugar Syrup, this  drink is perfect for settling the stomach after a big meal.

Created at Dante NYC, the Mediterranean Tonic puts a Spanish coastline twist on the typical G&T.  The drink incorporates the flavours of the region with Manzanilla Sherry, Lemon and Olive, as well as a dash of saline for a subtle brininess

Created by Dylan Shuey + Cedric Vongerichten at Wayan NYC, the Ube Ume is a riff on a Rum Sour. As well as the Rum, Lemon Juice, Simple Syrup and Aquafaba that you would expect, this drink also has Sake and the beautiful colour of Ume Plum Liqueur & Ube extract.

The Gravity Sidecar, created by Matthew Cox, is inspired by the story of Sir Isaac Newtown and incorporates apple in three ways – within the ice, the sour component and the garnish. Showcasing the beauty of the Cognac, the malic acid-adjusted Sauvignon Blanc is balanced by the Cointreau and Elderflower Cordial to create a versatile and complex drink.

A bittersweet riff on a reverse Manhattan, the Full Monte No. 2 is adapted from a recipe created by Janelle Engelson at Gertie’s Bar in Nashville. With Montenegro Amaro replacing Vermouth, this nightcap-style cocktail also has Bourbon and Angostura Bitters.

Created by Kenaniah Bystrom at Essex in Seattle, the Smoke Signal Cocktail is a beautiful mix of flavours that encapsulates the forest through the Douglas Fir Liqueur, citrus through the juices and smoke through the tea syrup, all interacting through a base of Bourbon.

The Cape Town bar, Bar By Rhys, has adapted the classic Clover Club with a few tweaks to create their Delight Club cocktail. With the use of Cape Town Gin’s Pink Lady Gin, in-house Raspberry Cordial, Sour Mix (an in-house mix of lemon & Lime Juice), Aquafaba and Mole Bitters, this is as delightful as the name implies.

If you are keen on coffee cocktails, then Coffee With Gianni will definitely hit the spot. The thing that makes grapefruit taste sour is also the thing that helps to stretch your caffeine high, so if you’re a little tired, it’s time to mix up some Grapefruit Vodka, Cold Brew Coffee and a little Simple Syrup.

Toby Maloney at The Violet Hour in Chicago wanted to pay an homage to the Last Word, but by adding the egg white and the absinthe, as well as making the Chartreuse flaming, the effect is one of Neptune’s fury in a stormy sea.
Created by Roison Garcia and his team at Ocean Prime restaurant in New York, the Prime Margarita is a bright and balanced Margarita riff that is nothing short of a flavourful fiesta!

The Black Ships were the name given to the naval vessels commanded by Commodore Matthew Perry, whose arrival, in 1853, forced an end to Japanese isolation. It is also the name of our Japanese Whisky Cocktail that also includes Pomegranate Juice, Port & a little Lemon Juice.

The perfect after-dinner digestif, the Port Of Spain has a sizable amount of Angostura Bitters. It is, therefore, no surprise that this drink has been named after the capital of Trinidad, which is, of course, also the home of the brand.

The Saigon Cooler is the perfect cocktail if you are after a fruity and well-balanced drink. Incorporating Raspberries, Gin, Chambord, Cranberry Juice and a little Lime Juice, this is a drink that is all about refreshment.

Well, it’s about time that we presented a medicinal solution. And at least with this drink every ingredient (except the sugar) has been used medicinally at some time (and if Mary Poppins is to be believed, it’s sugar that makes the medicine go down). So grab Genever, Green Chartreuse, Lime Juice, Sugar Syrup, Angostura Bitters & top with Tonic Water for a cocktail that is definitely A1.

If you’re looking for a drink to get the party started, then why not give your guests a Strawberry Zing? Mixing Strawberry & Lime Flävar, Vodka, Watermelon Liqueur, Lime Juice and a little Simple Syrup this refreshing aperitif is the perfect drink for the festive season.

Originally created by Sean Cadger at The Outhouse in Edinburgh, the Bakewell Tart Sour has all the jammy, almond-y tastes you would expect with a mix of Cognac, Amaretto, the syrup from Maraschino Cherries, Bitters and Lemon Juice.

Adapted from a recipe created by Matthias Lataille in 2016 in London, the Carré Nouveau is reminiscent of a Vieux Carré but with Lillet Blanc replacing the Sweet Vermouth and Gentian replacing the Angostura Bitters

The Red Hook cocktail is a modern classic that comes to us from bartender Enzo Errico, formerly of NYC’s Milk & Honey. With Rye, Punt e Mes & Maraschino Liqueur, this drink is, of course, another Manhattan riff with a Brooklyn theme.

If you are a Coconut fan, then there’s no better way to express your love than with a Coconut Margarita. Both the Coconut Milk and the Coconut Water add a true tropical nature to this summer libation.

Crisp, bright and summery, the Mid-Summer Cocktail truly lives up to its name. With Vodka as the base, the Fino Sherry adds a little nuttiness, while the Yellow Chartreuse add sweet, mellow, herbal notes

Created for Perle Skirvin Mesta, the US ambassador to Luxembourg, the Black Russian was devised by bartender Gustave Tops at the Metropolitan Hotel in Brussels in 1949. A simple mix of Vodka and Coffee Liqueur, this classic is deep and rich, while also being the older brother of the White Russian.

As the name suggests, the Lunes Aperitivo should perhaps have been the first Aperitivo of our week. Either way, the Tequila, Americano Bianco and the Suze combine to create a drink that sits nicely on the dry side of bittersweet.

ingredients: 101ml Rocket Fuel (Orange + Grenadilla Juice + Citric Acid)
description: Citrusy and bright, The Rocket cocktail is a rum-based highball that truly shines. With both white and spiced Rum and an orchestra of Citrus & Grenadilla Juice (Passionfruit), this is a drink that will send your taste buds into the stratosphere.
Created by Sylvian Solignac at Citrus, London, the Eden is a wonderful long Tonic cocktail made for summer days. With Vodka, St Germain, Apple Juice and topped with Tonic Water.

If you are looking for an unconventional, modern tiki drink, then Brother Hal might be the drink for you. The Rum is, of course, the star, but the Mezcal mixes seamlessly with the Orange and Lime Juices, while the Falernum and the Green Chartreuse bring added complexity.

Inspired by a Pina Colada, the flavours of Jalapina are all about the Blanco Tequila. The drink adds a bit of spice to compliment the creamy notes and the toasted coconut playing against the caramel and banana of the agave spirit.

Created by French bartender Nico de Soto, the Pandan-quiri offers a Southeast Asian twist on the classic Daiquiri. The cocktail offers the grassy, slightly bitter taste of Pandan Syrup to sweeten the drink before adding the usual Rum and Lime Juice.

The name Blushing Monk, of course, refers to the inclusion of Benedictine in this aromatic bittersweet sour. Added to that is Aperol, Lillet for a little brightness, Suze to offset the sweetness, and Lime Juice to add a bit of zing.

Strong yet well-balanced and herbaceous, Quill is a riff on a Negroni that is definitely not one to be left in the wings. With the usual suspects of Gin, Campari and Sweet Vermouth, this drink adds a rinse of Absinthe for an Anise and Woodworm undertone.
“With Negroni Week in full swing, Vanessa knew she had to get back to the city. Although Juan (her faithful PA) seemed to have gone to the birds under the careful tutorage of the forest ranger they had befriended, Vanessa knew that if she didn’t get a Campari in her hand quick-smart, even the sight of her in a negligee could not negate her neglect of the Negroni.”

As the name suggests, the Mexican Mule is simply a Moscow Mule variation that uses a nice Reposito Tequila as the base spirit instead of Vodka. So add the Tequila to Lime Juice, Sugar Syrup and Ginger Beer. It really isn’t more complicated than that but it is super tasty.

A twist on the classic Vieux Carré,  the Vieille Place is a balanced, yet spirit-forward, bittersweet aperitif. Created by Robbie Neskens at Bruut in Hassselt , Belgium, this drink incorporates Bourbon, Suze, Cognac, Dry Vermouth, Simple Syrup, a dash of Amaretto, aswell as both a dash of Peychard & Angostura Bitters.

Created at Atlas Singapore and inspired by the Place Vendôme outside of the Ritz in Paris, the Vendome Spritz incorporates citrus flavours and some sweetness for a drink that is crisp, bright and easy to sip

If you’re looking to add a bit more complexity to your next Old Fashioned, then don’t look any further than the Elderfashioned. The addition of St Germain not only compliments the whisky notes but also adds a certain ‘je ne sais quoi’ to the mix.

With Dark Rum, Creme de Cacao, Sweet Vermouth, Lime Juice & Cinnamon Syrup, the Julie Paradise has been created by the New York bar Nobody Told Me. And while nobody has told us who Julie is, but we can certainly tell you that this is one drink that will definitely take you to paradise.

If you’re looking for a sophisticated after-dinner cocktail, then the French Connection is just as thrilling as its name-sake. With Cognac and Amaretti Liqueur, this is a drink you sip and savour slowly.

If you assumed this drink was named after the first pub of the ‘crawl’ from the 2013 film World’s End, then you’d be right. At that time, bartender Alastair Walker was at The Everleigh in Melbourne, where he mixed Gin, Suze, Lime Juice, Sugar Syrup, a dash of Absinthe and it’s all topped with Soda Water to create the First Post.

Light, refreshing and easily drinkable, the Miami Spritz is the perfect cocktail to have by the pool. With Vodka, Watermelon, Campari, Lemon Juice and Simple Syrup, this is a drink has an effervescent lightness with a topping of Soda Water

Originally created by John E. Haas, a bartender from Pennsylvania at the turn of the century, The Modern Cocktail was promoted by Charles, S. Mahoney in his 1905 book, The Hoffman House Bartender’s Guide (1905). With equal amounts of Blended Scotch and Sloe Gin, it also has Lemon Juice, Sugar Syrup and a dash each of Absinthe and Orange Bitters.

Created by Garrett Flanagan for New York’s Pebble Bar, Night Train is the perfect after-dinner drink. A Manhattan-Boulevardier hybrid, this drink combines two Amari that adds an extra layer of bitterness.
Recipe and cocktail image from @imbibe

Pétanque may be a French game (similar to Boules) but the Amaretto in this drink is Italian and the Fino Sherry is Spanish. Go figure … To add a little more geographical confusion, the drink was created by an American, Andrew Bohrer from Mistral Kitchen in Seattle.

Dry & aromatic, the French Canadian is a wonderful aperitif created by Dan Corum Fisher at Hawksmoor, London. With Cognac, Gin, Maple Syrup, Lemon Juice and Angostura Bitters, with muddled cucumber adding freshness.

It’s typical that the week would end with one lousy goat … The Negroni & The Goat is a riff that comes from The Girl And The Goat Restaurant in Chicago back in 2014. It combines Gin, Aperol, Sweet Vermouth and Averna for a drink that’s far from gamey.

If you ever thought that your Martini needed a little something extra, then the Obituary Cocktail is where you might find it. With the usual Gin and Dry Vermouth, this cocktail also adds a splash of Absinthe to the mix.

The sweet notes of Bourbon are lifted and amplified by the almond flavours of Amaretto in this Old Fashioned riff. In addition to the Bourbon and Amaretto, the Almond Old Fashioned has Demerara Syrup and Angostura Bitters.
If flavour is truly your jam, then you’ll love the taste of a Fig & Rye. With Autumnal tones, this Cocktail has Rye, Fig Jam, Lemon Juice & a little Sugar Syrup to warm you from the inside out.

If you are looking for a late summer cocktail that reflects the colours as the seasons change , then Autumn In The Tropics is a good place to start. With Aperol, Rum, fruit juice and bitters, this is a tropical drink that crosses the seasons.

Designed to perfectly pair with cheese, the Pavoni cocktail was a winner in the finals of the Heering Cocktail Classics competition in 2018. Created by bartender Odd Strandbakken at Himkok in Oslo, Norway, the drink combines Cherry Heering with Fino Sherry, Maraschino Liqueur, Angostura di Amaro and Orange Bitters.

Easy to make and even easier to drink, the Stone Fruit Sangria uses a selection of versatile stone fruits, such as peaches, nectarines, plums, and cherries, soaked in white wine, with the addition of Peach Liqueur to make this sweet yet refreshing Sangria.

ingredients: 3 barspoon Honey Syrup (3 honey to 1 water)
description: It may not have the healing properties of an antibiotic but the Penicillin Cocktail, with its soothing yet spicy flavors of Scotch, Honey, Lemon Juice and Ginger Liqueur, is a surefire cure for a chilly autumn night.

Served at GG Tokyo New York, The Tomodachi is a beautiful riff on a Margarita. As well as the usual Lime Juice, Agave Syrup and Tequila (in this case pea-flower infused), the drink also has the tart and subtle sweet Ume Plum Liqueur

If a wine-like cocktail with strong hints of bitter orange is what your taste buds are crying out for, then the Sanctuary cocktail could be your sanctum. With Dubonnet, Amer Picon and Cointreau this is a. classic well worth the name.

When the weather is sweltering, would you reach for a beer, some juice, or Tequila? What if you could have all three. The Gingo combines tequila, St Germain, Grapefruit Juice & Pale Ale into a cocktail that will cool you down in no time.
An early champion of Mezcal, Phil Ward created a few modern classics with the spirit, among them, Division Bell. A riff on the Last Word, Ward swapped Mezcal for Gin and Aperol for Chartreuse.

The Gibson uses a pickled cocktail onion in place of the typical briny olive to add an umami undertone to the classic cocktail. With Gin, Dry Vermouth, and a Cocktail Onions as garnish, this is often thought to be the connoisseur’s Martini of choice.

If you are looking for a cocktail that is not only elegant but unmistakably timeless than a Dry Martini is the most obvious port-of-call. With Gin, Dry Vermouth (we like a six-to-one ratio) & Orange Bitters, this is one potation that always brings an air of sophistication.
One of the modern classics to emerge from Milk & Honey, the Star Daisy, is a bright citrus-based drink that mixes of Gin, Apple Brandy, Dry Curacao, Lemon Juice and Simple Syrup
A floral twist on the bitter classic, the Lanique Rose Negroni exchanges Vermouth for Lanique which gives this drink a delicate rosy finish while still packing a high-spirited punch

There is nothing more classic than a dry Martini and the Belvedere Martini fits that bill with vodka and just a hint of Vermouth. The trick is to ensure that there is enough ice in your stir and your martini glass is chilled.

Have you ever thought that the one thing the classic Paloma cocktail is missing is a delicate bitter complexity? Well, thankfully the Monte Paloma with it’s Montenegro, Tequila, Grapefruit Juice and Lime Juice is here to solve that little problem.

For a fun, easy, tropical drink that looks as good as it tastes, you can’t go past a Midori Splice. With Midori, Coconut Rum, Pineapple Juice and a head of Coconut Cream, this is one drink that combines the best flavours of summer.

Fernet Branca is almost a national drink in Argentina, so it’s not surprising that this bitter, spicy drink is named after the country’s best known first lady. With Fernet Branca, Sweet Vermouth, Ginger Liqueur, Lime Juice and Ginger Beer, the Eva Peron is definitely an attention-getter.

There’s an old story about J Edgar Hoover (no, not that one) that recounts that the former-FBI Director spent so much time at the Stork Club in NY that they actually named a cocktail after him. That cocktail is the FBI Fizz, with Cherry Heering, Jamaican Rum, Bourbon & Soda Water. And yes, we think you’ll find it quite arresting.

Like many hot coffee drinks, the Italian Coffee is defined by a single liqueur, in this case, Strega. When Strega is mixed with Coffee and whipped Cream, it creates a drink that makes an excellent after dinner indulgence.
Best described as being a little like a Ramos but without the cream, the Fabulous Fizz is bright and refreshing with Grapefruit Gin and Triple Sec but just a touch bitter with the addition of Campari

For a light and fizzy cocktail that’s slightly sweet, a little tangy, and totally delicious, you can’t go past Autumn In Paris. The Ginger Wine gives a little spice, while St Germain makes it truly refreshing and perfect for any time of year.

Let’s be honest, no matter how cool the name is, this cocktail is just a Greyhound with a salt rim. Again, historically a Gin drink, where the salt was used to dial down the tart and bitter notes of the Grapefruit. For this Salty Dog recipe, we’ve used the more popular Vodka, but you can sub in Gin if you’d like.

Although it may have a distinctly Gothic feel, the Gargoyle and Spire Cocktail has a wonderfully bitter but refreshing taste. Strega (Italian for the Witch) joins Gin, Orange Bitters and Champagne in what would have to be the perfect sipping drink to watch the creatures of the night.
Simple, yet classic in nature, the Cathy Olé is a gin-based cocktail where the richness of the Vanilla Liqueur of Licor 43 is beautifully balanced by the bone-dry sherry and the Lime Juice.

If you want to elevate and balance the flavours in a Tequila Negroni riff, then just add saline. With the San Diago bartender, Eric Gigers’ has created the Jalisco Stroll that uses the usual Blanco Tequila, Dry Vermouth & Campari mix in equal measure but added a few drops of concentrated saline to change the game completely.

The Strawberry Scotch Cocktail is a refreshing complex and delicious summer sipping drink. Light fruity strawberries mingle with peaty Scotch and tart lemon juice in a beverage that will just leave you happy.

Flavour forward Anejo Tequila is not the only star in The Allstar Cocktail. Accompanying it, it Allspice Dram, Italian Amaro and a dash of Chocolate Bitters for a drink that has not only spice but a good bit of depth.

Created in 1950 by Giovanni Raimondo at the Excelsior Hotel in Rome, this Negroni riff is a drier and more complex cocktail that swaps Campari for the slightly spicy Contratto Bitter and sweet vermouth for dry.

Believed to have been created in the 1970s, the Tootsie Roll cocktail is a drink that’s sweet, rich, and chocolatey, with a hint of citrus and is, as you might assume from the name, inspired by the famous US candy.

Created by Simon Difford in 2008 at The Cabinet Room in London, Damn It Jimmy is a cocktail that is delicate yet very slightly sweet. The Sake, White Rum mixes with the faint salty taste of Fino Sherry and herbal Dry Vermouth complexity.

Named after a house in Haut Bay, South Africa, which is haunted by the ghost of Elsa Cloete, who died of a broken heart. The liquid honours the lovers with a mix of Gin, Elderflower, Cucumber, Lemon & Hibiscus Juice, and Soda Water while being garnished with a stir of edible blue shimmer

As you might imagine this is a very fruity Margarita riff featuring watermelon. So throw a little Reposado Tequila in a shaker and add Lime Juice as you normally would but then add a little fresh watermelon and a nice amount of Watermelon Simple Syrup and you’ve got the one summer drink that you’ll be making on repeat.

The mother of all Brazilian cocktails, the Caipirinha is a simple, refreshing, 3-ingredient drink that mixes Cachaça, Lime wedges and sugar for the perfect drink to have on a summer afternoon with your amigos and familiar, no matter where in the world you are.

Fusions, both in restaurants and in bars, can create some wonderful if not unexpected flavour combinations. Created in a restaurant that creates a fusion of Peruvian & Japanese, the Sake Tonic is a perfect blend of popular Sake and aromatic Elderflower for a fresh and fruity aperitif.

If you are looking to add a little richness to a classic Martini, the Olive-Oil Washed Martini achieves that by mixing Dry Vermouth with the creamy nature of Oil-Washed Vodka as a base and then adding Orange Bitters.

If you like your drinks to have a definite caffeine flavour while remaining non-alcoholic, then Brew For Two is a winner. Mixing up non-alcoholic Tequila, Little Drippa and honey, this is a drink that will keep you coming back for more.
If you are after a Daiquiri but not as you know it, then a Witches’ Daiquiri may be just the drink. Aniseed, Sweet Almond and a delicate spice subtly influence this riff on the original.

If you thought that Jägermeister was just for shots, then the Kraken Meister will show you that it’s all grown up. Add the spice of The Kraken Rum with the herbal flavour of Jägermeister, add some lime for balance and top with coke.

Created at the (now defunct) Starlight Room in San Francisco, the Starlight Reverse Martini is the perfect drink for summer, but its Vermouth-forwardness might be a bit of a problem for Vermouth-shy Martini purists.

There’s no need for grief or sorrow with Lindsey’s Lament with its potent mix of Bourbon, Becherovka and Maple Syrup. Created by the Midnight Cowboy in Austin, Texas, this is the perfect digestif on which to end the night.

If you are after a simple yet complex aperitif, then the beautifully balanced La Perla is well worth mixing up. It combines the slight saltiness of the Manzanilla sherry with the delicate fruit of Pear Liqueur and the mellow oak and vanilla flavours of Reposado Tequila.

In case you’re curious, the name of this drink translates from the Spanish to mean “Old Fashioned”, so if you were guessing that this was a Tequila Old Fashioned, then you’re probably right. In fact, the Estilo Viejo, with Tequila, Agave & Angostura Bitters, it actually is.

Light, bright and effervescent, with just a little hint of tang, the Rhubarb Spritz is best drunk outdoors with friends. The mix of Rhubarb Gin and Prosecco is brought up a notch by the inclusion of Ginger Ale.

Life would be so much simpler if every cocktail was as easy and flavoursome as the Redheaded Ginger. With Lillet Rouge, Ginger Beer and a dash of Grapefruit Bitters, this tasty aperitif is light, refreshing and perfect for a bit of day drinking.

With fruity elements from muddled berries and apple juice, Courtside is a vodka-based cocktail perfect for balmy afternoons, as the name suggests, courtside. Elevated with Elderflower Liqueur and offering effervescence with a Soda Water top, this drink is a smash, no matter where you serve it.

While being a tasty little drop, La Coquette is a frisky little minx. With Cognac, Lillet Rose, Creme De Peach and Lemon Juice, she is certainly easy to drink but in typical French style can be difficult to forget.

Created by Jody Davids, When Adam Met Eve provides a misty journey through the ‘original’ botanical gardens. The drink plays with botanicals and citrus with highlighted herbaceous notes of juniper, rosemary and basil.

Created by Ricky Agustin, Smoke Follows Beauty tkes the muddled cucumber, cilantro and heat from the Poquito Picante cocktail and the lime juice and double agave (Mezcal & Agave Syrup) from the Spicy Margarita for a drink that is sure to be your next favourite.
“Although Vanessa personally loved Mezcal cocktails, the spirit had become so prolific that she felt that these were now the only drinks she created. The advantage, of course, was the she had the opportunity to drink quite a few (in the name of research) before deciding which ones to use as the basis of her new riffs.”

Created by Julia Momose at Kumiko in Chicago, The Grey Wolf is a Japanese Whisky riff on the classic Old Fashioned, with the inclusion of the savoury-sweet acidity of Plum Vinegar and the complex sweetness of Benedictine.

Created by Rob Gourlay of Esquire Tavern in San Antonio, the Philly Smash combines muddled berries (Raspberries & Blackberries) with Sugar Syrup. Add to that, Rye Whiskey, Averna & lime Juice and this drink will produce maximum flavour for minimum effort.

Jim Kearns from Slowly Shirley in New York has created this Orgeat riff on a 19th-century classic. The Whiskey Daisy No.2 juxtaposes the subtle softness of the drinks original Bourbon with the addition of the bright spice of Rye Whiskey.

At the end of a long day, there is nothing better than kicking back with a little fresh citrus and sweet bourbon that are both made more complex and earthy with the bitter-sweet addition of Averna. Combine that mix with egg white for a creamy, delightfully foamy finish of an Averna Sour.

While you might think the Cosmo Rita is an expected mashup of a Cosmopolitan and a Margarita, you shouldn’t discount it as a gimmick. The Tequila’s earthy nature stands up more strongly than the neutrality of Vodka, and the changed ratios mean the Cranberry Juice is more pronounced.
Sitting somewhere between a Mimosa and Moscow mule, the Morning Mule can be enjoyed at any time of the day. Mixing Vodka, Orange Juice & Ginger Beer this is the ultimate easy, brunch-style drink.

A riff on the Manhattan, the Bensonhurst was created by Chad Solomon at Milk & Honey in New York in 2016 and named after a neighbourhood close to his home in Brooklyn. With Rye, Maraschino, Dry Vermouth & Cynar, this is a riff you’ll grow to love.

If you want an example of the sweetness of the Kumquat rind adding that extra dimention to a cocktail then try this St Germain & Kumquat Cocktail. With Gin, St Germain, Kumquats, Sugar Syrup and Soda Water, this is a low ABV and low sugar drink with a beautiful citrusy edge.

A delightful riff on a Margarita, Cóctel Al Pastor (which means “shepherd style” in Spanish) is adapted using spices and herbs to create a cocktail that is balenced but with a little bit of a bite.
“Vanessa strongly believed that the best bar in the world always has to be the one you’re sitting in right now. But that belief, of course, did not create award shows … so she, like so many, had come to Singapore to see the offical results. While the event itself was always fun, Vanessa found the best part of flying 9,526 miles was catching up on gossip.”

Who doesn’t love a Spritz in the summer and Everything Is Coming Up Rosé is the perfect pitcher cocktail (we have written this with pitcher measurements – if you want to make it by the glass, then divide by four).  Combining Rosé with the pleasantly bitter Aperol and delicate, floral Hibiscus Tea, this is one cocktail you’ll have on stand-by all summer long.

If you’re trying to decide how to use your gin in Spring, one of the most delightful choices is a Bees Knees riff like the Easy Beesy. With Gin, Lemon and Honey Ginger Syrup, this is wonderfully beesy and truly easy and made memorable with the scent of Rosemary.
A riff on a Tom Collins, the Grand Collins playfully swaps out Old Tom Gin for Grand Marnier, creating an intriguing, layered flavour profile to match its lively effervescence.

As you will probably assume, this is a nice twist on the classic Manhattan. The Manhattan Island highlights Cognac as the main base spirit and adds to that Rosso Vermouth, Maraschino Liqueur & Angostura Bitters.

Probably the most famous of the Last Word riffs, the Last Ward was created by Phil Ward at Death & Co New York in 2007. Replace the gin from the original with Rye and the Lime Juice with Lemon Juice and add that to the usual Green Chartreuse and Maraschino Liqueur.

The key to a good Bourbon Blackberry Smash is the muddling of the Lime wedges, Blackberries and mint leaves. And it’s only once all the oils and juices have been released that it’s time to add the Bourbon, Sugar Syrup and a good topping of Soda Water

Very much doing what it says on the box, the Cherry Bold Sour, is filled out with a touch of the flavour of Maraschino Cherry Juice. Otherwise, it’s basically a Vermouth Sour with the added benefit of lemon juice and egg white.

Moonshine, also known as White Whiskey, takes the place of Bourbon in this fruity Julep. Mixing Strawberries, with the crisp flavour of Moonshine, Lemon Juice and Mint is the perfect way to ease into the weekend.

What do rabbits drink when they are just kicking back and relaxing over the Easter long weekend, well, a Carrotini, of course. They hop to it with a mix of Ginger Vodka, Carrot “C” speciality spirit and a muddling of Mint, Lemon peel and cucumber slices.

A close relative of the Moscow Mule, the Palma Fizz is a classic Vodka Cocktail inspired by the principal city of Ibiza. Rose Water and the spicy taste of Ginger combine to create a drink as intoxicating as the islands themselves.

Nothing brightens up the middle of the week better than an Elderflower Martini. Based on a standard 50/50 Martini recipe of Gin and Dry Vermouth, with the addition of the citrus and herb notes of St Germain & Lime.
Created by H. Joseph Ehrmann of San Fransisco’s Elixir Saloon, the Peppermelon Cocktail combines sweet watermelon, smooth gin, and spicy black pepper honey syrup for a drink with an intriguing twist.

A bit earthy and a little bit spicy, Rabarbaro (which is basically a dried Rhurbard Amaro) is a perfect edition for a Margarita riff. Similar in flavour to the Tequila itself, the Rabarbaro balances the Jalapeño in this variation while mixing beautifully with the expected Reposado Tequila, Lime. Juice and Agave Syrup.

This is one of those cocktails that feels like a modern classic, the Ginger Rogers is of course named after the famous Hollywood actress. Created by Marcovaldo Dionysos, the drink mixes Gin, Lemon and both Ginger Syrup and Ginger Ale with a whole mass of Mint.

Ideal for summers spent around the pool, this riff on the Tiki tropical classic is what refreshment is all about. Wonderfully Spritz-ified, this version of a Mai Tai pares down the Rum content in lieu of a Prosecco topper.

There is something rather special about a herbal, bittersweet tequila-based cocktail that gets you every time. With Tequila, single malt Scotch, Agave Syrup, Angostura Bitters and of course Amer Picon, Something Familiar is different enough to stand out yet familiar enough to indeed feel reassuring.
First seen on the bar at Dutch Kills in New York, the Mezcaletti is strong, nutty, buttery and (as the name suggests) made with a combination of Mezcal and Amaro Meletti, built in the glass over ice.

There is nothing nicer than a little Honey and spice and no-where better to get this flavour than in the Honeysucker Cocktail. Combining Kraken Spiced Rum with the Honey Syrup and a little Lemon Juice, this cocktail will leave you wanting more.

Created at the Oxo Tower Bar in London in the early 2000s, this is a citrus-forward cocktail that is more floral than tart. This drink has Vodka, Apricot Brandy & Lemon Juice, but it is the delicate flavour of the Rose Syrup that truly shines through.
It’s commonly been said that the only thing better than a Negroni is a Coffee Negroni. And considering the drink is an equal part mix of Coffee Liqueur, Campari & Gin, we’ve got to agree.

If you are after a drink that is short and evil then Ted Kilgore’s the Devil’s Soul may just be the drink for which you are looking. Combining everything that really shouldn’t be in a glass together, including Rye, Mezcal, Avena, Aperol & St Germain this drink has a smokey, boozy, bitter complexity that will delight.

While the Unnamed Go-To may sound as if it was thrown together as a bit of an afterthought, once you taste the combination of  Cocchi Americano, Fino Sherry and Prosecco, it will truly become one Spritz you’ll never forget.

A perfect after-dinner cocktail, the Orange Brûlée combines the sweet almond flavour of Amaretto with the wonderful bitter Orange flavour of Grand Marnier. This is then topped with cream and chocolate powder, which gives this drink the look of a traditional Crème Brûlée.

Not too keen on Christmas pudding? Then make this festive season all about the flavours of a Banoffee Pie with the dessert cocktail, the Banoffee Martini. With Salted Caramel Schnapps, rich Banana Rum, Vanilla Syrup, a little chocolate bitters and some lush cream, this drink will fulfil all your Christmas dreams

If you are after a divine flavor experience, then the Kumquat-Ginger Caipirinha should definitely be on your list of drinks to make this week. This drink is a simple variation of the popular Brazilian Caipirinha cocktail, in which fresh kumquats and ginger add to the flavour of the sugar and Cachaça.

If you’ve ever mucked up a cocktail then the Negroni Sbagliato is here to show you that mistakes can still be delicious. Sbagliato, in Italian, means “mistaken”, which is what the original bartender was when he used Prosecco rather than the traditional Gin, with the Campari and Dry Vermouth.

Traditionally, after a hard day on the range, cowboys wanted good water but a little bit spiked. In this riff, Seedlip Ranch Water, we come close with all the traditional Ranch Water flavours, but due to the Notas de Agave, no spike at all.

As you would assume from the name, the Passion Play cocktail utilises the exquisite summer flavour of passionfruit. Playing off this is a wonderful mix of Don Julio Rosado, Lime Juice and a little Honey

Created by American bartender Jefferey Morgenthaler in 2009, the Caneflower Cocktail is a riff on the Comte de Sureau cocktail created by German bartender Gonçalo de Souza Monteiro. This drink mixes Cachaça, Aperol & St Germain for a beautiful sipping cocktail.

The Knickerbocker is a classic cocktail from the mid-1880s, the name is derived from the nickname of the city’s Dutch settlers who wore their pants—knickers—rolled up just below the knee. With Rum, Raspberry Syrup, Dry Orange Curacao & Lime Juice, this drink provides perfect sweetness.

Created by Ryan Fitzgerald at ABV in San Francisco, High Altitude gets its name from the Mountain origins of both the Hakushu Japanese Whiskey and the Génépy des Alpes. It is a nice riff on a Japanese Highball.

Named after the Scottish poet, Robert Burns, the Bobby Burns Cocktail had a wonderful mix of Scotch, Vermouth & Benedictine. A riff on the Rob Roy (which is, itself, a riff on a Manhattan), this cocktail is set apart by the addition of herbal Bénédictine, which turns it into a wonderfully full-bodied digestif-style drink.
