A fun, flirty twist on a classic Margarita recipe, this Ruby Grapefruit Margarita is amazingly refreshing and perfect for any party! The addition of the Ruby Grapefruit, not only amps up the colour up also the flavour of this Tequila classic.
Starting with a strong backbone of Cognac, the Seventh Son then adds a combination of the rich flavour of Cherry Heering and the more delicate flavour of Rose Syrup, then tops it off with Pilsner

There’s nothing more tempting on a summer evening than the luscious taste of strawberries, so we’re lucky that the Fragaria Martini has not only Strawberry Jam but also Strawberry Liqueur to help impart the juiciness.

Sometimes, that Margarita just doesn’t have the citrus bitterness you crave, but if you make an Italicus Margarita and swap out the Triple Sec for Italicus, your craving is satisfied in the most Margarita way.

If you’re at a bit of a loss as to what to drink tonight after dinner but you have Bourbon, Sweet Vermouth, Maraschino Liqueur and Cynar at hand, then why not make the boozy but subtly bitter and earthy Five Keys.

If you’ve ever wondered if you could have cocktails for breakfast, then a Breakfast Martini should answer that question with a resounding ‘yes!” A fun mix of Marmalade, Gin, Cointreau & Lemon Juice, this is the ideal drink to have while you contemplate your day.

This long and refreshing Raspberry and Champagne cocktail was created in 2014 for Laurent-Perrier by Sean ware of the London Cocktail Club. A variation of Dick Bradsell’s Russian Spring Punch, it mixes Vodka, Chambord, Raspberries, Lemon Juice and Champagne.

If you are after a bright, citrus-forward Daiquari then a Derby Daiquiri really should be your first choice. Created at the Mai-Kai in Fort Lauderdale, the addition of Orange Juice to the tradition Daiquari base will delight.

If green beer and Guiness aren’t you’re jam, then a Boozy Iced Coffee with Irish Cream Liqueur is a cocktail that will definitely scratch that Irish itch and provides a perfect sweet, coffee and creamy dessert-style drink.

A riff on a Paloma, the Montenegro Paloma is made all the better with a touch of one of the lightest Amari. Montenegro plays especially well with the Reposado Tequila to create a sweeter take on this quintessential warm-weather tequila drink.

Trust a Platinum Blond to be complex, with the floral nature of St Germain taming the tart, zesty, citrus of both Grapefruit Juice and Grapefruit Vodka. Added to that, there is an herbal twist from the Rosemary and much-needed balance from the simple syrup and Lemon Juice.
Created by chef Jimmy Bradley, from The Harrison in New York, the Canale Torino is the perfect three-ingredient cocktail. This refreshing aperitif is a mixture of Aperol, Dry Vermouth, and Cointreau.
A riff on Trader Vic’s original Honolulu cocktail, Honolulu #2 swaps out the Simple Syrup and dash of Grenadine for the brilliant colour and flavour of hibiscus syrup and Pomegranate Liqueur.

Just to reassure you that not all Midori Cocktails are green, we have the Midori Cranberry Lime. A simple little drink but perfect if you’ve had a long day, it mixes Midori, Cranberry Juice and a squeeze of Lime before you drop the wedge into the glass.

Pear might not be the obvious choice for fall flavour, but Pear Brandy is very much a harbinger of the season. The foundation of the Pear Sour, the Brandy and Pear Juice gives a big pear flavour, while the lemon adds tartness and the simple syrup adds the right amount of sweetness.
“Since Juan (Vanessa’s faithful PA) went off to further explore the avian population of upstate New York with the ranger, Vanessa decided to play around with a few Fall cocktail ideas. As she measured out the lemon Juice she realised that while you can take the girl out of the bar, but you can’t so easily take the bar out of the girl.”
Ginger spice and all things nice are what you are going to find in the Black Spring. With a good mix of Rye, Byrrh, Nardini Amaro and Ginger Beer, this drink has a bittersweet, fruity Rye bread bite.

Unlike what it’s name implies, the Sloe Savage Thorn is a drink that does more to dull the pain than cause it. A neat mix of Sloe Gin, Tequila, Lime Juice and Agave, this is what happens when you send the English south of the border.

Created by Harrison Ginsberg while he was at The Dead Rabbit NYC, True Blue puts a different spin on an Irish Whiskey cocktail, by adding complexity through ingredients like Pedro Ximénez sherry and white miso cane syrup.

A variation on a Dirty Martini, the Weenie Martini makes the most of s summer barbecue by adding a tomato infusion to the Dry Vermouth and a hot dog garnish to the Vodka, Pickle Brine and Celery Bitters.

In a desert area like South Africa’s Karoo, the water spirit, Mama Wata, has her own allure. In liquid form, her homage, The Karoo Beauty, mixes Tequila with White Creme de Cacao, Strawberry Syrup and a Chilli Tincture to bring a spicy, fruity, tart taste to your glass.

ingredients: 30ml Hickson Rd Wild Rosé Summer Cup
base_spirit: Hickson Rd Wild Rosé Summer Cup
description: Perfect for brunch or a late afternoon soiree, the Summer Royale is made like all Royale’s, by building from the base (in this case Hickson Rd Summer Cup), and topping it with Champagne (or an acceptable sparkling wine) in the glass.

A Bacardi Legacy winning Cocktail by Constantinos Kazelis from Lost & Found Drinkery in Nicosia, the Black In Black has all the makings of a modern classic. Inspired by a Cuba Libre, this drinks has White Rum, Averna Amaro, Simple Syrup, Lime Juice, Angostura Bitters & Tonic Water.

If you are after a Margarita with a bit more of a sweet floral yet tart profile, then the Blood Moon Margarita, with its use of Blood Orange Juice rather than Triple Sec and the inclusion of Agave Nectar is a good place to start.

While you might think of Vodka as the spirit of choice in a Greyhound, the drink’s original spirit of choice in the Prohibition era was actually Gin. So we thought we’d put a vintage spin on this simple yet classic drink by mixing our Grapefruit Juice with Gin for the ultimate Grapefruit cocktail.

The Amaretto Sour has gotten a bit of a bad rep over the years, so Jeffrey Morgenthaler, the bar manager of Clyde Common in Portland embarked on a project to make a better version. He boosted the alcoholic strength by mixing in nearly a full ounce of overproof Bourbon, replaced the sour mix with real Lemon Juice and added an Egg White.

This wonderful Rose Syrup Cocktail was one of the winning Cocktails in the 2016 Bacardi Legacy Competition. Embracing White Rum, Lime Juice, Rose Syrup, Egg White & Angostura Bitters, it’s a little like a Rose flavoured Daiquiri, so what is not to love …

In the same way, you can’t physically stop a runaway train; you can’t stop drinking this riff on a Ramos Fizz. Created at New York’s Calico, the Runaway Train combines Gin, Añejo Tequila, Aperol, Rose Combier, Grapefruit & Lime Juices and egg white.

A twist. on a classic whiskey sour, the Alexis’ Bordeaux Sour gets its colour and flavour from muddled Maraschino cherries and Lillet Rouge. Add to that Whiskey, Lemon Juice, Maple Syrup, Egg White and Orange Bitters and then this cocktail is bound to delight.

If you’re after the taste of a Dark ‘N’ Stormy but with a bit of a twist, then a Kumquat-Ginger Smash is the drink you should be making tonight. With dark Rum, Kumquats, Kumquat-Ginger Syrup and Soda Water, this is a citrus and spice twist on the original.

With a mixture of Chinese Baijiu, Brazilian Cachaca and French St Germain, this one accord we can definitely get behind. Add to that a little Lime Juice, Honey Syrup and Orange Bitters and this is a light, fruity drink that will make you want to travel more often.

If you love a Tom Collins than you’ll find this riff, the Juan Collins, a pure delight. With Tequila, Lemon Juice, Sugar Syrup and topped with Soda Water, this cocktail adds a little Mexican spirit to the classic

If you are looking for a more Caribbean riff on a Mule Cocktail then why not take your taste buds on a trip and mix yourself up a Jamaican Mule. With Jamaican Rum, Lime Juice, Sugar Syrup & Ginger Beer, this is not only quick and easy but has a wonderful spicy Ginger taste.

An exceptionally tasty cocktail (and one of our simple favourites), the Ginger Scotch is as the name describes a highball of Scotch Whisky that’s topped with Ginger Ale. Cool, refreshing, yet a little spicy, this is a winner at any time.

If you are after a boozy, berry bomb then you should really be making a Blackberry Tequila Smash. After gently muddling some Blackberries, add in Sugar Syrup, Grapefruit Juice and Tequila for a drink that combines the best of summer.

If you are after an elegant cocktail that is also devilishly sweet, then the Mezcal-based Aventura will surprise you. It mixes the smokiness of the Mezcal with the sweetness of seasonal berries and the lively flavours of St. Germain and Grand Marnier.

Who doesn’t love a pun? And especially when it created with a bitter French apéritif made from the gentian root. But more than just the Suze Liqueur, Suze You, Sir, incorporates Tequila, the herbal complexity of Dry Vermouth and the sweetness of Agave.

Created by German blogger Matthias Friedlein (@mjm_augustine), the Two Trains is a fantastic liquorice-laced riff on the 20th Century cocktail. This is the perfect drink for train watching with Gin, Vermouth, Creme de Cacao, Lemon Juice, and Liquorice Syrup.

“Singularly shaped by the elements, Mezcal’s aroma and character are a natural pairing with Earthen, which mixes marvellously with tangy fresh-squeezed pink grapefruit juice.” – Jim Meehan
Image – AJ Meeker

Hopefully we don’t actually need to be stain in battle for the valkyries to lead us to Valhalla Rising. But either way, it’s easy to believe that the combination of Ginger Syrup, Sherry, Pilsner and Aquavit are definitely flavours worthy of the gods.

With the ingredients of the cocktail also making up the foam top, the Longest Sip, created by Nkosinathi Shabangu from Saint in Johannesburg, is a wonderfully complex drink with a robust mouthfeel. The aroma and spice of the Lavender Ricard Syrup blends seamlessly with the bitters that open up the flavours of the Cointreau and Cognac

If you’ve ever thought a Moscow Mule would be perfect, if only it had Grapefruit Vodka, then a Grapefruit Mule is the solution. Add to that the usual Lime Juice and Ginger Beer and you have a light, refreshing riff on the classic.

A nice little riff on the Negroni, the Amaroni has all the usual suspects (Gin & Sweet Vermouth) but swaps out the Campari for Amaro di Angostura for a drink that has rich, spicy, Cinnamon & Licorice notes that are distinctly Angostura.

We won’t go as far as to say it’s healthy but the Cascade has enough Raspberries in it that there must be some vitamin C and antioxidants floating around. Add to that Vodka, Cranberry Juice, Lemon Juice and Chambord for a drink that’s as good as it looks.

Like an almond cookie in drink form, a Disaronno Fizz is an impossibly fresh, zesty aperitif. Marrying the zing of lemon with the sweet almond of Amaretto, this drink comes to life with the addition of Soda Water.

If you want a nice little riff on the Bramble, why not throw all your chips in and make yourself a Gamble cocktail. With Gin, Sloe Gin, Grapefruit Juice, Sugar Syrup & Cherry Heering, this is an easy to drink, gin-laced, fruity drink.

Created by Alex Richer at the Red Bar in London, you can think of the Green Beetle as Tequila and lemon aromatized by Absinthe. In other words, an absinthe wash gives body to Reposado Tequila, Agave Syrup and Limoncello.

An early variation on the classic Martini, the Turf cocktail has a multitude of variations. This one here is based on the 1922 Harry MacElhone’s version with Gin, Dry Vermouth, Maraschino Liqueur & Orange Bitters.

Created by Eryn Reece at Mayahuel in New York, this cocktail really is, as its name suggests, The Real Deal. This deep-flavoured nightcap combines  Mezcal, Punt e Mes, Sweet Vermouth and a touch of Fernet Branca.

The Montreal Cocktail is a wonderful Rye cocktail created by a collaboration of 15 Montreal bartenders. Intended to represent Montreal’s French (through the use of Suze) & English (through the use of Gin) influences, it also throws a little Italian (Aperol) in for good measure.

While you might initially think the name of this cocktail, the Cuban Heal is a typo and we’re talking about shoes, it is in fact from the healing qualities of the ingredients that the name derives. With Rum (the Cuban part) and Cynar, Limoncello, Honey Syrup & Peychaud’s (the healing part), this drink is sweetly herbal.

Named after Dutchess County in New York State, the Dutchess owes part of its spelling to the addition of Genever, this Angostura heavy cocktail was created by Theo Lieberman of Lantern’s Keep and Milk and Honey in NYC.

A little like an aged rum-based Espresso Martini, Out To Sea adds unexpected depth and character with the inclusion of Fernet Branca and Falernum for a drink that is ideal as an aperitif (and is far less salty than the name implies).

Take the Martini into a teeny-tiny cocktail with Tayēr + Elementary’s One Sip Martini. Using Vodka, Vermouth di Torrino and Fino Sherry, sometimes one sip is enough (especially if you have a few of them).

The 3G may sound a little antiquated as we enter a 5G world, but once you realise that those G’s stand for Gin, St Germain and Ginger Liqueur, then the light, crisp and refreshing taste of this drink seems completely appropriate.

Taste Of Life was created by John Ng from MO Bar in Hong Kong and combines sweet, sour, salt and a little bitterness for a complex but refreshing drink inspired by the citrus-adorned streets of Hong Kong’s lunar new year celebration.

Sometimes you need a cocktail that will raise your spirits and what better name for that cocktail than the Gloom Lifter. It’s basically a Cognac and Irish Whiskey sour (with a little Grenadine Syrup), served straight up – and if that doesn’t get your spirits up, we don’t know what will.

Paying homage to the Swiss roots of the famously French liqueur Suze, the Swiss Account is a bittersweet aperitif with herbal notes. Created by Griffin Cox at Lot Six in Halifax, this drink mixes Vodka, Suze, Benedictine and Grapefruit Bitters.

Created by bartender John Hall at the Australian bar, Justin Lane on the Gold Coast, comes the Australiano. A cheeky riff on the Americano, with Australian-made Vermouth, Amaro and a housemade native botanical Soda
Image by Declan Roache

If you’re after a cocktail with a gentle pink blush and subtle taste of Rose then you can’t do better than an Indian Rose. With Gin, Apricot Brandy, Rose Water & Rose Syrup, this is a gentle but potent little drink.

What happens when Campari and Italian Vermouth meet the sand and sun of the Caribbean? Well, that would be a Kingston Negroni. Overproof Jamaican Rum stands up to the bombastic chocolate and bitter orange notes in the vermouth while drying out the Campari’s richness and tempering its bitterness.
Although offering savoury notes from the H by Hine Cognac, the Rosa di Roma is the perfect floral and light aperitivo that offers citrus notes from both the Bitter Bianco and dry Curaçao

Although you are swapping Bourbon for Pomegranate Juice, the Pomegranate Amaretto Sour is definitely a vibrant crowd-pleaser that attempts to make up for the lack of brown spirits with a dash of Bitters.

Nothing is better in the lead up to Burns Night than a good solid Scotch Cocktail and you can’t get better than a Return To Alcatraz. With blended Scotch, Grand Marnier, Lemon Juice, Orange & Vanilla Syrup & a touch of Ginger Liqueur this is a warming drink that will do your tartan proud.

A story as old as time, a Titan falls in love with a nymph, rebels against the gods and is subsequently turned into a jagged mountain at the southernmost tip of Africa. The Adamastor, as he was known, literally became Cape Peninsula, which in liquid form is represented by Gin, Dry Vermouth, Lychee Syrup, all top with a delicate Salted Aloe Air

If you are looking for a highball with a bit more of a luxurious taste, then the Grand Smash might be the right drink to have beside the courts this summer. Offering the complexity of Cognac as a base, it is given added depth with key notes of citrus and mint.

The only cocktail that we know to combine Whiskey, Port & Rum, the Suburban is a bit of an unusual Classic Cocktail. Originating in the 1930s, the combination of Bourbon, Tawny Port, Aged Rum, Orange Bitters and Angostura Bitters is definitely a riff on a Manhattan.

If you’re looking to add a bit of colour to your Old Fashioned, then there is no better way to do it than by swapping out the sugar for Grenadine. As well as the obvious Grenadine, the Grenadine Old Fashioned mixes Wheated Bourbon and Angostura Bitters for a vibrant version of this old favourite.

You’ve got to love a cocktail that looks crazy on paper but is actually half-decent in real life. The Blinker is a refreshing drink that incorporates Rye, Grapefruit Juice and Grenadine – see what we mean but don’t pass judgement until you give it a try.

Created by Damon Boelte of Brooklyn’s Prime Meats, the Glasgow Mule is a mule variation that uses Scotch instead of Vodka. The result is a tart and spicy cocktail that retains the Ginger Beer from the original but adds Lemon Juice, Angostura Bitters and a little St Germain.
Created by the late Jim Meehan, The Nose To Cocktail incorporates bacon-infused Irish whiskey, dark maple syrup, and lemon and orange juices and, of course, a whole egg.

In the drink, Bitter harbour, the lushness of Tawny Port finds a strong partner with smoke-laced Mezcal. These ingredients are then held together with the Gran Classico Bitter for a bittersweet cocktail that is not only ideal in a single-serve but is also wonderful when batched.

It’s not often that you get a cocktail gets named after a horse but when Simon Difford Created this drink in 2015, Velvet Maker was the filly that won the horse-race he was listening to in Ireland. The drink itself is well balanced with a botanical complexity from the Vanilla-infused Vodka, zesty Grapefruit and Dry Vermouth.

If you are after an easy alternative to a G&T, why not replace the Gin with the bitter complexity of Suze, for Le Petite Bouche (then simply add Rum, Orange Bitters  and, of course, Tonic Water). This dry and refreshing aperitif was created by Danny Wilson at Tabouche in Cambridge, UK.

Referred to in the “Bar La Florida” recipe booklet of 1935, the Golden Glove is, as liquor.com points out, ‘like a Daiquiri-Margarita hybrid’ that combines familiar flavours into a drink that is strong, refreshing and citrusy.

Made famous by NYC’s Waldorf Astoria Hotel, the Foghorn is a classic cocktail that utilises Gin, Ginger Beer (although Ginger Ale can be used), and Lime Juice (which is the one ingredient that differentiates it from a Gin Buck) for a refreshing drink that is classically made in an Old Fashioned glass but can also be made (as we have done) in a highball.

If you’ve spent time thinking that Bourbon would be even more amazing if only it had a clean mint finish, then grab your shaker, son, ’cause we’ve got a cocktail to make. The Dixie Dew is as fresh as the name implies, with Bourbon, White Creme de Menthe & Cointreau.

With Lemon & Basil flavours shining through, the Black Basil Cocktail is perfect for summer sunset sipping. With Basil, Vodka, Limoncello, Lemon Juice, Sugar Syrup and topped with a good dose of Tonic Water

Smoke & Mirrors does as the name implies and distracts you from its non-alcoholic nature with a satisfying amount of froth and creaminess. With Little Drippa, this drink will provide the solid cold extracted coffee hit you need.

It’s hard to not smile when a refreshing and fruity concotion like the Poker Face is put in front of you. With a solid base of Tequila, the nice brightness of Cointreau and a good dose of almost tropical Pineapple Juice, this drink is a cure for whatever ails you.

When the wind is up, there is nothing better than pulling out the Ginger Wine and making a cocktail like the Stone & Gravel. Popular in Jamaica, this drink combines White Rum & Green Ginger Wine for a simple, easy and surprisingly good little drink.

While this might look like the typical recipe for an Espresso Martini, this Belvedere version has shifted the proportions. This drink has a little more Coffee Liqueur than usual but less Vodka and less Simple Syrup (while the Espresso shot remains the same).

If you’re after something bitter and boozy, yet dangerously drinkable, then then the Sharpie Moustache might just be your cocktail. Easy to make with equal parts of Rye, Gin, Meletti Amaro & Sweet Vermouth, this spicy, herbal cocktail will definitely hit the spot.

If you’re going to do an after-dinner sipper then why wouldn’t you make a Parle-vous Irish Cocktail, where your Cognac is accompanied by Irish Whiskey that has been stirred in with rich orange and herbal liqueurs.

As you might assume from the name, this Tequila based drink is a riff on the classic Gimlet. As everyone knows Tequila and Lime are divine and the earthiness of this spirits certainly makes up for the loss of Gin’s botanicals.

Created in 2014 by Márcio Silva, the Lavarello cocktail is a nice, boozy riff on the Rabo-de-Galo which swaps out the sweet vermouth for Cynar and then adds that to the Cachaça, Aperol & Chocolate Bitters.

One of the Soho House groups’ House Tonic cocktails, the eastern Standard is based on the Eastside Cocktail which is of course itself based on the classic Southside. With Gin, Lime Juice, Simple Syrup, Mint and Cucumber, this is a drink that is cool and refreshing with the right amount of zing.

If you’re after a rich, somewhat indulgent cocktail at the end of the week than a Jungle Fire Sling ticks all the boxes. Cognac balances out Cherry Heering, Parfait Amour Liqueur & Benedictine with the zing of Ginger Ale.

If you are after a liquid representation of a vivid sunset in a cocktail glass, then the Vivid Gibson is the cocktail for you. Created by Joey Tai for Clooney By XO in Melbourne, this drink creates a symphony of citrus sweet & savoury refreshing notes.
Image by Sam Bygrave – kindly provided by Australian Cocktail Month

If you are after a cocktail with a truly summer flavour, then perhaps its time to give the Raspberry Thyme Margarita a try. With the Tequila and Cointreau from the original, this drink adds Lemon Juice, Raspberries & Thyme to the mix, so that all you’ll need to add is the sun.

Although the Chancellor is very much a classic, its origin story is pretty much unknown. But our lack of knowledge aside, the Scotch, Dry Vermouth, Tawny Port, and Sugar Syrup result in a complex, sophisticated drink with fruity notes.

Nothing puts hope in your mind and love in your heart more than the summer flavours of Lillet Rose and Raspberries in a Sweet Charity Cocktail. With Lillet Rose, St Germain, Soda Water and Raspberries to garnish, this is an elegant, floral drink that certainly impress.

It may sound contradictory, but this drink has elements of saline and smoke,  like if you were eating sushi at a BBQ. Gia It Laldie! is a verb that means to give one all. With Laphroaig 10-year, Cachaça, cardamom ginger cordial, soda water and a garnish with cucumber ‘seaweed’, this drink has a beautiful vigour and energy.

Sophisticated? ✅ Refreshing? ✅ Fresh and dry ✅✅. This version of a Cucumber Martini is a clean, natural take on the classic. With Vodka, Bison Grass Vodka, Cucumber and Simple Syrup, you’ll find that cucumber has never tasted so good.

If you love a White Russian but always wanted it to be more Christmas-y, then the Peppermint White Russian needs to be in your glass right now. Using the Kahlúa, Cream and Vodka of the original, this drink ups the Xmas factor with the addition of Peppermint Schnapps.
“While Vanessa had been prepared for most of the horrors that the hospitality industry goes through during the festive season, she had not expected the number of times she would need to duck or suddenly change direction to avoid random guests with unexpected sprigs of mistletoe”

ingredients: 15ml Simple Syrup (star anise and black tea-infused)
description:
Spicy, sweet and a touch floral, The Ginger Rabbit offers heady aromatics, with a Ginger, a Bourbon base and infusions of black tea and star anise. Rounded off with Creme Yvette, this drink is packed with flavour and a perfect way to end the day.
“As Vanessa continued to play with tea-in-cocktail combinations, she found her ideas were multiplying faster than a rabbit on heat. But it wasn’t until she whipped up a nice little Bourbon number, that she noticed the tea was bringing out the background notes, and that really started to spice things up.”

If you’re a gin drinker, a G&T is probably your go-to and why not, it does exactly what it says on the tin by mixing Gin with Tonic Water. You can get overly fancy with garnishes but to our mind, as long as its namesakes are good quality, you can’t beat a simple lime.

If you are after a bittersweet but mellow aperitif, then Reno with Montenegro, Suze, Americano Bianco, and Italicus, is a good call. Named after the river in Bologna in Italy, this drink was created by Georgio Ferrarese at the Holy Birds in London.

Designed as a variation on the delicious Trinidad Sour, the Surprise Sour is an equal parts cocktail that is truly more than its parts. With Amaro di Angostura, Scotch, Lemon Juice, Pineapple Juice & an Egg White, this is a drink you’ll come back to again.

The Blood & Sand is a classic scotch-based cocktail that has withstood the test of time. The recipe first appeared in 1930 in The Savoy Cocktail Book by Harry Craddock and has become a mainstay on bar menus ever since with Scotch, Cherry Heering, Sweet Vermouth & Orange Juice
A popular drink throughout Mexico, the El Torado is a delightfully fruity little number. With Dry Vermouth and Apple Juice, it has a dry sophistication with a backbone of Reposado Tequila.

Created by Wyn Vida, beverage director at The Cathedral in Austin, Texas, the Dulce Vida Prickly Pear is a refreshing, easy-to-construct Margarita riff with an eye-catching colour that will grab you every time.
You could easily say that the Crystal Clear cocktail is clearly refined. With Vodka, Italicus, Kummel Liqueur and Birch Water, this drink has a subtle citrus, pine and carraway flavour.

Raspberry fruit richness balances with bitter botanical complexity in the Irish Whiskey-based drink Super Seedy. With an affinity to an Old Fashioned, this cocktail uses Irish Whiskey (preferably Jameson’s Caskmate Stout Edition), Raspberry Syrup and Suze.

With a rich colour, a robust fruit flavour, and depth from a combination of rums, this Strawberry Daiquiri will delight you at every sip. Refreshing and summer-ready, you can easily amp everything up by allowing the muddled fruit to sit in the tin with the other ingredients for a few minutes before shaking.
Refreshing is the watchword when it comes to the Irish Mule. A twist on the classic Moscow Mule, this drink is super easy to put together, combining Irish Whiskey, Lime Juice and Ginger Beer

The phrase, The Bees Knees, was used in Prohibition times as slang to mean ‘the best’. And the combination of Gin, Honey Syrup and lemon Juice, this classic drink is the definition of a  buzz-worthy cocktail.

If you like your Margarita with a bit more of an international flair, then the Italian Margarita should be in your shaker tonight. The Amaretto adds a nice dash of Apricot and Almond flavour to the usual suspects of Reposado Tequila, Cointreau and Lime Juice.

The Painkiller is a variation of the classic Pina Colada and was created at the infamous Soggy Dollar Bar in the British Virgin Islands using Navy Rum, fresh Pineapple Juice, fresh Orange Juice & Cream Of Coconut.

If you want to show off the delightful sweetness of fig, then there is no better cocktail than a Figtini. With Fig Liqueur, Vanilla Vodka, Lemon Juice and a few dashes of Aromatic Bitters, this is a perfect cocktail to drink in an imperfect world.

If you are after a coffee cocktail that’s not an Espresso Martini then a Pura Vida might be just the ticket. With the rich smokey flavour of Mezcal, the sweet earthy taste of Tia Maria, the smooth full-bodied taste of Averna, and the nice zesty flavour of Orange Bitters.
For an Eastern European version of a Gin & Tonic, you can’t go past a Beton Cocktail. Add the Czech liqueur, Becherovka to a good quality Tonic Water for a cool refreshing drink with a hint of spice.
A beautifully balanced yet refreshing long drink, the Tennessee Berry Mule is a wonderful combination of berries, almond, and ginger, rounded off with a distinctive Tennessee Whiskey kick

My love for telling stories is the key behind my creations, to share and be part of the Patrón Perfectionists story is something I am immensely thankful for! My cocktail strives to bring the story of the Patrón Jimadors to life, and I am extremely proud of the outcome! – Aiden Rodriquez – Eau de Vie

If you are after a spiritous and aromatic cocktail then the paycheck is a drink that pays off. The Honey Syrup balances the bitter Suze which both works nicely with the Earl Grey infused Gin, Dry Vermouth and Cointreau.

Sloe Gin replaces sweet vermouth in this simple Negroni riff. The Sloe Gin replaces the Vermouth and has just enough sweetness to balance the gin and Campari. The Sloe Gin adds some bright red berry notes to the drink and has a surprising amount of acid.
Sweet and creamy, the Celtic Frappe is a drink that offers more than just a boozy ice cocktail due to the mix of Irish Honey Liqueur, Vermouth & Pastis

Watermelon takes centre stage in the Watermelon Elderflower Cocktail. Accentuated with rum, elderflower liqueur, and a hint of Lime Juice these ingredients combine to create a satisfying and refreshing drink.

With notes of dried fruits, caramelized banana, and soft baking spices, the Emerald Cocktail is a riff on a Manhattan created at The Dean Bar in Rhode Island and made with Irish Whiskey instead of Rye or Bourbon.
“After making her fourteenth Espresso Martini that hour, Vanessa was delighted (and let’s face it relieved) when a guest asked instead for a bartender’s choice, stipulating only that the drink should match the colour of the red Christmas ornaments on the bar.”

There’s nothing like a Witch Hunt to get the blood pumping. And with Strega (Italian for Witch) hidden beautifully in this cocktail among the Scotch and Dry Vermouth, we think you’ll enjoy the chase as much as we do.

Pulitzer Prize-winning author Viet Thanh Nguyen’s favourite tipple may be Scotch but when it comes to cocktails, he loves to shake up The Sympathizer. Named after this book, this Bourbon, Aperol, Cynar cocktail was devised by his book representative Andrea Tetrick and was served at the book launch for the novel.

If you are after a slightly more unusual margarita riff, then you can’t go past a Weaver. The Hibiscus Syrup melds wonderfully with the Saffron and Anise flavours of the Meletti creating a wonderful depth.

At this time of year, there is no way to get away from the Mint Julep. And who would want to? With Bourbon, Simple Syrup and Mint, this traditional Derby Day cocktail is practically a southern ritual.

No cocktail embodies the subtle Ginger flavour provided by a ginger Liqueur better than the Oooh Ginger. A delicate mix of Añejo Tequila, Ginger Liqueur and Dry Vermouth, this drink has an almost Martini-like quality.

Ada Coleman created the Hanky Panky for a customer who wanted a drink with a bit of punch to it. And with the combination of Gin, Sweet Vermouth and Fernet Branca, that is exactly what this drink provides.

The wonderful aperitif wine, Lillet Rose, takes the driver’s seat in this fruity, summery Martini riff. The best way to describe a Reverse Rose Martini, is by referring to it as a Martini/Aperitif hybrid, which has less Gin than the traditional Martini but enough Lillet Rose (instead of Vermouth) to provide a much lighter, floral flavour.

If you are faced with a little left over Champagne, then turn it into a syrup and throw it into this wonderful Daiquiri riff. The Rum, Lime and Champagne work beautifully together in a drink that you’ll be sipping all summer long.

Cuba Libre is a fancy of way of saying a Rum & Coke. Translated from Spanish, the name means “Free Cuba,” a phrase that was popularized around the end of the Spanish-American War and used to celebrate that Cuba was freed from Spanish rule.

With the citrus of Cointreau and the fruity palate of Rémy Martin 1738, it’s only natural to think of any riff on a Sidecar as having ‘breakfast cocktail’ overtones. This is very much the case with Purple Haze, created by Blessing Maphosa from Marble Restaurant in Johannesburg, which highlights this idea with a Foccaia and Raspberry Jam garnish

For a classic mix of Caribbean flavours, you really can’t go past a Corn ‘n’ Oil. The “oil” in the Corn ‘n’ Oil is a reference to blackstrap rum, which sits atop this cocktail like a puddle of petroleum.

A Frenchified riff on a Greyhound, the Bichon Frisé cocktail is just as darling as you would expect. While its accent comes from the addition of St Germain, there certainly wouldn’t be any harm in adding a French Vodka like Grey Goose to the mix.

Inspired by the modern classic, the Penicillin, the This & That Cocktail was created by Beth Willows at Seaworthy in New Orleans. This drink adds a healthy dose of Peach Liqueur to the Scotch, Lemon Juice & Ginger Syrup.

This pretty pink, gin-based cocktail is closely related to the Pegu Club but comes from the Pendennis Club in Louisville, Kentucky. It uses Apricot Brandy instead of Curaçoa and Peychard’s Bitters which adds a bright flavour profile.

The fun thing about the Lychee Colada is that you don’t need to enjoy long walks in the rain. In fact, all you’ll need to love is Rum, Coconut Milk, Coconut Water & Lychees to make this milky, frothy drink work for you.

Apparently first served to actor Broderick Crawford back in 1941, the history of the Moscow Mule is one of oversupply. When you need to get rid of Copper Mugs, Ginger Beer and promote a new Russian Vodka in the US, you end up with this refreshingly spicy Cocktail.

Created by Zac Overman at the now-defunct Fort Defiance in Brooklyn, the Angostura Colada is a riff on a Pina Colada. While retaining the original’s Pineapple and Coconut, the drink replaces much of the Rum with Angostura bitters, which is balanced by the Overproof Rum and Lime.

Pleasant, unexpected and thirst-quenching. Teal is a combination of all green ingredients and 100% Blue Agave. It’s a celebration of the green top notes of Patrón Silver reminiscent of fresh-cut grass, lime zest and eucalyptus – Harrison Kenney – Cantina OK! – Sydney

With its name derived from the early 20th century was mayor of Dijon, France, Félix Kir, the Kir is an enduring classic. With Cassis and dry white wine, this simple yet elegant drink is the perfect aperitif.

It may be Christmas Eve but if you can get your hands on some strawberries, then you really should throw as many as you can into this refreshing Sake-based cocktail. Take a moment to appreciate the fresh, refreshing taste of this drink before all the madness of tomorrow.

Burrowing the art of whisking from the kitchen, the Port Cocoa Flip folds a depth of flavour from the Port into the aromatic spice from the Bitters and Brandy before creating a full mouth feel from the combination of Creme de Cacao, Cocoa Powder and Vanilla Syrup

Bright and floral, the Esmeralda cocktail was created by Ben Sandrof at Drink in Boston. It mixes Cachaça with Lime Juice and St germain but it’s the futher addition of Islay Single Malt that really makes this drink.

Inspired by one of history’s greatest explorers – Columbus. Our shared passion for adventure, change and discovery and our personal experience of Mexico and Italy led me to fuse these ingredients while painstakingly and sustainably extracting their true feelings and flavours to perfection – Niccolo’ Maffezzoni – The Trader Bar – Darwin

Created by Dick Bradsell in the 1980s, this stunning red punch is a sledgehammer of a drink. With Vodka, Créme de Cassis, Lemon Juice, Sugar Syrup and Champagne, this drink could have been defined as the perfect seasonal punch.
Created by Chaim Dauermann at Up & Up NYC, the Insanely Good Gin & Tonic is insanely good, due to the mix of the Gin & Suze to which Angostura and housemade lime cordial is added.

If you ever wondered what would happen if you put more than just a dash of Angostura Bitters in a cocktail, then let me introduce you to the Bitter Last Word. As you might assume this is another Last Word riff, so you’ll need to add Green Chartreuse, Maraschino and Lime Juice (as you’d expect).

Nothing enlivens the classic Mint Julep Cocktail better than a little heat, as we find in the Jalapeño-Spiked Bourbon Julep. Jalapeño infused Sugar Syrup is muddled in with Mint before crushed ice and Bourbon is added for a cocktail with a bit of bite.
While some may call it boring, others define the Vodka Soda as a timeless classic. Definitely simple, clean and crisp, this cocktail is the perfect drink when you don’t want anything too fussy.

Nothing says summer like a mango and it works particularly well with a good dry Vermouth, as it does in a Mango Buck. Infuse the Mango in the vermouth and then mix with Ginger Beer for a refreshing summery drink.
A classic but under-rated tequila cocktail, the El Diablo, is a wonderful mid-century drink that combines Tequila with Crème de cassis (a sweet blackcurrant liqueur), Lime juice and ginger.

Created in 2003, by Eric Fossard at Cecconi’s in London, the Watermelon Cosmo is a fun, fruity riff on the original. With a mix of muddled Watermelon, citrus Vodka, Lime Juice, Cranberry Juice, Watermelon Liqueur and Orange Bitters this drink has poolside written all over it.

Catrina, originally known as “La Calvera Garboncera,” was a cartoon created in 1913 to mock the emerging upper classes in Mexico who appeared to be denying their Mexican heritage by adopting more European styles of dress. La Catrina was a reminder that “everyone is equal in the end.” While true, the same can’t be said for this particular cocktail, which is elevated with Horchata, cinnamon syrup, and Patrón Añejo.
Created by Sasha Petraske, of Milk & Honey fame, the Cosmonaut as a cheeky dig on the Cosmopolitan. Much simpler than the classic it only uses three ingredients – Gin, Lemon Juice and Raspberry Jam.

With overtones of a Paloma Cocktail, the Ginger Grapefruit Cocktail has the same refreshing qualities but with a little bit more spice. With Gin, Ginger Liqueur, Lime Juice, Ruby Grapefruit and Soda Water, this is a drink that is easy as Sunday morning.

With Easter fast approaching, there is no better time to highlight a few Carrot based cocktails – and no better spirit to use than Carrot ‘C’ Specialty Spirit from Boardroom Spirits. Distilled from actual carrots, the spirit is a perfect addition to a Carrot Cosmo, especially when it is mixed with a little Triple Sec and Carrot Juice.
Image courtesy of Boardroom Spirits

Named after the famous hotel in West Virginia, the Greenbriar was first recorded in Harry McElhone’s 1927 Barflies and Cocktails. In that recording and most others, the type of Sherry wasn’t actually listed, so through the skill of Simon Difford Oloroso Sherry was decided upon and then added to the Dry Vermouth and Peach Bitters.

Sometimes a spirit-forward cocktail is really your only option. With this in mind, we present The Addington, a beautifully balanced, stirred Cognac-based cocktail with Vermouth di Torino and Benedictine.

If you are after a little spice in your Daiquiri, then you can’t fault a Ginger Daiquiri. Combining Spiced Rum and a little Ginger Syrup (sliced Ginger root with sugar and water) and the usual Lime Juice, this cocktail adds a bit of bite to the classic.

Created by Jim Kearns working at The Happiest Hour in New York City, Fall From The Tree is a cocktail that embraces an autumnal mix of baking spice, apple and brown spirits.
“While Vanessa was a little thrown by the amount of fall decorations that had suddenly appeared in the bar, she did appreciate the seasonal change to the cocktail menu. Sure, she couldn’t see the bartender over all the faux autumn leaves but after a few of his Applejack concoctions, she realised she really didn’t need to …”

If you’re looking to create a lively cocktail that beautifully marries the earthy complexities of both Suze and Reposado Tequila than you will have found it in Suze-Tequila Sour. Simple add Lemon Juice and a bit of Agave to the mix and you’ll be all set.

Found in fields and woodlands throughout County Meath, Jackdaw are highly adaptable, sociable crows that work together for the greater good of the flock.   The Jackdaw cocktail is based on the tropical Jungle Bird, with Irish Whiskey, Pineapple Juice, Campari, Simple Syrup & Lime Juice.

cocktail_name: A Few Of My Favourite Things
description: All Sound Of Music jokes aside, A Few Of My Favourite Things is a wonderful bittersweet citrusy cocktail that’s hard to resist. With Cognac, Sherry, Aperol, Green Chartreuse, Angostura Bitters & Orange Bitters, we assume this might just be one of your favourite things too.

Created by Meaghan Dorman at Raines Law Room in NYC, the Midnight Boutique makes it the perfect nightcap. Incorporating St-Germain alongside grapefruit, the drink balances these bittersweet flavours with the salinity and smokiness of Mezcal and Tequila.

Named after the sugar on the rim, the Brandy Crusta was invented by Joseph Santini, a bartender in New Orleans at his bar, Jewel of the South back in the late 1800s. One of the establishing classics, this drink is a mix of Brandy, Maraschino Liqueur, Orange Curaçao, Lemon Juice, Sugar Syrup, and Angostura bitters.
“Standing on the banks of the Mississipi River, Vanessa realised that a half-dozen ensuring classic cocktails had been born from these shores. The thought made her wonder whether any of the amazing new drinks she had tried as part of New Orleans Cocktail Week, would also add to the annuls and impact on the future with the same resonance as the brandy drink she held in her hands.”

If you are finding the temperature starting to rise, then you can do no better than to make yourself The Two-One-Two. With Reposado Tequila, Aperol & Ruby Grapefruit Juice, this drink has the appearance of liquid sunshine and a crisp, tart flavour.

A riff on a Sidecar, The Disco Waldo, created by Alex da Fonseca from The Blockman in Johannesburg, takes inspiration from the colours and flavours found in the disco era of cocktails. The tropical fruit notes in the Cape Vintage Port plays beautifully with the citrus of the Cointeau and the plum and fig notes of the Cognac.

There’s nothing as lush as velvet and in this case, Red Velvet as created by Brendon Osmers at Gerard’s in Brisbane. The strawberry & lemongrass, red currants and dry fino create a zesty, fresh body which is carried through to the bubbles by the bittersweet Elderflower Tonic
Image – Sam Bygrave

The Beet Margarita puts a truly vegetal spin on the. classic. With the usual Tequila, Cointreau, and Lime Juice, this drink adds Beet Juice, Apple Cider Vinegar, and Sea Salt for a Margarita like no other.

Created in 2016 by Rhys Wilson at Happiness Forgets in London, the Jerezana Cocktail (pronounced ‘hera-zana’) is a delicious stirred drink. Combining two Sherries and two Vermouths, this cocktail is heightened by Vanilla and the citrus of Orange Bitters.

Created by Jeffrey Morgenthaler in 2001, the Bourbon Renewal is essentially a fruity Bourbon Sour that punches above its weight. It is enhanced with Creme de Cassis for a juicy fullness and a dash of Bitters.

A riff on the Daiquiri, Against All Odds was created at New York’s Red Paper Clip. Showcasing the funky character and aromatics of Ten To One White Rum, the drink provides an unexpected yet flavoursome twist on the original with the addition of the Chinese 5-Spice Syrup.

Created by Audrey Saunders of NYC’s Pegu Club, the Gin Gin Mule is often thought of as a Moscow Mule but with Gin. As the name suggests though, there are two Gins involved – the first is a good London Dry, the second is Ginger Beer, which when combined with the Mint, Lime Juice & Sugar Syrup gives this drink an almost Mojito feel.

Named after the New Orleans suburb, the Bywater was created in 2008 by Chris Hannah at Arnaud’s French 75 Bar. With aged Rum, Amer Picon, Green Chartreuse, Falernum & Peychaud Bitters, this is a spirit-forward, bittersweet, herbal cocktail that is perfect as an after-dinner digestif

If you’re looking for a drink with a tropical edge but a definite kick, the Snake Eyes may well be worth the gamble. With muddled Jalapeño and Basil, Pisco, Passionfruit Purée, Mango Purée, Lime Juice & Agave, the odds of you liking this drink are better than its namesake (1 in 36, if you’re curious).

Fig season can seem relatively short but with the aid of Fig Liqueur, cocktails like Mr Fig Stuff can be created all year round. In addition to the Fig Liqueur, throw a little Gin, Marashino Liqueur and Lemon Juice, for a drink that will sate your fig desires every time.

Created by Salvadore Calabrese at Fifty in London, the Salty Martini is a drink that benefits from a long stir. As the name suggests, there is a saltiness that comes through the Caper Brine, as well as from the Fino Sherry, which also adds a distinct nuttiness.

The bright, citrus blend of Seedlip Grove mixed with Clementine Juice (or Orange Juice if you’d like) and topped with Soda Water in the Seedlip Mimosa, is the perfect way to have all the fun of brunch without the day-drinking.

While Vermouth is mainly used as a modifier these days, that was not always the case and the Reverse Manhattan is a homage to those former days. With Sweet Vermouth, Rye and Angostura Bitters, this is a wildly delicious drink if balanced correctly.

Refreshing and bubbly and easy to drink, The Cornell Special is usually served straight up but can easily be adapted to be served over ice. With Gin, Benedictine, Lemon Juice & Soda Water this is a truly classic Equal Parts Cocktail.

If you are after a cocktail that’s bright and full of depth, then the Berlin Wall might be worth a visit. With Tequila, Lime Juice, Falernum and Orange Bitters, this is another drink that shows just how versatile Falernum is to your home bar.

Created at New York City bar Mother’s Ruin by bartender Sylvanus Johnson, Word To Your Cardamom is a tongue-in-cheek riff on a Margarita that uses Mezcal, the aperitif Barolo Chinato and Cardamom Syrup in addition to Tequila and Lime.
“Returning to New York, Vanessa had been looking forward to celebrating the 75th anniversary of the Margarita at a friend’s bar. But staff shortages and her unparrelled knowledge of Margarita riffs quickly saw her mixing up some Tequila and Lime variations behind that bar, instead of drinking them in front of it.”

If you are after a cocktail with deep rooty and herbal notes, you’ll scream, ‘Jeez Louise’. Created by Chris McMillian at the Revel Cafe & Bar In New Orleans, this is a bittersweet drink highlighted by zesty citrus and subtle carbonation.

Oddly enough the name of this cocktail actually means ‘railway station’ in Italian, but that certainly doesn’t take away from the spiritous and herbal nature of this digestif. With Fernet Branca, Strega and Sweet Vermouth, the Stazione was originally conceived by Alex Frezza.

If you and your friends love long afternoons with a Margarita in one hand, then the Seedlip Margarita provides a more elevated option with the inclusion of Notas de Agave into the mix of Lime Juice and Agave Syrup

Created by Beth Willow at Seaworthy in New Orleans, This & That is a riff on the Penicillin by Sam Ross. While it uses many of the original ingredients (although some in. different quantities) this drink deletes the Single Malt Scotch but adds Peach Liqueur.

A bright green blast from the past, the Midori Sour is fun, fruity and definitely delicious. With Midori, Vodka, Lemon Juice, Lime Juice & Soda Water, this cocktail beautifully combines sweet and sour flavours.

Perfect for alfresco summer dining, the Elderflower Cooler uses Raspberries to add a vibrancy of both colour as well as flavour to any gathering. Easy to make, with the crisp additions of Gin, Lemon Juice and Mint, this cocktail is the perfect summertime tipple.
Nothing shines quite so bright in the cocktail world as a sparkly Gin Twinkle. With Gin, St Germain & Prosecco, this easy drink has a light floral flavour and bubbles for days.
Modestly named, the Improved Scotch Cocktail was created by Kyle Davidson of Blackbird in Chicago, and adds herbal Benedictine and Orange Bitters to a flavorful base of Scotch Whisky and Honey.
Austin Hartman created La Quebrada Spritz at Montana’s Trail House in New York. It is a delicate yet bracing drink inspired by Hartman’s grandfather, who was a cliff-diver in Acapulco.

There’s no better way to while away an afternoon than throwing together a Fig cocktail (especially when you should be doing other things). In Full Fig is appropriate for any occasion and is simple to make by adding Fig Liqueur to Vodka, St Germain, Ginger Liqueur and Agave (we’ve been drinking it most of the afternoon, so totally time well spent).

Similar to a Screwdriver, The Bocce Ball utilises the outstanding pairing of almond and citrus through the Amaretto and Orange Juice to create a tall, refreshing highball that is as easy to make as it is to memorise.

While the cocktail is a riff on a Boulevardier, the name Smells Like Tea Spirit is a delightful pun on the Nirvana song as it uses Indian Whisky brand John Paul’s Nirvana and black tea, in addition to the usual Sweet Vermouth and Campari.

There is an old saying that the Jägerita is the one drink that manages to mix a bartender’s favourite shot into a bartenders favourite cocktail. With Jägermeister, Cointreau, Lime Juice and Sugar Syrup, this will soon become your favourite too.

When cold-brewed Darjeeling Tea is mixed with Bourbon, for the Darjeeling Unlimited, it makes a truly refreshing cocktail. A pinch of salt helps enhance the tea’s savory flavours and when that is mixed with lemon and a little Sugar Syrup, you have the perfect summertime cooler.

As part of a collaboration with Patrón, Heidi’s Black Magic-Rita was created for Heidi Klum’s annual Halloween party in 2023. Utilising the brand’s prestige tequila, Patrón El Alto, the cocktail adds Blackberry Syrup, Fresh Lime Juice and Scrappy’s Fire Water Tincture for a drink that definitely casts a spell.
“In an attempt to fight off the effects of her jetlag, Vanessa finally emerged from her apartment and into the haze of a friend’s pre-Halloween Halloween party. While it may not have had the cache of Heidi Klum’s actually Halloween party, the broken smoke machine was doing its best to mist over that point.”

Although The Franklin in New Orleans has made subtle tweaks to the classic Rosita, swapping smoky tequila for mezcal and Aperol for Campari, the result is a softer take but one with plenty of character.

A pre-dinner aperitif that is light, bitter and bright, Too Soon? was created by Attaboy’s Sam Ross. A mix of Gin, Cynar, Lemon Juice, Simple Syrup and orange slices, this is a drink that will surprise and subsequently delight.

A riff on the classic Whiskey Sour, the Apple Sour Bourbon is a nice fruity twist on the original. Neither too sour or too apple-y, this drink creates a delicate balance with Bourbon, Apple Juice, Cointreau, Lemon Juice & Orange Bitters.

A little bitter, a little fruity but definately delectable, Uno Más is a cocktail that ois as easy to ddrink as it is to make. With Mezcal, Aperol, Agave Syrup, Lime Juice and Guava Purée, this is a drink that will definately have you coming back to the bar.
“Vanessa loved a good bar takeover, so when she heard that one of her favourite bartenders was doing a shift in Singapore, she had to go. Sure, it wasn’t exactly like following a rock band on tour, but she considered that, in this modern age when everyone is famous, she considered it the nearest thing.”

Created by Natasha David, Mountain Man is a riff on a Whiskey Sour utilizing a little peach through Pêche de Vigne, as well as the roundness of Maple Syrup and the spice of a little Ginger Syrup.
“With this latest cocktail consultancy gig now done, Vanessa decided it was the perfect time for both her and her faithful PA, Juan, to escape the heat of the city and enjoy the last of the summer weather upstate. So with a case of Bourbon, a tent and a fishing pole, the pair answered the call of the great outdoors in an effort to discover just how camp they really were.”

Now while technically a Tom Collins, has four ingredients, we’re assuming no-one really counts the Soda Water. So with Gin, Simple Syrup, Lemon Juice & Soda Water, we’re still counting this as a three-ingredient cocktail because it’s easy, delicious and definitely a drink that has endured.

Sometimes a long, clear drink with a grassy, Alpine aroma and a fresh pine finish is the only way to go. If this is the case, then a Pernelle with certainly fit the bill, with Vodka, St Germain, Poire William Eau De Vie, Lemon Juice & Soda Water.

If you are after a boozy Rye Cocktail, there is no more enchanting cocktail than an Enchanted Field. With a nice slug of Strega added to the Rye base, this drink combines Orange Juice & Sugar Syrup, for a drink that is flavoursome and fresh.

Created by Cape Town bartender Leighton Rathbone, the Green Mach III is a riff on a Sidecar with a difference. Sure, it has the Cognac & Cointreau that you would expect. Still, it also incorporates Spanspek (a South African Muskmelon) and a white chocolate rim, which take it into the realm of a Midori Sour and Brandy Alexander, respectively.

If you are after a little ‘hair-of-the-dog …’ that is actually restorative, then you can’t go past Jim Meehan’s cocktail Nurse. While Meehan created this drink with Noilly Prat, we’ve gone with the more fruity yet botanical Cucielo Bianco Vermouth di Torino to accompany the Soda Water and Cucumber wheel.
With bitter notes of gentian balanced with honey syrup, the Clandestine is an aperitif the also contain citrus bergamot and scotch spirit. This cocktail was created in 2017 by Simon Difford.

The Rob Roy is, quite simply, a Scotch Manhattan. The cocktail pairs your favourite Scotch with Sweet Vermouth, allowing the Whisky to shine through. This is one cocktail where your premium Scotch will not go to waste.

Adapted from David A. Embury’s 1948 The Fine Art Of Mixing Drinks, the Club Cocktail is the perfect aperitif. This drink has survived due to its dry and aromatic nature and its mix of Fino Sherry, Tawny Port and Orange Bitters.

Inspired by the myth of Persephone, daughter of Zeus, who was abducted by Hades, king the underworld to be his bride. Queen of the Underworld is a Margarita variation that swaps in a Pomegranate shrub for Triple Sec (or Cointreau).

Delicately spiced and honeyed, the Argha Noah offers a flood of flavour. With blended Caribbean Aged Rum, Honey Syrup, Drambuie Liqueur, Oloroso Sherry and Cranberry Juice, this cocktail is almost biblical in its appeal.

A riff on the classic Cosmopolitan, the Kosmo Kramer uses the expected Vodka but swaps out Raspberry Syrup for Cranberry Juice, Lemon Juice in lieu of the usual Lime, and while it doesn’t give Triple Sec a look in, it does add Ginger Syrup, Aloe Water and Floral Bitters instead.
“As Vanessa watched one of the secretaries from the many office Christmas parties throw up near the bar, she suspected she was in with a chance in tonight’s Bad Behaviour Bingo. All she needed now was An inappropriate word from ‘Santa’ and Drugs in the bathroom, and she would have seen it all …”

If your taste buds are crying out for a smokey-Pineapple Cocktail, then its worth travelling to Scorpion Reef. This wonderful tropical potion combines just enough overproof heat to capture your attention,  while providing your taste buds with that sensation of caramelized pineapple fresh off the grill.

Created by Phillip Jeffrey at GE Club in London, the Zelda was apparently named after a patron who we have to imagine was as beautifully bright and herbaceous as the drink itself. With muddled Mint, Bison Vodka, Lime Juice and Orgeat, what’s not to love …

With a tropical taste but a winter Christmas look, the White Christmas Margarita is a riff that combines traditional Margarita ingredients with a Coconut edge from Coconut Milk and Coconut Rum.
“Vanessa had hoped that by making her favourite Christmas-style Margarita riff for her favourite guest, she would be filled with all the goodwill and promise of the season. But sadly, the first “woohoo” of the evening hit her ears as a large group of women, obviously on a girls’ night out, descended on the bar.”
Created by Giovanni Burdi in London in the ’90s, the Bohemian Mule is a refreshing and herbaceous riff. The Absinthe holds its own with the Lime Juice, Simple Syrup and Ginger Beer.

If you are looking for a Margarita variation that has a certain freshness and aromatic herbal notes, then the Garden Basil Margarita will certainly hit the spot. The crispness of Apple Cider and the aroma of fresh Basil, make this riff a true tribute to spring.

After a long day, there is nothing better than sipping on a spirit-forward cocktail. The Nail In The Coffin is such a drink, as it combines Fernet Branca and Nadeira Wine with Japanese whisky and Licor43.

ingredients: 75ml Volcan de mi Tierra Tequila Cristalino
description: If you like your Martinis dirty, then why not swap out the Gin for Tequila and create a Mexican Martini. Similar to the original but distinctive enough to be intriguing, this drink adds Cointreau and Lime to the Tequila and brine.

Nothing is more refreshing on a hot summer day than a tall glass of iced tea. Now if you mix that iced tea with some Lychees & Simple Syrup (& possibly a little Bourbon if you’re so inclined) then you’ve got a cocktail (either alcoholic or non-alcoholic) that really can’t be beaten.

One of the best known and most widely drunk of the Spritz Cocktails, the Aperol Spritz is an old-school Italian aperitif that defines summer day drinking. With three simple ingredients – Prosecco, Aperol and Soda Water – this is the perfect Italian aperitif.

For a slightly more herbaceous take on our Bee’s Knees theme, than a Bumblebee’s Knees is worth a try. The mix of the herbal Chartreuse and a nice herbal Gin, with Lemon Juice & Honey Syrup will create quite a buzz.

If you want a Mint Julep with a little bit more spice, then you can’t go past a Cinnamon Mint Julep. The strong, sweet and woody flavours of Cinnamon Simple Syrup mix beautifully with Bourbon and the Mint add an additional aromatic element.

It may have a funny name (and yes, our imaginations are making up all sorts of stories) but if you are after something light, then an Umbongo, may be just the ticket. With the pulp of a Passionfruit, Vodka, Passionfruit Liqueur, Orange Juice and finshed with Ginger Ale, this medium sweet, tropical drink it hard to resist.
Combining floral and sour notes, the Lanique Rose Margarita is a beautiful rose-tinted twist on the Mexican classic that mixes Tequila, Lime and Agave with the rose-based liqueur Lanique.

There is something undeniably refreshing about a Cognac Julep. With a mass of crushed ice, Cognac, Sugar Syrup and Mint, it is only a slight variation to a Mint Julep but well worth the deviation. We’ve used Martial Cordon Bleu for this recipe as it’s mellow fruit and spice finish adds a certain flair.

Nothing says summer like the combination of Grapefruit Juice and Rosé that is found in the Rosé Paloma cocktail.  Add to that mix the smokiness of Mezcal, a little Lime Juice and Agave and this wonderful Paloma riff will have you sipping all season long.

If you want a bubbly version of a White Negroni, then a Rib Tickler Spritz is the cocktail for you. St. Germain Elderflower Liqueur lends a floral edge, while Suze preserves the bitter character of the original.

Stylish in its simplicity, the Stone Fence mixes Bourbon with Apple Cider in a highball style of drink. With a long history that dates back to the mid-1800s, not much is known of its history or the derivation of the name.

There is nothing more refreshing than the classic Southern style of a Mint Julep. Known as the signature drink for the Kentucky Derby, it is a simple yet wonderful mix of muddled Mint, Sugar Syrup, crushed ice, and a good dose or two of Bourbon.

If you are looking for a delicate cocktail with a bit of a punch, then the Elder’s Fizz is your perfect summer drink. The St Germain creates the ideal bridge between the floral whisky and the sparkling wine.
Created by Bobby Heugel at Houston bar Refuge, Greenhorn is an easy-to-construct, fruit-forward drink that combines bright-green Midori with the bittersweet Suze and Blanco tequila.

There are a few recipes out there for a Frisco Sour but we’ve used the original here. The drink marries the spiciness of rye with the sweet herbal qualities of Benedictine and then holds it all in check with Lemon Juice.
What’s the dirty little secret of a Dirty Martini? Well, brine, of course! With Gin, Dry Vermouth, Olive Brine & Olives for the garnish, this riff brings a salty, savory note to the classic.

If you want a Hazelnut riff on the classic Black Russian, then a Nutty Russian should be ypour go-to cocktail. To make this work a good shot of Angelico is added to the Vodka and Coffee Liqueur that make up the original.
A fearless riff on a Penicillin cocktail, the Honey Badger mixes up Rosemary, Ginger, Lemon, Honey & Bourbon. Yet, like its namesake, this drink is badass and should never be underestimated.

Although the deep red colour of The Half Bood Prince makes it a perfect Halloween cocktail, the mix of Bourbon, Chambord, Pomegranate Juice, Lemon Juice and a touch of maple Syrups takes the appeal of this drink far beyond magic and mystics.
“Having been sent a rather beautiful bottle of Bourbon by a PR friend, Vanessa decided to get into the Halloween spirit by making herself, and her faithful PA Juan, a rather nice little treat. Unfortunately, Vanessa was to discovered, as she turned into the hall, that Juan had decided to instead go with an arachnid trick.”

Created by Iain Meldrum at the Michael Neave Kitchen & Whisky Bar in Edinburgh, his version of The Dandy is a pale aperitif. The Single Malt Scotch, Suze and Dry Vermouth sit well together creating a drink that is dry and more on the bitter side of bittersweet.

If you are a fan of a good Tequila cocktail, then the Medicina Latina will be a hard drink to resist. Perfect as an after-dinner indulgence, this drink combines Tequila Blanco with a touch of Ginger Syrup and a little more Honey Syrup to even it all up.

With a name that plays on the brand Laphroaig (the Scotch originally used in this drink) and a nod towards the Last Word (another equal parts Cocktail), The Last Laph uses Scotch, Ginger Liqueur, Pineapple Juice, Lemon Juice & a dash or two of Absinthe.

A featured offering at Cachette 1907 Bar during the inaugural New Orleans Cocktail Week, the Southern Gentleman is a riff on a Blueberry Bourbon smash and is, due to the addition of the fall sweetness of Pear Liqueur, just as gentile as its namesake.
“Since Vanessa believed that walking off a plane and straight into a bar was the only way to travel, her friends at New Orleans Cocktail Week were not surprised to see her down a sweet little bourbon number less than an hour after her arrival.”

No matter whether there’s a chill in the air or not, there’s no occasion that isn’t perfect to drink an Alaska. With Gin, Yellow Chatreuse, Fino Sherry and Orange Bitters, this cocktail has an icy flavour that’s as bracing as a glacier.

Created by Anthony Mylott at Margo’s in Santa Monica, California, the Mezcal Avocado Margarita is a riff that offers a creamy texture from the avocado and a good dose of Mezcal.
“While Vanessa found making Margarita riffs all night made her happy, she quickly realised she had forgotten how truly difficult people could be. While she was used to certain guests making passes, she never saw the point in them loudly declaring their drinks should be comped because they ‘know’ the owner.”

If you are after a deeply romantic looking cocktail then I’ll Wait For You is definitely one you shouldn’t wait to make. With Grapefruit-infused Gin, Lillet Rouge and Lambrusco, this drink is lush, dark and bittersweet.

A bit of a riff on the Sidecar Cocktail, the XYZ may be the end of the alphabet but it’s right up front when it comes to Rum based sours. You’ll never regret making this simple but tasty little number with White Rum, Cointreau & Lemon Juice.

Created by Simon Difford at the Cabinet Room in London in 2017, the Mexican in Manhattan swaps nearly everything out but is still a riff on the classic Manhattan. The Rye is replaced with Añejo Tequila, the Sweet Vermouth for Bianco Vermouth, the Angostura Bitters for Lavender Bitters and then a touch of Maraschino Liqueur is added for a little sweetness.

More than the sum of its parts, the Zucca Sour is an extraordinary cocktail that is simple to make but bar-quality to drink. Mixing Rabarbaro’s earthy, herbal character that amplifies the gin, while the Lemon Juice and egg white transform it into a lively sour.

When you can’t decide between Bourbon and Wine, the Rose & Rosé Bourbon takes you to a wonderful middle ground. With Bourbon, Rosé Wine, Rose Syrup, Ruby Grapefruit Juice and a topping of Soda Water, this is a wonderful light and bright drink.

With very much a Jamaica feel, the Street & Fly Special was created by Joseph Schwartz as a homage to the bon vivant lifestyle of Errol Fly and his friend Sam Street when they spent time in the Caribbean. This is reflected through the drinks use of dark Rum, Pimento Dram, Giger Syrup ad Lime Juice.

If you are after a gin cocktail with a truly countryside feel, then you can’t go past the Rhubarb Rebel. Mixing those distinctly earthy flavours of Rhubarb and cloudy apple, this drink heightens the relaxed spritz vibe with the addition of Soda Water and Prosecco.

Sometimes you just need to reach for a drink that’s not only simple but also refreshing. With good quality Cachaça, fresh Lemon Juice and a nice dose of Honey Syrup, the Lemon Beat is just one of those cocktails that will not be beat (especially in the heat).

Can’t decide what to drink? Then why not do a mashup of two cocktails as presented in the White Negroni Daiquiri. Combining Rum, Lillet Blanc, Suze, lemon Juice, Simple Syrup and Orange Bitters, this drink is the best of both worlds.

A twist on the classic Pinã Colada, the Pinã Cholada is made with Toasted Coconut infused Pisco, Coconut Water, Lime Juice, Falernum, and Pineapple Syrup. A true ode to tropical drinks, this cocktail is named after a tiny Thai Restaurant in LA.
To infuse the Pisco, toasted the Coconut in a 350-degree oven for ten minutes, then combine Pisco and Coconut in a large jar. Let sit at room temperature for three days, shaking once a day, then strain through cheesecloth

A sweeter iteration of the classic Cosmopolitan, Not Your Cosmo was created at JJ Dak in New Jersey and uses Dry Curacao in place of Triple Sec and a lime and Cranberry Reduction instead of straight Cranberry Juice.
“While at first Vanessa found the constant stream of Christmas music enchanting, after two weeks of Holly Jolly Christmas and Jingle Bell Rock, she quickly came to the conclusion that all she really wanted for Christmas was a chance to drown her sorrows with a truly Silent Night.”

cocktail_name: Breakfast at the Maison de Martin
description: South African bartender Alecs Besier has combined some of your favourite breakfast staples to create Breakfast At The Maison de Martin. She has mixed butter croissant washed Rémy Martin 1738, with coffee-infused Cointreau and pressed juice, all topped with a rich butter float.

So, you want to keep it simple? There’s nothing simpler or tastier than a Barista Old Fashioned. It has enough Irish Whiskey to make it worthwhile, enough Coffee Liqueur to keep you pleasantly alert and 2 dashes of Angostura Bitters to balance everything out.

My Patrón Perfectionists entry was inspired by sharing a drink with friends. I wanted to create something bright, approachable and refreshing while showcasing the versatility of Patrón Silver – Daniella Darakis – The Gresham

base_spirit: Hickson Rd Wild Rosé Summer Cup
description: A riff on the classic drink the Clover Club, the Hickson ‘Clover’ House, adds a bit more of a kick to mix. Using the Egg White and the Lemon Juice (all be it double the amount) from the original, this drink replaces the gin with Hickson Rd Summer Cup and adds to the Raspberry Syrup by transforming it into a Spiced Ginger and Raspberry Syrup.

If you’ve ever made a Martini, looked at it and thought ‘Why is there not almond in this?’, then we have a Martini variation that will answer that question and so much more. The Dis-a-Tini mixes up enough Vodka, Dry Vermouth and Amaretto to put a twist in your next cocktail hour.

Otro Palabra means Another Word in Spanish, so as you might assume,  this is yet another variation of a Last Word.  This is a milder but still herbal and earthy variation on the classic, using Reposado Tequila instead of Gin and Yellow Chartreuse instead of Green.

The Airmail is a very elegant classic that was first published in 1949, in Esquire Magazine’s Handbook For Hosts. Aged Rum and Brut Champagne are balanced with a little Honey Syrup and Lime, for a drink that’s always a welcome delivery.

If you are looking for a way to elevate your next cosy night in, then a Crown Royal Vanilla Hot Chocolate has all the comfort of a hot chocolate but with the addition of rich crème brûlée and toasted oak flavours of the Crown Royal Vanilla.

Taking inspiration from the classic cocktail the Rusty Nail, Simon Gifford has added fruity and floral elements for his Galvanised Nail. Using the same base of Scotch and Drambuie, he has added St Germain, Apple Juice and Lemon Juice for an uplifting take on the original.
If you like a French 75, then you’ll be completely charmed by the Southern 75. Made with IPA Beer, Bourbon, Lemon Juice & Sugar Syrup, this inventive drink is a must for the craft brew age.

If you’ve been wondering what to do with your old Tom Gin, then this slightly Spirtzy Cocktail will be perfect. The Tom Terrific blends Old Tom Gin, Cherry Heering, Lemon Juice & a good dose of IPA, for a summer sipper that will have you coming back for more.

Playing with Mezcal’s savoury and salty side, Apium is a Margarita riff from the book Mezcal by Emma Janzen. The savoury notes of celery bitters add to the smoke of the Mezcal for a tantalisingly seasonal take on the original.
“To her mind, nothing broke up the tedium of a long shift better than those moments when the brand reps swaggered in. Although she was familiar with the expression, ‘don’t get high on your own supply’, it still surprised her that most reps asked for drinks that didn’t include the liquids they were supposedly selling.”

A simple savoury twist to a White Lady, Like A Lady has all the elegance you’d expect and a bit of a bite from the ground pepper garnish.  With a refreshing flavour from muddled Cucumbers, this drink also incorporates Gin, Suze, Lemon Juice, Egg White and a touch of Simple Syrup

For a nice twist on the Paloma, you’ve got to love the refreshing yet easy cocktail The Snitch. This cocktail merging smoky mezcal with grapefruit shrub (rather than the Paloma’s traditional grapefruit soda) and mixes in a dash of Campari for a slight kick of bitterness.

Throw a little Bourbon, Rye, Campari, Dry Vermouth & Crème de Cacao into a mixing glass and you end up being as the name of. this cocktail suggests, All In. This drink is obviously spiritous, with a little underlying chocolate and a general bittersweet taste.

Long before Sex In The City got hold of it, the Cosmopolitan Cocktail looked a little different than it does today. Back in 1934, the drink utilised Gin, Cointreau, Lemon Juice and Raspberry Syrup for a more well-balanced version than what is often dished up today.

Moving away from heavy tropical drinks, Juyoung Kang at the Fontainebleau Las Vegas created The 9th Island, a light, bright, tropical Mezcal Highball that’s easy to drink. It has hints of roasted agave, pineapple, and spice, all softened by coconut water.
If you want to give your Mule that sweet, tangy edge, there is no better way than with a Tangerine Mule. And nothing goes better with citrus than Bourbon topped with Ginger Beer.
If you’re after the warm hug of a hot chocolate but with a definite boozy yet citrusy edge, then the Orange Hot Chocolate will be the perfect way to spend a lazy Sunday afternoon.

If you can find a gin that uses Bitter Orange Peel as one of the botanicals, then it will blend perfectly with the bittersweet Bergamot of Italicus and make the Gin & It a drink you will mix time and time again

As you might assume from the name, the Black Manhattan is a riff on the classic Manhattan cocktail. In this version, the Bourbon remains, as does the Angostura Bitters and Orange Bitters but the Dry vermouth is swapped out for Averna.

If when you grab a jigger, you want Maraschino Liqueur, Yellow Chartreuse and Grapefruit Bitters to be mellowing and delicately flavouring your Anejo Tequila, then good job, you’ve made an Amatitan Twist.

ingredients: pinch Lavender Rimming Sugar (Pink House Alchemy)
description: Bold, both in colour and flavour, the Vespertini is (as you might expect) a riff on James Bond’s Vesper Martini. This drink is fit for a king with a nice stir of Gin, Blanc Vermouth, Hibiscus Rose Syrup & Lavender Rimming Sugar.

Named after the Mexican dried salted fruit, the Saladito was created by Marco Tello as a riff on Sasha Petraske’s The Business (which in turn is a riff on the Bees Kees). The trick with this drink is to shake the Mezcal, Honey Syrup and Lime Juice mix with a large ice cube, really well. This produces an almost egg white-like foam to which the cayenne pepper and sea salt can adhere.

Originating from the savoy Cocktail Book, the Maiden’s Blush (No. 2) is an enchanting mix of Absinthe and Gin with just a delicate hint of Grenadine. Incredibly simple to make but boozy enough that we hope that someone is seeing the maiden home.

If you’ve ever thought that your chocolate deserved to have more of a peppery, smoky edge, then Cocoa Smoke is the cocktail you’ve been looking for. With Mezcal, Ancho Reyes, Crème de Cacao (White) & a little extra Chocolate Bitters, this drink’s name says it all.

If you love a little rhyming slang with your cocktails, then the Randy is a perfect choice. The verbal link creates a perfect base with the Port and the Brandy, while the Orange and Vanilla flavours dial this drink up to the next level.

If chilli spice smothered by honey with vanilla vodka and a little Lime is the combination of taste sensations you are after, then the Spicy Fifty should be very much on your radar. Created by Salvatore Calabrese, this drink was the signature offering on the first menu of the bar Fifty in London.

The Zucca Highball is a flavoursome variation on a classic highball. The slightly smoky sweetness of Zucca Rabarbaro makes it a perfect match for a blended Scotch, while the Honey Syrup gives a little sweetness and the and the Soda Water lightens everything up.
A riff on the El Presidente, the Cuban Liberal is a sadly forgotten classic. The White Rum is softened by Italia Vermouth but then taken up a notch with the addition of the French Amer Picon Liqueur.

When you think of cocktails made with Limoncello, it’s hard to go past Salvatore Calabrese’s creation Salvatore Meets. Created in 2015, the drink is basically a refreshing, zesty Lemon Daiquiri topped with a splash of Champagne.

If you want to experience the lighter side of the Allspice Pimento Dram, then you can’t go past a Dram Rickey. The combination of Allspice Pimento Dram, Lime Juice and Soda Water makes this drink sweet, spicy and refreshing.
If you are going to call a drink Bitter-Sweet, then including the combination of a bitter red liqueur, Dry Vermouth and Amaretto is incredibly apt, and exactly what you should put in it.

As delicate as it’s colour, the Raspberry Gin Sling is the perfect mix of Raspberries and Juniper.  Ideal for long summer afternoons, this drink is simple, easy and bursting with succulent fruity flavour.

Printed in 2009 in the book Sips & Apps by Kathy Casey, this version of the Montréal cocktail uses Rye, Sweet Vermouth, Pernod Anise and Peychaud’s Bitters for a sweet rye manhattan with French Creole influence.

Approaching Patrón Perfectionists, I really wanted to create a drink that highlighted the delicious caramel, honeyed notes of Patrón Reposado while still providing a delicious umami experience for the drinker. The use of coriander, soy sauce and Patrón Reposado in a drink was an inspiring experience. The Mamacita was a pleasure to create and make and I hope you enjoy – Grace Rawlings – Memphis Slims House Of Blues – Adelaide

Infused tea into a syrup can be one of the easiest ways to add tea’s flavors to a drink and the Scarlot Glow uses Hibiscus Tea, with it’s gentle sweet floral notes to balance the complex mixture of pisco, yellow Chartreuse and grapefruit juice.
“After an amazing week of experimenting with tea flavours, Vanessa felt particularly drawn to the bolder and brighter flavours that the more floral offerings imparted. This resulted in her quite quickly concluding that the flaming red of Hibiscus was definitely her cup of tea.”

After working with Robert Petrie of Bob’s Bitters to make a reproduction of Abbott’s Bitter, Jake Burger created his first Manhattan riff at the Portabello Star in London. The Portabello Star Manhattan has Rye, Dry Vermouth, Sweet vermouth and a dash of Abbott’s Bitters and is a must-try for fans of the classic.

Based on the Rosy Deacon, a classic cocktail from the Stan Jones’ Complete Bar Guide, this drink was reimagined and rounded out by Jim Meehan at PDT in New York around 2009. With Gin, Sloe Gin & Ruby Grapefruit Juice, it is the Absinth wash that gives the drink it’s ‘green’ name.

The combination of Pear and Pimento Dram in an Allsorts Inc is amazing. Add to that Mezcal, Blanco Tequila, Lemon Juice, Falernum & Orange Bitters, for a cocktail that has all the flavour elements from spicy and sour, right through to sweet and fruity.

Simple and clean, the Autumn Fizz is the perfect way to celebrate the change of seasons. Mixing Gin, Lemon Juice, Agave Nectar and crisp Sparkling Apple Cider, this is a drink that gives a gentle nod to the nippy weather ahead.
“Being someone who usually prefers admiring nature from a distance, Vanessa thought she as taking the beginning of their second week of camping in here stride. But no matter how much they were roughing it, she did insist that they at least showed a little civility, and at least dress for cocktail hour.”
This is a Daiquiri that takes no prisoners. Made with Overproof Rum, Green Chartreuse Lime Juice and Falernum, this drink was created by Gregor de Gruyther at LAB bar in London in 2005.

ingredients: 1 bottle Experience Napa Valley Cabernet Sauvignon
