description: The perfect fruity summer beverage, the Classic Sangria is a traditional Spanish wine punch that blends Red Wine, Cognac, and a variety of summer fruits. The trick with a Sangria is time, where the longer the fruits and wine get to know each other before you add the Soda, the better.

Playing up the banana flavour two ways: with Banana-infused Tequila and Tempus Fugit Crème de Banane liqueur, the Banana Hammock offers a tropics-inspired Margarita. Created at Coral Wig in Baltimore, the drink is brightened up with Yuzu Juice and MSG Solution
“During her break, Vanessa had a chance to catch up with one of her favourite guests, a woman who had bartended in New York in the late 80s. The woman was fascinated by the ingredients available and the drinks that Vanessa was able to create. “In my day,” the woman quipped, “if we did anything more complicated than a Vodka Soda, it was a big night”

Inspired by a hot Peruvian summer, The Falso Spitz bring a little of Peru to your glass with a combination of Pisco, Aperol, Grapefruit Juice & Elderflower Tonic Water for a drink that will definitely quench your thirst.

An easy equal parts cocktail, the Spicy Dead Lady intertwines smoky Mezcal, and bittersweet Aperol. The drink is rounded off with the soft, tropical spices of Falernum and the tang of a little Lime but finishes with the heat of Hellfire Bitters.

Combining two of the best tastes of summer, the Sparkling Spiked Peach Lemonade is the perfect batched cocktail if you’re after that allusive hit of summer holiday nostalgia. Using a Vodka base, this drink adds a Peach Puree and Lemon Juice that combine to produce a juicy, sweet drink with a little tang.

Often used to qualify women as seductive or ‘dangerous’, the name Pantera Rosa actually mean Pink Panther (yes, as in the films /animated series).In cocktail terms though, it describes a fresh, vibrant and fruity drink with Gin, Raspberries, Limoncello, Lemon Juice and Simple Syrup

Probably one of the best known punches, the Fish House Punch is a classic, dating back to the early 19th Century. Dry, a little sour and with an underlying fruit flavour, this drink combines Cognac, Golden Rum and Peach Brandy.
“Although Vanessa still wasn’t convinced by her manager’s idea to add a selection of peach cocktails to the menu, one advantage she could see in that change was that it gave her the opportunity to push one of her favourite classic punch cocktails.”

Highlighting the characteristics of raw liquor, the Albino Old Fashioned is made on a base on White Whisky. Muddled Grapefruit is added for its tangy quality, as are muddled Brandied Cherries for their complexity and of course a dash or two of Angostura Bitters are added to balance everything out.
For a flamboyant mix of tart and sweet, you can’t go past a French Martini. Easy to drink and very fruity, this cocktail offers a delightful mix of Vodka, Chambord & Pineapple Juice.

You can’t do Wimbledon without Strawberries and cream, so the Wimbledon Martini allows you to embrace Strawberries in liquid form. Created in the 90s, this Rum based cocktail incorporates fresh Strawberries, Strawberry Liqueur and, of course, a little cream.

Bring on the sun, the summer, the heat … and then you’ll have the perfect conditions for this refreshing little beauty. A Grapefruit Julep is a mix of Vodka, Grapefruit Juice, Grenadine, Honey, Mint Leaves & Lime Juice and utterly tasty.

Well, now it comes down to it, as we explore the Devil’s Soul, which is as you might expect is spiritous, smoky, earthy, bittersweet, floral, and understandably complex. While some may describe this drink as short and evil, the combination of Rye, Aperol, Averna, Mezcal & St Germain is really just what we need today.

The Esplanade Mezcal Swizzle proves that not all Swizzles need to be made with rum. This drink, as the name suggests, mixes the earthiness of Mezcal, with the nuttiness of Sherry for a tasty riff on this tropical, summer classic.
“While Vanessa was putting the final subtle but somewhat suave touches on the new cocktail menu, Juan (her faithful PA), was contemplating his new Louis Vuitton-inspired mantra … WPWT? (Would Pharrell Wear This?) While he had no intention of outshining Vanessa on opening night, he did intend to create a bit of a social media stir (or was that perhaps a social media swizzle?)”

The Trinidad Sour may not be a drink that is quite to everyone’s tastes – especially with so much Angostura Bitters – but with Orgeat, Lemon Juice & Rye, this concoction created by New York bartender Giuseppe Gonzalez certainly has an allure.

Created at Quill in the Jefferson Hotel, Washington DC, the Red Rover feels a lot like a sophisticated Sangria (minus the fruit salad). With Shiraz Red Wine and Navy Rum, the Black Raspberry Liqueur (Chambord) adds that necessary fruity edge.

Created in 2010 by Fraser Campbell at the Alchemist in Melbourne, the St Croix Sunset is a beautifully coloured little concoction. With Rum, Apricot Brandy, Campari, Orange Juice, Lemon Juice and Vanilla Syrup, this is not only fruity but bittersweet as well.

An Old Fashioned doesn’t always have to be made with Whiskey, and a Black Apple Old Fashioned shows that Jägermeister can be a nice alternative, especially when mixed with a little Apple Brandy and Apple Bitters.

For a spicy and warming on the rocks cocktail, the Old Mill can’t be beat. Peaty Islay Malt & Calvados combine with a good dose of Ginger Wine to create a cocktail that’s ideal for sipping when the temperature drops.

Named after the Ed Sheeran song, The Hills Of Aberfeldy is a stunning twist on a highball that is perfect for those moments when you long for the smell of heather. A beautiful mix of Scotch, Benedictine, lemon Juice and Ginger Ale, this drink is easy to drink with a little spice.

Whether you’re making a toast to a winning horse or simply taking a break with friends on a Saturday afternoon, the Woodford Spire is as simple to take as it is to drink. Woodford Reserve’s Kentucky Derby cocktail, the Woodford Spire, is an excellent mix of Bourbon, Cranberry Juice and Lemonade.

If you love a Whiskey Sour, then a Tequila Sour, using 1800 Tequila, is bound to be a hit. Balancing spice flavours with a citrus kick, the cocktail mixes Reposado Tequila, Lemon Juice, Simple Syrup, Orange Bitters & Egg White.

If you’d like your Cognac with some sweet herbal and Ginger notes than a Mon Dernier Mot (My Last Word) is for you. The Cognac melds beautifully with the spicy Ginger Liqueur and the herbal Chartreuse for this nice little riff on the classic.

Due to its colour, you might think the Grasshopper is a 1970s creation, but it was actually first shaken back at the turn of the last century.  A combination of equal parts crème de menthe, crème de cacao, and cream this drink is a perfect minty after-dinner treat.

Bourbon and melon combine in the light and refreshing Melon Splash. The Bourbon pairs wonderfully with the Midori, the Lemon Soda brings it all together and the squeeze of Lime Juice provides just the right amount of tartness.

Appearing originally in Esquire’s Handbook For Hosts (1949 edition), the Poet’s Dream is very much a dream of a cocktail. With Gin, Benedictine, Dry Vermouth & Orange Bitters, this drink has a wonderfully subtle honeyed and herbal flavour.

The name of this drink, Psychopathia Sexualis, will immediately catch your eye and of course demand an explanation. It is based on the controversial German 1886 book of the same name that deals with the psychology of deviant sexual behaviour. With Gin, Sherry, Dry Vermouth, Sweet Vermouth & Orange Bitters, this is a drink that doesn’t require any masochism but hey, if sadism is your bent and you want to bring some into the preparation, then you do you …

If you are after a drink that perfectly balances fruit, spice, and everything nice, then Cargo Plane will help you imagine that you are watching the sunset on an island beach. Created by Matheson Reece, for Therapy in Adelaide, this cocktail features Rumbullion! Spiced Rum, Aperol & Banana Liqueur.
Image – Matthew Kroker

Created by Kelsey Ramage of Trash Collective, the Apple Core Sour takes a sustainable approach by using the part of the apple you might normally throw away, and then mixes it with Vodka, Honey, Aquafaba and Lemon Juice.

If you are looking for the perfect Fall cocktail, nothing says ‘falling leaves’ better than a Pumpkin Spice Latte Cocktail. With Kahlua, Vodka, Espresso, Pumpkin Spice Syrup and Milk, this is a nicely boozy way to drink your coffee.
“To Vanessa’s mind nothing extinguished the memory of a long flight better than a good cocktail. Thankfully, here faithful PA Juan, was ready at the apartment with the perfect Fall concoction. After all, don’t all girls just love the taste of Fall?”

No matter where in the world you are or what the weather is doing, there is a comforting simplicity in drinking a cocktail with bright, refreshing flavours that indicate that, yes, the spirit of spring is eternal. Spring Eternal mixes a house-blended Rum, Apple Lemongrass Wine and Aquafaba for a radiant, frothy sour.

Watermelon and Cucumber are the perfect flavour pairing if you are looking for a fresh and invigorating cocktail. Add to that some Gin and Soda Water and you have a watermelon Cucumber Cooler, the cuatro of refreshment.

As long as you can get you hands on Strawberries, any time of year is perfect for a Spring Fling Cocktail. With the fruity depths of Cognac, the herbal slug of Becherovka and the acidity of Lemon Juice, this is a perfect brunch sipper.

A speciality of Miss Emily’s Blue Bee Bar in the Bahamas, the Goombay Smash will take your taste buds to the tropics. This potent Tiki-style drink features Navy Rum, Coconut Rum, Cointreau, Pineapple Juice & Lime Juice.

The Bootsy Collins amps up the colour, flavour and potency of a Tom Collins with the aid of the ruby-hued Lillet Rouge. Add to that Vodka, Lemon Juice and Simple Syrup, and this riff is as funky as its bass guitarist namesake.

Created in 2017 by Tony Conigliaro, the G&T Royale is a classic, summery aperitif gin cocktail. With flavour hints of Vanilla & Orange, this drink mixes Gin with crisp  Tonic Water and enlivening everythiung with a couple of shots  of Champagne.

If you’ve been thinking to yourself that your Manhattan doesn’t have enough mandarin notes, then you’re in luck with Bonaparte’s Manhattan. With Rye, Sweet Vermouth, and Mandarin Liqueur, it is made drier and all the more complex with the addition of Averna.

We’re going back into the cocktail annals for this one, with the Sangaree’s origins dating back to the late 1700s. It takes its name from the Spanish word for blood, Sangre, and this version comprises Old Tom Gin, Sugar Syrup and Tawny Port.
The name gives away the fact that this cocktail is a distant riff on the classic Manhattan. What the name doesn’t indicate is that it has echoes in its taste of another classic the Dark ‘N’ Stormy.

If you love an Italian Spritz, then why not go a little further east for a Metaxa Peach Spritzer. Citrusy, refreshing and just a little bit bitter, this drink is the perfect vehicle in which to try this Greek Brandy-like liquid.
“Vanessa’s manager was delighted they would finally use the Greek Brandy-like liquid that had been sitting on the back-bar. A former bartender had assured him it would be the next big thing, but like so many predictions, it had remained unopened.”

Obviously the Golden Sazerac is a riff on a classic Sazerac, the official cocktail of New Orleans. Created by iconic bartender Giuseppe González, the drink swaps out Rye for Cognac, Simple Syrup for Golden Syrup and ups the bitters ratio.
“Escaping to a mate’s Creole cottage for a riff on the most New Orleans of drinks, Vanessa contemplated that sometimes the simplest changes can have the most impact. A change of location, a change of ingredients, a change of pace had all lead her to see the city through a new lense.”

What happens when Japan meets Italy? Well, a discerning Cocktail that perfectly balances sweet, bitter and savoury of course. Toki Americano has a wonderful, yet unexpected combination of Japanese Whisky, Cocchi Americano, Amaro Nonino & Grapefruit Bitters.

Created at the RedBar Brickell in Miami, Honeymoon Beach demonstrates that there is no more perfect match than White Rum and Raspberries. Simple, clean and refreshing, the drink also incorporates Pineapple Juice, Lime Juice and Sugar Syrup.

For a Negroni variation that takes us south of the border, we have an Ancho Reyes Negroni. In this equal parts drink the Gin is swapped out for Tequila, adds the spicy flavour of Ancho Reyes Liqueur, a little Cynar and the Sweet Vermouth from the original.

The Americano is based on the old 19th-century Italian cocktail the Milano-Torino, which has Campari and Martini Sweet Vermouth. The story goes that when American came over to Italy during Prohibition, they liked to temper the drink with Soda Water and the locals nicknamed this new drink the Americano.

Whether you are coming into spring or experiencing the joys of an Indian Summer, The Duch Connection is a lovely, refreshing twist on a G&T with Genever instead of Gin and beautiful colour from the Lillet Rose and Peychaud’s Bitters

This may seem like a very simple libation but the Highball Mizuwari is a Japanese cocktail that’s all about the Whisky—and the ritual involved. Even before you add the Soda Water, this is a drink that is all about the stirs, so make sure you count them at each stage.

Adapted from a recipe created by John Robinson at The Hive in Arkansas, the Holy Joe Cocktail uses Irish Whiskey, Sweet Vermouth, Apricot Liqueur, and Cynar for a boozy, bittersweet aperitif that is perfect as a nightcap.

This wonderful mix of St Germain, Vodka & Champagne may seem innocent enough, but trust us, when we say that this is one cocktail that definitely has a glint in its eye. The Twinkle cocktail may appear light and airy but be aware that it packs quite a punch.

If you are after an almost mesmerising cocktail then you can’t go past the wonderful flavours of the Hades Cocktail. The wonderful spice of Kraken Rum, is added to the caramel sweet yet slightly bitter finish Averna, then brought together with the bitter-sweet palette of Rosso Vermouth.

Late at night, there is nothing more tempting than the bittersweet and citrusy notes found in a Monte Manhattan. A riff on the classic Manhattan cocktail, this aperitivo has Montenegro, Rye, Bourbon and a dash of Angostura.

Rather spiritous, Archibald’s Last Memory mixes with Rye, Fernet Branca, Benedictine & Maraschino Liqueur. Even though it is intended to be drunk without ice, on-the-rocks does help round out the edges and open the complexity.

With its root in the video game Red Dead Redemption, the cocktail Marston’s Revenge is a drink as nicely complex as the character itself. You won’t need to be too tactical with this drink as it is a mix of Reposado Tequila, Yellow Chartreuse, Lemon Juice and Grapefruit Bitters

It doesn’t take Google Translate to determine that the Ultima Palabra is a riff on the Last Word. With most of the usual suspects, this equal-parts drink, created by Simone de Luca at High Road House Club in London, swaps out Gin for Mezcal and adds a good measure of Pineapple Juice.

If you are after a bold and spicy tequila cocktail with nutty almond undertones and a little sweetness, then the Pink Elephant is your drink. Reminiscent of a Singapore Sling, this drink was created by Leo Robitschek at NoMad London.

Drinking an Irish Car Bomb is probably one of the more preferable ways to let your taste buds explode. With a little Irish Whiskey, a little Bailey’s Irish Cream and a lot of Guinness, it’s not hard to detonate this decadent pleasure.

Who doesn’t love a riff on a riff and that’s exactly what you get with The Bee’s Bodice.Created by Luke Hanson at Dr Inks Curiosities in Exeter (UK) the drink was based on a riff the bar had formally done on the Bee’s Knees. With Lavender-infused Vodka, Suze, Honey Syrup, Lemon Juice and Grapefruit Bitters this drink has a cleansing bitterness amid a honeyed floral flavour.

Adapted from the 1937 menu from Bar Florida in Havana, the Daiquiri No. 4 is a wonderful Daiquiri riff that combines Gold Rum (rather than the usual White Rum) to the mix of Lime Juice and Sugar Syrup, and adds a little Maraschino Liqueur for good measure.

There is something wonderful about the combination of Bourbon and Raspberry Liqueur, especially when you add to that mix Cranberry Juice, Lemon Juice and Sugar Syrup for the slightly sweet, but amazingly fruity balance of a Marquee cocktail
The subtle dark fruit and chocolate tones of Dark Ale combine wonderfully with the spice of Ancho Reyes and the rich, smoky flavours of a good single malt Scotch in the cocktail Beer & Loathing.
The lovely and light Oaza Cocktail blends Becherovka, with Lime Juice and Sugar Syrup. A bit of a riff on the classic Gimlet, this is a truly refreshing drink with a nice little spicy kick.

You may not have thought it, but Apple Juice and Elderflower Liqueur work really well with Canadian Whisky. If you want to test this idea, give an Elder and Wiser cocktail a try, using the oldest continuously produced Canadian whisky, Elder (you know, just so the name makes sense…).

Created by Harry MacElhone of Harry’s New York Bar in Paris, in the 1930s, Between The Sheets is derived from that other classic cocktail, the Sidecar. A boozy mix of  White Rum, Cointreau, Cognac & Lemon Juice, the name is apt if you drink too many.

If you’re gunning for the perfect Irish Cream cocktail than the Smith & Wesson might be the just pull your trigger. With Vodka, Kahlua, Irish Cream & Half & Half, this is a drink that comes in with all guns blazing

One of the few cocktails that can be served both hot and cold, the Pilgrim is a warming mix of Rum, Grand Mariner, Orange & Lime Juices, Pimento Dram & Angostura Bitters. To serve hot, gently simmer ingredients in a saucepan.
What happens when you mix Marker’s Mark Bourbon with Sipsmith Gin? Well, a Marksmith of course. And when you add a little Sweet Vermouth to the mix it’s like a slightly more boozy Manhattan.

If you are after a simplified riff on the classic Mai Tai, then Grand Marnier offers you the Grand Mai Tai. Concentrating on only Jamaican Rum, using Lemon juice instead of lime and Orgeat as the only sweetener, this drink puts Grand Marnier centre stage.

It is believed that Julio Bermejo from Tommy’s restaurant in San Francisco has a legendary knowledge of Tequila. With that knowledge, he created the Tommy’s Margarita, a simple but classic riff on the original that’s made with Agave Syrup but without the traditional Orange Liqueur.

The traditional Bramble has been around since the 1980s but we’ve adapted it a little to make it even fruitier. In our version we’ve swapped out traditional Simple Syrup for a Blackberry Simple Syrup, then added it to the traditional ingredients of Gin, Lemon Juice and Créme De Mûre.

With Grapefruit Vodka and Grapefruit Juice, the Grapefruit Drop is best described as the Grapefruit lovers Cosmopolitan. Refreshing and enlivening with zesty citrus this drink also has Lemon Juice, Triple Sec and Simple Syrup.

If you’re interested in paler version of the traditional Harvard Cocktail, then a Fair Harvard is for you. While the traditional Harvard has Brandy & Sweet Vermouth, the ‘fair’ version is the perfect mix of Pisco, Bianco Vermouth & Orange Bitters.

If you are after the spicy, full-flavoured taste of the South, then you’d better be making a New Orleans Mule. A wonderful combination of Bourbon, Coffee Liqueur, Pineapple Juice, and of course Lime Juice & Ginger Beer, it will have you saying Laissez Les Bons Temps Rouler.

As you might assume from the name, the Tobacco Road cocktail utilises the smoke from Mezcal which it adds to the briny sherry and vegetal Cynar for a drink with a rich Tobacco aroma (with a hint of salt to bring out the flavours).

An agave-based riff on a Moscow Mule, the Minted Mule mixes Silver Tequila, Ginger Beer, Lime Juice and Mezcal to create a more complex version of the original with hints of smoke mixed with ginger flavour and citrus notes.

Who doesn’t love a riff on the Last Word cocktail? This variation, the Other Word, was spotted at the Vanish in Los Angeles and puts together a nice mix of Mezcal, Yellow Chartreuse, Agave Syrup, Maraschino Liqueur and Lime Juice.

It doesn’t take a saint to want to be stranded with this sweet little tropical drink. The Shipwreck Saint offers an infusion of Rooibos Tea into White Rum and another of Cocoa nibs into Triple Sec that add a new dimension to the typical Spiced Rum, Demerara Syrups, Lime Juice and Pineapple Juice.
“With all the fervor surrounding South Africa winning the Ruby World Cup, Vanessa was strangely drawn to the Rooibos Tea. Although normally she found it far too sweet, she did rationalise that the tea’s nuttiness infused it into a tropical-style drink would, like the Springbok’s win, provide a flavourful, yet nail biting finish.”

Toffee AND Coffee? Yes please! Creamy Toffee meets the indulgent Salted Caramel Flävar in the Sticky Toffee Espresso Martini. This drink is a flavour sensation, hands down and a delicious twist on the Dick Bradsell classic.

If you are going to drink, then who wouldn’t want to drink like Clint Eastwood? This Manhattan variation is made using Bourbon, a little Sweet Vermouth, and a few dashes of Orange Bitters for a cute little variation on the classic.

The easiest way to think of the  Jalisco Pear Cocktail is as an Autumn Margarita. The natural pairing of Pear Liqueur & Pimento Dram is a classic combination and when mixed in with Tequila & Lemon Juice, the result is just begging you to curl up with it by the fire.

A perfect summer aperitif, this fruity and light cocktail is as easy to make as it is to drink. Truly, there is nothing complicated here, so much so that the ingredients are all in the name (Chambord, Vodka, Lemonade). Tres easy! Tres chic!

A beachy play on the classic, this Negroni riff features soft Lillet Blanc in the place of traditional vermouth, with a hint of grapefruit bitters to round out the package. It’s the perfect Negroni for channeling warm summer vibes.

When Richard Boccato and Michael McIlroy worked together at Little Branch in New York City they collaborated to create an American Trilogy. This riff on the Old-Fashioned mixes Brown Sugar with a ‘half-rye & half-Applejack’ backbone to shift the classic into a slightly darker place.

If you are looking for a cocktail with a rich Blackberry flavour and a stronger Ginger finish, then you can’t go past this little beauty which really is Berry Nice. With Blackberries, Vodka, Chambord, Lemon Juice and Ginger Beer, this is both refreshing and super flavoursome.

If you love a Margarita but somehow feel that they generally need a bit more oomph, then a Ginger Margarita might just be the drink you’ve been waiting for. With Tequila, Lime Juice and Ginger Liqueur, this is a lovely spiced twist on the original.

The Japanese Maple is the perfect sour cocktail to start the night right. Simply add a little Lemon Juice, to the Japanese Whisky and balance everything out with Maple Syrup and Egg White, for a perfect, tasty libation.

If you love a Paloma (and realistically, who doesn’t), then why not make it brim with the colour of Plum Liqueur. The Plum Paloma, created by La Contenta in New York, combines Tequila or Mezcal and the usual Lime Juice but adds a little Plum Liqueur for a colour we all love.

An infinitely drinkable cocktail, the Wink is a seductive little libation that tempts you with every sip. Reminiscent of a Sazerac but with Gin and Cointreau, this cocktail has an Absinthe wash that sets the stage for this delicate yet fruity concoction.

In bar speak, a boomerang is a drink sent from one bartender to another via a trusted intermediary. Longtime baijiu-bartender Paul Mathew unveiled the Bittersweet Boomerang (with Baijiu, Yellow Chartreuse, Creme De Cacao & Cynar) at the 2017 Tales of the Cocktails as a special gift to the bartenders in attendance.

This drink comes from Ted Saucier’s 1951 book, Bottom’s Up & is basically, a Vodka Mojito.  Served straight up, Hi Ladies is a tasty mix of Vodka, Lime Juice, Sugar Syrup & just that little bit of muddled Mint.

If you like your citrus on the tarty side and lots of it, then a Kumquats, Lemongrass & Rum is a drink that certainly won’t disappoint. With Kumquat Juice, Kumquat-lemongrass Syrup and Rum, this drink has a perfectly balanced zing.

Created at NYC’s legendary Milk & Honey, the Greenpoint is a riff on the Brooklyn, which is, of course, a riff on the classic Manhattan. With Rye, Yellow Chartreuse, Sweet Vermouth, Angostura Bitters & Orange Bitters, this is a nice boozy, yet slightly herbal variation.

In 1824, Dr Johann Siegert produced his first aromatic bitters in Angostura, Venezuela. One hundred and ninety-four years later, Siegert’s Sparkling Cocktail with Amaro di Angostura, Earl Grey Tea Syrup, Lemon Juice & Tonic Water pays homage to the man.

Designed to bring out the bright grain flavours in Irish Whiskey, The Declaration was created by Ezra Star at Drink in Boston. The cocktail adds Dry Vermouth to stretch out the Whiskey and Lemon Juice to give the drink more life.
A Vermouth-based riff on the classic Army & Navy Cocktail. Army, Navy & The Marines keeps the Gin, Lemon Juice and Orgeat of the original but adds a Dry Vermouth and a pinch of Salt.

Tasting a little like a boozy Cherry Soda, you can’t go past a Cherry Smash if you’re after a a sweet little cocktail. The muddled Cherries really make this drinks the luscious Cherry Heering flavour mixes with the Bourbon.

Ayurvedic Tea from The Organic Tea project is wonderful herbal blend made with Cardamom and Chamomile. We have used the tea to create a simple syrup that pairs beautifully in this sour with a blanco Tequila.

Whether you look at this as a Mezcal cocktail, an equal parts cocktail, three-ingredient cocktail or simply as a Negroni riff, the Mezcal Negroni is the perfect modern cocktail, as Mezcal can easily stand up to the strong personalities of both Vermouth and Campari.

Created by Steve Dragun at Lucy’s Lounge in Brooklyn, the Far East Peach is a perfectly balanced equal parts cocktail. With Yuzu as the star, this drink also combines Rye Whiskey, Mezcal & Crème de Pêche.
Created by Rool Buckley at Café Lebowitz in New York in 2003, the Riviera Breeze is a summertime cooler that combines the wonderful flavours of aniseed and citrus to really live up to its name.

Dry and delicate, this modern version of the classic Bamboo Cocktail was adapted by Joaquín Simó in New York. Mixing Fino Sherry, Dry Vermouth, Sugar Syrup, Angostura Bitters and Orange Bitters, this dry is also aromatic and complex.

To balance the use of Overproof Rum in his Tai Du Mai, a riff on a classic Mai Tai, Erik Hakkinen at Roquette in Seattle added Cognac instead of dark rum, as well as a little Pineapple Syrup to the usual Lime, Orgeat and Triple Sec

Like the Julep, smashes have come to include all sorts of fruit, and this one showcases sweet, ripe strawberries. Muddle those Strawberries with a good dose of Gin, and a little Sugar Syrup, Lime, Strawberry Shrub and a topping of Soda Water.
Created by Sam Ross in 2004 at Milk and Honey in New York City, the Old Maid has an English garden party attitude. With Gin, lime, mint, and cucumber. this drink zings with freshness.

The name Santa Cruz Sour was often used in the oldest cocktail book to reference a Rum Sour, so it’s not surprising that Bar By Rhys chose it for its Rum Sour riff. Providing a nice touch of Tiki, the drink mixes the bar’s house-blend Rum, Pineapple Juice, Ginger Cordial, Sour Mix & Aquafaba.

To some a Smoky Martini, is considered one of the best of the variations. Traditionally (and this is the version we drink), the cocktail builds on the classic Martini with Gin & Vermouth but adds an amazing smokey flavour with peated Scotch.

Now if you’re going to grab a bottle of Cointreau, it seems only sensible to make a Cointreau Cocktail. A nice bittersweet concoction, this drink mixes Cointreau (obviously) with Sweet Vermouth (we’ve used Punt e Mes) and a few dashes of Aromatic Bitters.

When it comes to Blackberry Cocktails, there’s nothing more special than the drink an Especial Day. With muddled Blackberries, White Rum, Sweet Vermouth, Créme De Mûre, Pineapple Juice & Peychards Bitters, the colour and flavour of this drink is beyond par.

You’ve got to love the Aperitif love, especially when it’s for Lillet Rouge. So grab a little Lillet and mix it with Gin, Clemintine Juice, Lime Juice and Angostura Bitters to create the drink, Lillet, My Love.

With it’s smokey flavour and citrus undertones, the Earl Grey Cider Cocktail has a true Autumnal feel. When added to the Bourbon, Lemon Juice and Apple Cider, the Earl Grey Tea highlights the complexity and depth that Tea can bring to cocktails.

If you’ve ever wondered about what a creamier spin on the Aperol Spritz would be like, then Cotagna’s Aperol Fizz is well worth a try. With Aperol, Lemon Juice, Sugar Syrup, Egg White and Soda Water, this frothy twist was created by Jason “Buffalo” LoGrasso of Cotogna in San Francisco.
While you may not immediately think of cantaloupes in cocktails, their soft sweetness can work beautifully, as is shown by the fruity and aromatic mix in the ginn-based drink, the Cantaloupe Smash

Sitting proudly within the tiny cocktail movement, the Three Gulps Martini was fashioned by London bar, Tayēr + Elementary. A four to one ration martini, this drink incorporates Vodka, Vermouth di Torrino, and Sherry.

A riff on the modern classic, the Debonair, the Elegente is as stylish as its name. Created by Robert Simonson and published in his book, Tequila & Mezcal Cocktails, this drink replaces Scotch with Mezcal and adds a good belt of Ginger Liqueur for a little zing.

Created by Simon Difford in 2006, the Sidecarriage is a wonderfully light and tasty riff on the Sidecar Cocktail. With the Lemon Juice of the original, there are also hints of cider that comes through the Calvados Brandy and a nice little twist from the Elderflower Liqueur.

If you want an Amaro-based variation on the Highball, then the A.L.O could be the cocktail for you. Mixing Amaro di Angostura, with Angostura Bitter, Lemon-Lime Soda and a dash of Orange Bitters, this mix up is pure Angostura perfection.

With a thick, syrupy texture and a rich, fruity flavour, Paradise #3 should really be your #1. The Gin & Apricot Brandy Liqueur plays nicely with the Passionfruit and neither are overwhelmed by the Orange Juice.

The most classic, and some might even say the best, of all the sours, is the Whiskey Sour. It’s all about balance, so even if you don’t usually like Whiskey, the combination of  Bourbon, Sugar Syrup & Lemon Juice, just can’t be beat – it’s a classic for a reason.

With a classically-inspired approach, Plain Sailing is a stirred cocktail created by Paige Walwyn in Chicago, which presents a straightforward mixture of Gin, Blanc Vermouth, Manzanilla Sherry and Sloe Gin.

If you’re looking for a plain old Negroni, then, of course, you’ll mix Gin, Campari and Dry Vermouth but if you want something a little different, why not add Aprés Tea (Lemongrass, Liquorice & Lemon Verbena) and create the very tasty Aprés Negroni.

Tasty, foamy, and refreshing, Konrad Kantor of New Orleans’ Manolito has created the Amaretto Sour Frappé which is, as expected, a riff on an Amaretto Sour with a splash of Pineapple Juice blended into the mix.

If you are after a laid-back, fresh-from-the-garden drink, you won’t go wrong with trying the Rhubarb and Grapefruit Collins. With Rhubarb Gin, Ruby Grapefruit Juice, Honey Syrup & Soda Water, this long, effervescent drink has a certain classic minimalism.

There are a few different Afterburner cocktails around but the one that we are doing today is a simple but effective mix of Coffee Liqueur, white Overproof Rum and White Créme De Menthe which creates a smooth, peppermint-laced coffee drink.

Why stop with decorating your altar with sugar skulls when you can decorate your cocktail with sweetness, too? The Boxcart features lightly aged Patrón Reposado, Citrónge Orange, Lemon Juice, Simple Syrup and the addition of a little extra sweetness with a sugar rim.

It’s well known that author Normal Mailer is very much a pre-writing drinker. His smokey Martini-style creation, the Berlin Station Chief with Gin and Single Malt Scotch first appeared in his 1991 novel, Harlot’s Ghost.

If you want a fun and delicious drink that’s a bit more under the radar than a Margarita or a Paloma, you should try a Mexican Firing Squad. The Grenadine adds only a little sweetness and you can also top with a little Soda Water if you want to create a longer, cooling drink.

Sweet and graceful, the Honey Rose Margarita is a great riff on the classic. With the Tequila and Cointreau that you would expect, the drink swaps out the Lime Juice and replaces it with Lemon and adds a delicate floral edge with Honey Syrup and Rose Water.

The Berry Barracuda has, as you might assume, a bit of a bite. That, of course, comes from the Age Balsamic Vinegar. But it’s the combination of Whiskey and Strawberries that makes this cocktail stand out. Really it’s a combination of unusual flavours that works like a dream.

Drinking Tequila is a bit of club and now that’s official with the Tequila Club Cocktail. A riff on the Pega Club, this drink has Tequila, Dry Orange Curaçao, Lime Juice, Lavender Bitters and Angostura Bitters and yes, has a bit of a Margarita feel as well.

“Recuerdo,” the Spanish word for “memory,” and remembering loved ones is essentially what Día de Muertos celebrations are all about. Featuring the light oakiness of Patrón Reposado complemented by brown sugar, citrus, and egg whites, this is a cocktail you’ll want to remember.

While the average spicy Margarita can be a bit of a cliché, it really is a flavour combination that works. But if you’re after a bit of an alternative take, then the Mexican Razor Blade is a variation that’s anything but average.

If you are poolside this summer, then a Guava Daiquiri is the perfect drink to have in your hand. light, refreshing and summery, Guava Juice makes the perfect addition to the Rum, Cointreau and Lime of the original.

Pink Gin started as a medical cure, when sailors in the Royal Navy were given Angostura Bitters as an antidote for seasickness. Of course the Angostura tasted nicer when mix with a little Gin and bartenders, the Schofield Bros. have made it better with a little sweetness & Peychaurd’s Bitters.

If you like a Manhattan but ever wondered what it would be like if it was slightly fruitier than making an IVO Cocktail is a must. Simply swap out the Sweet Vermouth for Dry, add it to the Bourbon and Angostura Bitters and throw in a little Chambord.

While tea is often steeped when used in a cocktail, this Japan-inspired drink from bartender and distiller Allen Katz, sees matcha powder added directly. As well as the Matcha, 14 Hours Ahead incorporates Gin, Lemon Juice, Lime Juice, Honey Syrup and heavy cream.
“After taking some of the teas back to a friend’s bar, Vanessa decided to add a little Matcha to the mix, as she had always wanted to go to Tokyo. And while Japanese bartenders would be horrified at her lack of precision, she reasoned that since they were 14 hours ahead, whatever messy experiements she did now, would already be perfected in their timezone.”

Named for the bluegrass that grows in Bourbon country, the Bluegrass cocktail was created by Hayden Lambert at Merchant Hotel in Belfast. Embracing the Cucumber, Bourbon and the bittersweet orange of Aperol, the drink also has Simple Syrup as well as both Orange and Angostura Bitters.
With Bourbon, Raspberries, Crème de framboise, Lemon Juice, Simple Syrup & Soda Water, the Mrs Robinson (No.1) is definitely a cocktail that is trying to seduce you.

Nothing brings the sun as much as the inclusion of a little Passionfruit in your cocktail. With Gin, St Germain, Passionfruit Juice, Lime Juice, Sugar Syrup and a dash of Orange Bitters, the Sun Fruit Cocktail is the perfect drink to celebrate the summer.

If you are looking for a refreshing beer cocktail that’s an alternative to drinking straight beer then the Czechmate has day-drinking written all over it. The Becherovka blends harmoniously with a Pilsner and they are both strengthened by the Vodka and Lemon Juice.

Created by San Francisco bartender Cynthia Tran, Tropic Like It’s Hot is a light and refreshing rum cocktail that utilises yellow Chartreuse, Lime Juice and the aromatics of Pineapple Sage infused Aperol.

Simple, bubbly and refreshing, Frankly My Dear is easy to make and offers a bubbly, refreshing, fruity sip that features Peach Puree as well as Tequila, Cointreau and Lemon Juice, all topped with Prosecco.
“Although she was aware that Peach Fuzz was the Pantone colour of 2024, even a Peach & Prosecco cocktail could not convince Vanessa that peach should be used in every cocktail on the new menu.”

A wonderful combination of Rum and Apple flavours, the Puerto Apple is definitely a drink that should be on your must-try list. With White Rum, Applejack, Lime Juice & Orgeat, the apple flavour peaks through in this fruity, flavoursome concoction.

First created in New York by Brian Miller at the Pegu Club, the 19th Century. A Bourbon-based variation on the 20th Century cocktail, this drink also has White Creme de Cacao, Lillet Rouge and Lemon Juice.
A lovely low-alcohol twist on the classic London Calling, this drink mixes gin, Fino Sherry and Soda Water for a refreshing after-dinner drink or all-day sipper.

Working with Seedlip’s tagline for Notas de Agave, the Seedlip Paloma presents all the bright, zesty flavours that you would expect from a Paloma, but by adding this non-alc spirit, you’re choosing differently.

Simone de Beauvoir was entranced by Apricot cocktails. They were to her (and her fellow existentialists – yes, Jean-Paul Sartre we’re looking at you) a key to understanding phenomenology: it exists to be enjoyed and it existed because it was enjoyed. For us, The Woman Destroyed is just a drink with Scotch, Sweet Vermouth, Apricot Liqueur and Cynar (but yes, it was enjoyed).

The Mexican marigold flower, known as cempasuchil, is traditionally used to decorate Día de Muertos altars, and, in the case of the Marigold Mule, it makes its appearance in the form of a garnish alongside, Patrón Silver, St. Germain, fresh lime juice, and ginger beer.

Perfect for a hot summer night, the Lychee Lime Fizz is light with the subtle taste of Lychee. Start by muddling Mint Leaves and Lychees in Lime Juice & Honey Syrup before adding Vodka then top with Soda water, for a perfect drink to beat the heat.

No one knows who invented the Alabama Slammer, but legend has it that this cocktail was first shaken at the University of Alabama in 1975. The sweet mix of Southern Comfort, Sloe Gin, Amaretto and Orange Juice is supposedly the signature drink of the Alabama Crimson Tide football team.

If you are looking for a perfect spirit to pair with Italicus, then you really can’t go past the addition of Gin. Add to that the citrusy aromatics of Lemon Juice and the silky texture of Egg White and Simple Syrup, you have a perfect drink in the form of a Gin & Italicus Sour.
There’s nothing like a bit of Mint Tea and Gold Rum to get your party started right. With added Lime Juice, Sugar Syrup & Mint, this Daiquari-style long drink is the perfect summer cooler.

Based on the traditional Irish Coffee, The Blizzard Cocktail adds a bit of Hazelnut flavour and a good dose of Irish Cream Liqueur to the mix, which makes it the perfect way to either start or end St Patrick’s Day.

Mamie Taylor was a famous opera singer around the turn of the 20th century and one story goes that a Rochester, New York bartender created this drink at her request sometime around 1899. This tall cooler is a simple three-ingredient cocktail, that blends Scotch, Lime Juice and is topped with Ginger Beer.

If you are after a slightly more complex, yet beautifully herbaceous Martini-style cocktail, then The Frank O’Hara is a great place to start. But don’t be mislead by the simplicity of this drink, as the botanicals in both the Gin & the Strega blend harmoniously.

If you love a Negroni but are after something a little less robust than Sweet Vermouth, then give a Lillet Negroni a try. With Gin, Campari & Lillet Rose, this is the perfect summertime variation on the classic.

There’s definitely nothing suburban about the Subourbon Cocktail. With Blackberries, Bourbon, Sweet Vermouth, Cranberry Juice and Angostura Bitters, this fruity, long, Bourbon laced drink is ideal for balmy summer nights with the neighbours.

If you love a traditional Whisky Highball but regret that they’re not more tropical, then Tony Roehr at Noble Experiment in San Diego has answered your call. With the Aperol and Passionfruit Syrup you’ve been missing, the Tropical Popsicle has a fun, tropical vibe.
Replacing both the Vodka and Triple Sec with Rosé Port gives the Rosé Port Cosmopolitan an added depth and flavour that allows the drink to remain balanced, quaffable and incredibly easy to make.
Toss your G&T aside, we’re submerging ourselves in vibrant ’70s colours with an M&T. “M&T?”, you ask. Well, obviously it’s a Midori and Tonic Water with the added citrus hit of a little Lemon wedge.

The easiest drink you could ever make, a Slane & Ginger is essential for any Irish whiskey lover’s drink menu. This refreshing highball is nothing more than a shot of Irish whiskey topped with ginger ale and a squeeze of Lime Juice but none the less, perfection.

If you love a little coffee flavour then the Kraken Espresso might make a welcome change from the usual. With the spice of Kraken Rum, the almond-y taste of Amaretto, a little Vodka and finishing with a good jolt of Espresso, you’ll be surprised at how well they work together.

With the Añejo Smash, you discover what happens when the Margarita grows up. With Añejo Tequila, Grand Marnier, Agave Syrup, fresh Mint and lemon wedges, this is a cocktail that demonstrates what happens when aged Tequila gets a splash of minty freshness.
Created by Will Ballantine at Wild by Tart in London, the Brasil is a lovely mix of citrus and herbaceous flavours, with Cachaça, Lemon Juice, Yellow Chartreuse & Simple Syrup

Cucumber and Basil are truly a winning combination and they work really beautifully in the light, refreshing Cucumber & Basil Smash. Simply muddle Cucumber, Basil, and Simple Syrup before adding the Gin & Lemon Juice.

ingredients: 60ml Hickson Rd Wild Rosé Summer Cup
base_spirit: Hickson Rd Wild Rosé Summer Cup
description:
The English may have invented the Summer Cup (a traditional, flavour-packed summer punch), but it seems it took the Australians to perfect it. Using a mixture of the newly released Hickson Rd Wild Rosé Summer Cup and Ginger Ale, the Hickson Rd Summer Cup Cocktail helps to cool everything down as you breathe in the summer heat.
Image and recipe kindly provided by Hickson House Distilling, Sydney

Fresh, crisp apples makes this wonderful riff on a Gin & Tonic ideal for Autumn afternoon sipping. Designed specifically to be made with Caorunn Gin, due to the spirits natural affinity with red apple yet, at a pinch, this cocktail can really be made with any strong botanical Gin.

Very much a showstopper, the Rhubarb Sour is a delight of a drink. With the taste of Rhubarb breaking through the sherbert-like flavour of the lemon and sugar, the drink is smoothed out by the egg white and grounded by the Angostura Bitters.

Inspired by the classic Army & Navy cocktail, the Strawberry Bearcat was created by John Ploeser at Brooklyn’s Featherweight. With a definite nod to Tiki, this drink is made with gin, orgeat syrup, lemon juice and muddled strawberries.

One of the joys of Equal Parts Cocktails is that they are a breeze to measure and mix. With a delightful mix of Brandy, unsweetened Cranberry Juice, Simple Syrup & Lime Juice, the Cran-Brandy Cobber is just such an easy cocktail.

Have you always loved the idea of a Cosmopolitan but wished it didn’t have Cranberry Juice? Swap it out now for Aperol and you have an Aperol Cosmpolitan that’s a little bit more grown-up but with the same tart bite.

Built on a split-base of Tequila and Mezcal, the Mezcal Sun-Risa, created by Ignacio “Nacho” Jimenez at Ghost Donkey, is lengthened by Orange Juice, Bitter Orange Juice and topped with spicy Hibiscus-Habanero Syrup

Standing for Benedictine and Brandy, the B&B Cocktail is a simple mixing of two spirits. One of the best classic cocktails, it is an icon of sophisticated drinking and makes an ideal after-dinner drink or nightcap.

Blackberries are a good way to incorporate a summer vibe in your cocktails and a simple version is the Blackberry Tonic. A wonderful combination of a semi-sweet Vermouth, with Crème De Mûre and Tonic, will soon have you forgetting your G&T’s.
Created by Shannon Tebay at Death & Co, the Sundial is a frothy, rich and complex Cognac cocktail with Cherry Eau de Vie, Orgeat and small doses of Elderflower Liqueur and Amaro.

Created by the 2016 patrón Margarita Of The Year finalist from Dallas Stephen Halpin, the Smoked Mangonada Margarita features bright citrusy and fruity flavours complemented by just the right amount of smokiness.
“Picking up another shift at a recently opened rooftop bar, Vanessa was enjoying her time back behind the stick. Like the view it offered, this bar was a little loftier than the usual haunts that she used to work, so it didn’t take long for her to realise that you could tell as much about a venue from the bottles it kept its well, as you could from the menu or the guests.”

Created in the 1930s at a Bermudian nightclub of the same name, the Ace Of Clubs is a wonderful classic to drink while you’re playing cards. This rich Daiquiri riff, prepared uses Aged Rum, Lime Juice and with the lush flavour of Crème de Cacao.

When a Bamboo Cocktail and a Vodka Martini love each other very much, the result is Well Fortified. With Moscatel, Vodka, Dry Vermouth, Fino Sherry & Bison Grass Vodka, this boozy, aromatic aperitif combines a trio of fortified wines.

Found in the late Gary Regan’s book Negroni, The Stiletta is an exercise in flavour combinations.  Created by Phil Ward, the drink combines Star Anise infuse Campari with Sweet Vermouth and Blanco Tequila.
For a sweet little cross-continental journey, why not join us for a little drink we created called Rome Via Tokyo, where Sake and Limoncello show that travel can open a world of flavours

Created at Trick Dog in San Francisco in 2013, the Polar Bear is a riff on the classic Stinger Cocktail. While Mezcal and Créme de Menthe may not seem like natural allies, with. a little Blanc Vermouth and Angelica Tincture (which can be swapped out for Celery Bitters) this drink just works.
As the snake from the Garden Of Eden would tell you, no harm ever came from a little Original Sin. Of course, he wasn’t creating it with Vodka, Sake and Honey Syrup but luckily you can …

There was never such a set of distinguished writers than those that sat around the Algonquin Round Table. Although they mainly drank Martinis, they also indulged in the hotel’s namesake drink with Rye, Dry Vermouth, Pineapple Juice and Honey Syrup.

If you are after a Martini-style cocktail that has a little bit of sweetness through the addition of Old Tom Gin and Benedictine D.O.M Liqueur, then the Ford Cocktail might just be ideal. Yet keep in mind it is the addition of Orange Bitters and the Orange zest that truly make this drink.

With fresh herbal notes, the Gold Metal is a light, modern, citrusy cocktail. With Reposado Tequila, Yellow Chartreuse, Lemon Juice and Maraschino Liqueur, this is a drink that certainly goes for the win.

For a truly sunny sipper, you can’t go past the bright yellow look of a Sunflower Cocktail. After a Absinthe rinse, add Gin, Elderflower Liqueur, Lemon Juice & Orange Liqueur in equal parts, for a drink that will really brighten up your day.

Created by Ivy Mix from Brooklyns Leyenda, the En Cuarto is an equal parts cocktail with a Latin edge. With a name meaning “in fourths” or “in quarters”, this drink is a variant of a Martini with Pisco, Gin, Dry Vermouth and Sweet Vermouth.

With the Pompier cocktails as his entry, it’s easy to say that children’s author, essayist, and Pulitzer Prize winner E. B. White is still the authority on The Elements of Style. This refreshing, low-alcohol highball with Vermouth, Créme de Cassis and Soda Water, will clear the proverbial cobwebs and put a little spritz in your step.

With the Lilikoi Sunset, Mauro Hernandez at Strong Water in Anaheim has created a Daiquiri riff that is a passionfruit version of the original. Leaning into the tropical nature of the drink, this riff uses Passionfruit Syrup and a touch of funk with Jamaican Rum.

The Grand Sidecar is the signature classic for Grand Marnier cocktails recipes. Truly refreshing and perfectly balanced, the Grand Sidecar effortlessly marries the citrus notes of Cordon Rouge’s bitter orange liqueur with the intensity of Cognac.

Are there any words in the English language better than Bittersweet and Bubbly, especially when used together to describe a Montenegro Spritz. And it really couldn’t be easier, as all you need is Montenegro & Prosecco to make this drink an occasion.

Rum and coffee are natural bedfellows, so work together beautifully in the El Cafecito. With Dark Rum, Coffee Liqueur, Licor 43, Simple Syrup & Chocolate Bitters, this is a tasty drink that is the perfect way to end the night.

Defying its name, the Black Rock Chiller is a perfect example of the trend for serving room-temperature cocktails. It mixes a big, sweet, menthol hit of Fernet Branca, with the wonderfully herbal quality of Añejo Tequila and bitter Suze.

If you are feeling a little brash, then you can’t go past a Cheeky Negroni. Fragrant & beautifully balanced, this drink retains the simplicity of the original, with equal parts Aperol, Lillet Blanc & Hendricks Gin

A riff on a Rum Negroni, Little Cuba blends flavours of chocolate and raisin with a delicate herbal spice. Created by Lisa Kempen at Deadshot in Auckland, this drink stirs Cacao & Coffee Spiced Rum with Cynar and Sweet Vermouth.

Created in 2017 by Loris Carotenuto at the Dorchester Hotel in London, The Queen’s Steeple is a bittersweet, orangey aperitif. Dominated by Montenegro Amaro, this drink also incorporates Cynar, Italicus and Boker’s Bitters.

A non-alcoholic riff on an Amaretto Espresso Martini, the Deja Brew will indeed feel familiar to a coffee cocktail lover. With non-alcoholic Amaretto, non-alcoholic Coffee Liqueur, Little Drippa and Vanilla Syrup, this drink is delicious and sophisticated.

A bit of a riff on the classic Brandy Metropolitan, the Capetonian embraces the best of the Mother City. With a mix of one of the Cape’s finest Brandy’s (Joseph Barry VSOP), Caperitif (a local Dry Vermouth), Angostura Bitters, as well as a local Fynbos Bitters (Naartjie Spice Bitters which can be subbed for Orange Bitters)
Unlke the South American river of the same name, the Orinoco cocktail is a wonderful mix of Cachaça, Apple Juice, Fino Sherry, White Creme de Cacao, all sweetened with Orgeat Syrup.

How good the mix of Strawberries, Raspberry Liqueur and Maple Syrup are with Bourbon will truly make you blush. The Bourbon Blush was created by Simon King at MJU in the Millennium Hotel, London way back in 2003.

Created by Emily Lanthorne at The Courtesy in Winter Park Florida, the Tequila-based Bella Donna combines bright, tropical notes with Aperol and Pineapple Syrup with a hint of herbaceousness from the Ancho Reyes Verde.

The Floridita Margarita, created back in 1999 by Robert Plotkin and Raymon Flores of BarMedia, is a beautiful blush coloured drink that combines Ruby Grapefruit Juice, Cranberry Juice, Lime, Cointreau & Tequila.

Created as a digestif, After Hours is a Martini-style cocktail with a delicate liqueur richness. With Gin, Maraschino Liqueur, Kummel Liqueur and Orange Bitters, this is drink has a lightly spicy and faintly nutty flavour.
The Lanique Rose Clover Club is a sweet, floral and silky smooth riff on the classic Clover Club, substituting Lanique and Vermouth for Gin and Lime Juice for Lemon.

If you like your cocktails with a vibrant colour and a strong, fruit, Raspberry taste, then a Tartini is the cocktail for you. With Vodka, Chambord, Cranberry Juice and a bunch of muddled Raspberries, this drink may have a ’90’s edge but still works well today.

Sure, the Parmesan Cheese Espresso Martini may have been a cocktail that went viral, but it does have its virtues. The concept of pairing coffee and cheese goes back centuries and although it has had mixed reactions, for our money, you can go past the subtle savoury and salty element that the Parmesan adds.

Forget Tequila Soda. Instead, go for the cunning highball mashup created by the Hellbender Nighttime Café in Queens, the Margarita Soda. Simplicity is the key to this drink, which uses the base of a Tommy’s Margarita topped with club soda.

With a distinctly Asian vibe, the Ichijiku (pronounced thee-zhee-kush) is as clean in flavour as it is elegant. With Fig Liqueur, Sake, Coconut Water and Aromatic Bitters, this drink should be sipped slowly and savoured.

If you are after an Old Fashioned riff with a warming complexity then a Walnut Old Fashioned should hit the spot. So further spike your Bourbon & Orange Bitters with a little Walnut Liqueur for a drink that glides effortlessly down your throat.

If your looking for a laid-back, fruity, slightly sweet Mojito riff, than a Baja Mojito is definitely your drink. Most often found on holidays or by a pool, the Gold Rum, Passionfruit and Passionfruit Liqueur all combine for drink that says RELAX in capital letters.

The Rhubarb Crumble certainly does not disappoint if you love dessert cocktails. With Rhubarb Gin as the flavour backbone of this drink, it is nicely accompanied by Ginger Cordial and Clementine Soda Water.
Note: Mediterranean Tonic can be used in place of Clementine Tonic & Ginger Cordial can be swapped for either ginger or gingerbread syrup

As the name suggests, The Dude Abides is a riff on a White Russian but more than that, the drink with it’s Brandy, Vodka, Amarula and Cold Brew Syrup is a tribute to the Cohen Brother’s The Big Lebowski itself … right down to the ‘rug’ the drink is presented on (it really ties the drink together …)

This simple and tasty 2:3:8 recipe is not as sour as a traditional sour (which is usually 3:4:8 – three-quarters sour, 1 part sweet and 2 parts strong) but the bite of the Ginger Syrup definitely makes up for it.

If you are after an aperitivo that is not only whisky-laced but also has bittersweet mingled with complex herbal notes, then the Yamabuki is the cocktail for you. Other than being a fun name to say, the drink mixes Japanese Whisky, Bianco Vermouth, Montenegro Amaro & Orange Bitters

The Tipperary first appeared in recipe books around 1916 but it hit its stride when it came out in Harry MacElhone’s 1922, ABC Of Mixing Cocktails. With the addition of Sweet Vermouth and Green Chartreuse, this is a wonderful Irish Whiskey-forward nightcap.

If you’d like your Old Fashioned to have more orange sweetness with notes of Vanilla and oak, then a Grand Old Fashioned is what you should be making. The drink replaces the usual sugar with Grand Marnier for a smoother, more elegant finish

The tart, sweetness of Kumquats mixes really well with Gin, as can be seen in The Luxembourgh cocktail.  With Gin, muddled Kumquats, Rosemary-infused Aperol, Sugar Syrup, a sprig of Rosemary and Soda Water to top, this is a delightful fruity drink.

If you used to spend your holidays berry picking as a child, then a refreshing Hedgerow Tonic will definitely bring back some memories. Mixing Gin and floral Elderflower with a combination of fruity spirits, this drink is very much a celebration of summer foraging.

Created in 2010 by Dick Bradsell, the Triple A is the ideal modern classic that will start your night off right. As you might assume the use of Absinthe, Apple Juice and Orgeat (Almond), are the three elements that denote its name.

Adapted from Stanley Clisby Arthur’s 1937 book, Famous New Orleans Drinks and How To Mix ‘Em, this Rye-based riff on a Manhattan is made sweeter with herbal Bénédictine, while bittered with Peychaud’s and Absinthe

Created by Eric Tecosky at a club on Sunset Boulevard back in the 1990s, Surfer On Acid is the Jägermeister cocktail you don’t expect. Combine Jägermeister with Coconut Rum Liqueur and Pineapple Juice for a very fruity but only slightly sweet drink.

If you’re after a Daiquiri-style cocktail that includes a nice dose of Tawny Port than you’ve got to try a Havana Cobbler. With White Rum, Tawny Port, Green Ginger Wine and Sugar Syrup, this drink might seem a little unusual but it has a wonderful spicy flavour.

Sometimes you just need the sweet/ sour that only Pomegranate gives to get the night started right. Thankfully, the Side By Sidecar not only includes the Cognac, Cointreau & lemon Juice of the original but also provides a nice Pomegranate Liqueur kick.

Life is a bit of a gamble, so why not enlist the aid of a cocktail like Lady Luck. With Gin, St Germain, Pear Nectar, Lemon Juice & Grapefruit Bitters, this is a drink that will certainly help you play your cards right.

If you are anything like us, then you can’t go past a little Evening Passion. We love it due to its smokiness (via Mezcal), its fruitiness (via Passionfruit Juice & Passionfruit Syrup), its lightness (via Soda water) and let’s face it, it’s really easy to drink.

You don’t get more classic than the Daiquiri, but if you want to switch it up a bit then turn to the Black Daiquiri. Add the spice of Kraken Rum, the full flavour of Demerara Syrup and the wonderful sour of fresh Lime Juice and you have a Daiquiri in a different dimension.
For a Sherry-spiked twist on the Bee’s Knees, you can’t go past an O’Henry. With Gin, Lemon Juice, Honey Syrup & a float of Manzanilla Sherry, this cocktail offers a nice, sweet start to the weekend.

A Bourbon & Jam is an easy mix of Blackberry Jam, Bourbon, Lemon Juice and a tiny bit of Honey. This drink, with its use of jam, is the perfect way to get the flavour of Blackberries, if the fruit is out of season.
Created for the 2017 World Class final competition by Kaitlyn Stewart, Spilt Milk is a riff on a Cobbler, with milk liqueur standing in for the sugar and a cherry shrub for the fruit.

Audrey Saunders created the French Pearl in 2006 at the Pegu Club NYC as a tribute to 19th-century Parisian architecture. It mixes notes of anise, botanicals, lime, and mint for a drink that is both fresh and complex.

Created by Jillian Vose when she was at Dead Rabbit in NYC, Psycho Killer combines Irish whiskey, white creme de cacao, banana liqueur and coffee nib-infused Campari for a drink that’s lush, bold, yet not overly sweet.
There can be no better combination in a cocktail glass than Vodka, Coffee & Whiskey (cream), so why not stor up the Muddy Water as it’s not a drink that will confuse matters in any way.

With its name taken from the SE Hilton book, The Outsiders, Stay Gold Ponyboy, Stay Gold is as vibrant in taste as it is in colour. With Bourbon, Thyme-infused Aperol & Dry Vermouth, you really won’t want to say goodbye to this slightly bitter, earthy flavoured drink.

If you are after a little Caribbean buzz, our #COTD a Jamaican Honey Bee is flying straight for you. If you’re not a fan of big Rum drinks or strong cocktails, this is certainly a drink for you and an ideal hot weather thirst quencher.

If you are looking for a more vegetal Baijiu Cocktail to try then Don’t Skip A Beet is definitely worth making. With Baijiu, Gin, Beet Juice, Lemon Juice & Grenadine, this is a well-rounded drink with a more savoury slant.

Providing a floral and slightly sour flavour profile, Apricots are the perfect accompaniment to Bourbon, as they mellow out the oaky bite. Created by Fitz Bailey, Brown-Forman mixologist, Summer At The Grove is the perfect Bourbon cocktail, with its Apricot Syrup and muddled Apricots.

There is something truly delectable about a good kiss and it seems that French kiss (No.3) does not disappoint. With an underlying character of Cognac, the Lime Juice then tames the flavours of raspberries and the rich almond flavour of Orgeat.

Created by Seth Brammer at the Filament in Dallas Texas, Brooklyn’s Finest is a nicely spiced riff on the classic Brooklyn cocktail with Cognac, Rye, Vermouth Amaro, Falernum and, of course, Angostura Bitters

With a wonderful dry finish, the Arnaud Martini is a classic cocktail with an interesting balance of Blackcurrent, Vermouth and Gin. Named for the pre-ward French actress, pianist and singer Yvonne Arnaud.

A delicate Gin sour, with lots of green tea flavor up front and an earthy, sweet-and-sour finish. Once the Gin is infused with Green Tea (which only takes a couple of hours) add Lemon Juice and Honey Syrup for
A riff on the Manhattan, the Emerald is not only an easy drink to make, but it is one that allows your choice of Irish Whiskey (and Sweet vermouth) to truly shine through.

Originating back from Jerry Thomas’ day, the Prescription Julep gives a nod to the days when Juleps used to be prescribed for medicinal purposes. And who wouldn’t want to be prescribed a refreshing mix of Rye, Cognac, Mint Leaves, Sugar Syrup and Orange Bitters.
Nothing makes the rich almond flavour of Amaretto come to life better than honey and if you then mix that with Cognac and Islay Single Malt Whiskey, you get the brilliantly balanced Homely Smoke.

Nothing goes better with Vermouth than fruit, as is seen with Django Reinhardt. Created by San Diago bartender Erick Castro from Polite Provisions, this is a cocktail that blends Dry Vermouth, Lemon Juice, Simple Syrup and some muddled Orange slices.

There is no drink that could sound better right now, than the Feel-Good hit Of The Summer. Created by New York gastropub Moonrise Izakaya, this drink is a wonderful mix of White Rum, Cognac, Pineapple Juice, Orange Juice, Coconut Cream & Water.
Created by Dale “King Cocktail” DeGroff, the Irish Blonde is a boozy but bright Irish Whiskey cocktail that mixes in Dry Orange Curaçoa, Fino Sherry and a dash of Orange Bitters.

While this Daiquiri variation is called the Winter Daiquiri, don’t let the name fool you. This drink is equally at home poolside as it is fireside. The duo of Rums makes this cocktail more complex, with Banks 5 Island Rum adding depth and Black Strap Rum adding notes of molasses, coffee, and cloves.

There’s no better way to celebrate Easter than with the Easter Cocktail. Created by Simon King at the MJU bar in the Millenium Hotel in London, the Vanilla Vodka in this drink really lifts the Crème de Cacao, while the Cardamom adds a little sweet spice to the mix.

When you get a mix of Bourbon, Coconut Liqueur, Grape Juice, toasted Coconut Syrup, Lemon Juice and black food jell together, for a drink that is carbonated for a tropical soda feel, then you know some sort of shape-shifting Trickster must be involved.

Who needs Vodka when you can create an Espresso Martini-style cocktail with Tequila. 1800 Tequila have created a Tequila Coffee that incorporates Tequila, Coffee Liqueur, Créme de Cacao, Cold Drip Coffee and a little Pedro Ximenez Sherry.

Tatanka is the Native American word for buffalo which of course refers to the Bison Grass Vodka used in this drink. Reminiscent of Earl Grey Tea, the Tatanka is perfectly balanced with the addition of Apple Juice and a dash of Lime Juice.

If you’ve never had a Haitian Rum cocktail before, then Maiden Voyage is aptly named. So, crack open the Rhum Barbancourt and mix in a little of the wine-based Aperitif, Cardamaro, before adding Lemon Juice, Maple Syrups and a dash or two of Peychard’s Bitters.
“Although she couldn’t deny that she loved the cocktails she ot to try at events like New Orleans Cocktail Week, sometimes the more cultural aspects of a city, like its music, were for Vanessa, the real highlight.”

You can’t get a better cabin fever cure than the Cabin Fever Cure Flip. If the general creaminess added to two different types of rum and the sweet spice of Benedictine of this drink doesn’t stop you from climbing the walls, then nothing will …

The Fourth Regiment is a Manhattan riff that uses a trifecta of bitters, in addition to the Rye and Sweet Vermouth, to propel itself to the next level. The Orange Bitters adds a citrusy zing, the Angostura Bitters adds a wonderful spice, and the Celery Bitters adds a nice savoury element, that makes this drink unique.

It’s said that the Seapea Fizz is named for song writer and composer Cole Porter (the sound of the name mimicking Porter’s initials, C.P.). The pale green cocktail is a simple—yet bracing—mix of sugar, lemon and absinthe, but this somewhat astringent mixture is not to everyone’s taste.

As one of the world’s best selling spirit, Gin really does serve a crown, but for the moment it has a cocktail. Created by Jonathan Lind, the Gin Crown mixes Gin with its older cousin Genever with a little Walnut Liqueur and a good dose of Ginger Beer.

Created by St Germain global ambassador, Camille Ralph, the Cyn Cyn is a lighter, more delicate riff on the Negroni. The combination of Cynar, and St Germain is harmonised beautifully with the Dry Vermouth to really bring out the floral elements.

A reinvention of the classic Old Fashioned, the Slane Fashioned is created with flavours that highlight their signature triple casked process. With Slane Irish Whiskey, Oloroso Sherry, Demerara Syrup, Angostura Bitters and Barrel-Aged Bitters, this is an Old Fashioned with an Irish lilt.

The Drinkaterium is a beautiful Gin based cocktail that is a distinctive blend of aniseed flavour from the Wild Fennel and Citrus with the Lemony flavour of the Spekboom.  If Spekboom is too hard to find, the Lychee Spekboom Syrup can be subbed for a Lychee Lemon Syrup.

A bit of a margarita variation, the El Jerez mixes Tequila, Fino Sherry, Grapefruit Juice, Lime Juice & Agave Syrup. The fino sherry lengthens the drink and tones down the citrus and tequila a bit while keeping up the acidity.

If you like a Rusty Nail Cocktail, then the Very Rusty Daiquiri might be just up your alley. With smooth Caribbean Rum mixed with the spiced Whisky-flavour of Drambuie, this is a cocktail that is both rich and satisfying.

The combination of beer and berry flavours never hurt anyone and once you add a little whiskey, this is the perfect barbecue cocktail. In fact to not make it this weekend, might be thought by some to be Beyond The Pale.

Named of course after the 1930s fictional pilot and adventurer, the Biggles Sidecar is basically a ginger flavoured riff on the classic Sidecar cocktail. With Cognac, Ginger Liqueur, Lemon Juice, Sugar Syrup & Peychaud’s Bitters, this is one drink that will have you repeatedly landing back at the bar.

Like a Gingersnap Cookie but in liquid form, the Gingersnap Cocktail is a wonderful evening sipper. With Amaretto, Amaro Di Angostura, Scotch, Ginger Liqueur & Lemon Juice, this drink is smooth, spicy and an all-round crowd pleaser.

Created by Patrice Plante from Canada for Campari’s Red Diaries (2017) campaign, the Alpha is as rich in colour as it is in flavour. With muddled Raspberries, Campari, Blanco Tequila, Agave Syrup, Lemon Juice and a dash of Orgeat, this is a truly transglobal drink.

The Ruby Negroni could best be described as a great starter Negroni. If you find the bitterness of Campari & Gin a little too much, then this drink allows you to sweeten up the mix with the addition of a little Raspberry Syrup, Port, & Prosecco.

Ideal for sitting on the porch on a hot summer day, a Sweet Tea Bourbon is a perfect pitcher cocktail. With muddled Mint and Orange slices, this cocktail also combines Black Tea, Agave & Bourbon, for a relaxing libation.

For those moments when you need a little bubble and glam, there is no more accessible drink than the Glitterati. With Don Julio’s Rosado, grapefruit and lime juices and agave syrup, the bold colour is met with a tingling effervescence from the sparkling Rosé
Originally created at Bar Opiume in Singapore, the Crossbow cocktail is sophisticatedly dry. With Cointreau and Crème de Cacao, the drink has a wonderful chocolate orange taste laced with gin.

Created in 2015 by Scott Burgess at Some Place in Liverpool (UK), Le Chateau has a distinctly European vibe. Served straight up,  this cocktail uses Cognac as the base, adding herbal Benedictine and bittersweet Aperol as the supporting liqueurs.

No matter whether it’s an election year or not, there is no better aperitivo to drink than a Mount Rushmore. Created by Patrick Pistolesi at Drink Kong in Rome, this cocktail has Bourbon, Montenegro, Fino sherry and a splash of Coffee Liqueur that make it an interesting alternative to a Boulevardier.

While you could think of Fancy Free as simply a riff on a Whiskey Old Fashioned, where the Maraschino takes the place of sugar, there is much more to this drink than that. Surprisingly dry, the mix of Bourbon & Maraschino is made all the more aromatic with both Angostura & Orange Bitters.

The Cheshire Cat is certainly a cocktail that will put a big grin on your face. A twist on the classic Vieux Carre Cocktail, this substitutes Scotch for Rye Whiskey and Cherry Heering for Sweet Vermouth and it’s all balanced with a nice dose of Punt E Mez.
In Poland, Bison Grass Vodka and Apple Juice are a classic combination and when you add an equal part of Honey Liqueur, well, then, you have a Martini like no other.

The Maple Leaf cocktail is a simple, reasonably mellow, yet moreish riff on a Whiskey Sour with a silky Bourbon and tart Lemon Juice, both of which are sweetened with a thinned Maple Syrup.
“While Vanessa often found it easy to set hearts on fire, building a simple camp fire had proved a smidge more difficult. Luckily Juan had been able to throw together a Whiskey Sour riff with hints of caramel that seemed perfect for the occasion. While the night air was still a little warm, this drink was a reminder that this would be their last summer break, with more autumnal weather was soon to come.”

Suze has often been associated with artists, so it’s no surprise then that Maggie Eckl at Dead Rabbit named this drink, The Artist’s Muse when she created it in 2016. Bittersweet and fruity, this cocktail has Pisco, Suze, Crème de Pêche, Lemon Juice, Sugar Syrup and Egg White.

Interestingly, the Torpedo Blu is named after a 1960s Italian song. That aside though, it has a nice mix of  Tequila, Chambord Liqueur, Simple Syrup, Lime Juice & Elderflower Tonic. With such a combination, this is a drink that will take you on a journey from Mexico to the Italian Alps.

This pandemic has given tequila lovers the opportunity to experiment at home, and home is the exact inspiration for Homespun. I love low prep and replicable drinks that everyone can enjoy and taking everyday ingredients out of my own pantry was an authentic way to make that happen – Bec Bailey – Cielo Rooftop – Brisbane

Created by the late Sasha Petraske at his famous Milk & Honey, the Apple Jack is obviously, rich in apple flavour. As the name suggests, the drink is a sweet and sour mix of Applejack Brandy, Apple Juice, Lemon Juice & Sugar Syrup.

Sometimes referred to as an Alpine Spritz (due to the inclusion of Elderflower), the Hugo Spritz is a palate-pleasing Italian Aperitif Spritz. Refreshing and light, the combination of Elderflower Syrup, Mint & Prosecco make this an ideal cocktail for the summer months.
Utilising Tequila Don Julio Rosado, a silky-smooth tequila finished in Ruby Port Wine Casks as a base, the Rosado Spritz is the perfect Paloma riff to sip in the sun by the pool.

Whiskey and Sake come together with Ginger Liqueur to create this ode to the Manhattan, the Manhattan Love Story. Sake takes on the modifier role (typically played by Vermouth in a Manhattan) and the ginger liqueur gives it a sweet and spicy undertone.

Gary Regan, in his book Joy of Mixology, adapted the original 1930s recipe by substituting Amaretto for Crème de Noyau and dropped the Orange Bitters. He, of course, tweaked with the ratios a bit but thankfully kept the Gin, lemon Juice and Angostura Bitters.

Lighter and zestier in flavour than the original Paloma, the Swedish Paloma is a riff that swaps out tequila for Grapefruit Vodka. To that is added Grapefruit Juice, Lime Juice, Simple Syrup and Soda Water.

Doomed to sail the seven seas forever but unable to make port, The Flying Dutchman is a legendary ghost ship. In liquid form, she mixes Gin, Green Melon Cordial, Green Apple Juice, Lemon Juice and, of course, a dash of saline solution. If seen on the ocean, she is a portent of doom. Seen in a glass, she’s topped with Prosecco, dill oil and a sprig of dill and far less ominous.

Believed to be one of the best of today’s Sherry cocktails, Remember The Alimony, is a wonderful slow sipper. In addition to the Sherry, the drink combines Cynar & Gin for a wonderful cocktail that will definitely become a modern classic.
Mixing fresh cucumber and gin with the herbaceous flavour of Green Chartreuse will result in a Lone Palm. This drink is vibrant and ultra-refreshing, created by Diego Valencia at ARCA in Tulum.

When a cocktail has the name Cognac, we all know what the dominant spirit will be but what you may not have guessed is the South African liqueur that it mixes so well with. Van Der Hum is a Tangerine Liqueur, so it’s complex citrus flavours play beautifully with Cognac & St Germain.

As the name suggests, the Negroni Bianca Bergamotto is a Bianco Negroni with added bergamot citrus complexity. With Gin, Bitter Bianco Liqueur, Italicus and Bianco Vermouth, this drink was developed to help promote Italicus when it launched.

How could we resist combining two of the world’s greatest loves – Gin & Coffee? With Coffee Liqueur, Gin & Tonic Water, the Turbo G&T will definitely get your night (or day for that matter) started right.
Bartender Jeffrey Morgenthaler of Portland’s Clyde Common created this extravagant twist on a whiskey sour. With Marmalade as the star, it mixes beautifully with Bourbon, Lemon Juice and Egg White.

Although Toronto is a Manhattan riff, it gets its name from the use of Whisky from north of the border. Although the Canadian Whisky is there to tame the bitter bite of the Fernet Branca, it joins Sugar Syrup & Angostura Bitters for a drink that’s rich and bitter.

If you are after a tropical cocktail that doesn’t get too sweet, then the robust How To Kill A Friend is an option that you may not have considered. Similar to the classic Jungle Bird, this drink includes Mezcal, Campari, PX Sherry, Triple Sec, as well as Pineapple and Lime Juices.
“Like so many women before her, Vanessa couldn’t resist a soft opening. And while the night had gone off without a hitch, the early morning found her outside, sitting on the curb with a cocktail in hand. While she loved her friends, there were times when their insistence that they were, in fact, true Mezcal connoisseurs, made her contemplate how simple it would be to find a whole new use for a ice mallet.”

A wonderfully light and tempting drink, the Hotel Georgia was named after the hotel of the same name in Vancouver which opened in 1927. The drink itself is assumed to be dated from two decades later in the 1940s and combines Gin, Orgeat, Lemon Juice, Orange Flower Water & Egg White.

If you are in a bit of a jam with the flavour of your cocktails, might we suggest a Blueberry Jam & Prosecco Cocktail? Luckily, not as sweet as it sounds, this drink has a nice tart edge thanks to the Blueberries, Lemon Juice and dry Prosecco.

Created at Cape Town’s The Queen’s, yet named, of course, for the region where the main spirit, Glenfiddich Whisky, is from, the Speyside is as gentle and fruity as its namesake with Honey Syrup and Peach Bitters
Created in 2003, by Murray Stenson at the. Zig Zag Café in Seattle, the Chas has a wonderful tang. With great Bourbon personality, the drink is uplifted with hints of Almond and Orange.

An Amaro twist on the classic Margarita, the Monterita is a wonderful bittersweet drink that replaces Cointreau with Montenegro Amaro. Add to that a little Lime Juice Juice and Agave Syrup and you have a citrusy Italian riff.

For an Absinthe tipple that contains serious magic, you can’t go past the Necromancer. The Absinthe & Lillet Blanc are brightened up by St Germain and a dash of Gin. A riff on the even more classic Corpse Reviver, this cocktail casts a spell of its own on all who drink it.

It’s as if Fernet Branca and Cold Brew Coffee were made for each other and they play delightfully in the Light Flight Cocktail. They seem to be having so much fun, that floral St Germain joins them, as does a good dose of Tonic.

Created by Jess Yurko from the Queensyard in New York, Migratory Coconuts is definitely a baller of a rum Cocktail. With White Rum, Coconut Syrup, Lime Juice and garnished with Hibiscus Ice, this is one drink you want in your hand for a New York summer.

A favourite for prohibition drinkers, the Chrysanthemum is a complex, zesty and potent drink that shows Vermouth off beautifully. With a little Benedictine and Absinthe added to the mix, this is definitely a drink that has stood the test of time.

One of the most visually impressive classic cocktails, the Ramos Gin Fizz is all about the dry shake and the extended shaking required to achieve the towering soufflé. While the ingredients may look simple, this drink is a bit of a workout but well worth the effort.
“Taking in the best of New Orleans Cocktail Week, had lead Vanessa to the iconic Bourbon Street. After popping onto a few bars, she decided to do the most touristy thing she could by ordering the most iconic classic the city had to offer. Luckily, she eventually found a bartender athletic enough to bring her request satifacturally to a head.”

Nothing is better at the end of a long day than the wonderful combination of flavours that is found in the Susquehanna Cocktail. The spice of the Rye cuts perfectly through the sweet almond flavour of the Amaretto for a drink that will certainly make your day.

If you’re after an “extra dirty” Martini but with a touch of spice, then the Salt & Pepper Martini, created by Michael McIlroy at Temple Bar in NYC, is your answer. The Celery Bitters, Manzanilla Sherry and Saline Solution add that dirty element, while the Liqueur and pepper garnish add the spice.

If you are after a cocktail that is well balanced with a rich fruity flavour, then you can’t go past the Godfrey. With Blackberries, Cognac, Grand Marnier, Crème De Mûre, Lemon Juice & Sugar Syrup, this is an ideal drink for humid summer days.

A refreshing, summery twist on the classic, the French Negroni cocktail will have you instructing the cabana boy to keep them coming. An equal parts drink like its name-sake, the cocktail mixes Pampelle, Gin & Vermouth Blanc – trés delicious!

While you might think of the Paloma as the ultimate Tequila cocktail, swap that out for Mezcal and add a little IPA beer and you’ve got a cocktail that enhances the original in the most delightful way.
